reviewText: This was one of the most disappointing movie-watching experiences I have ever had. I was totaly duped by the unreliable film critics not to mention the false advertising promoting the movie.After watching this you will not be at all surprised that it was based on a comic book, err...graphic novel. All the dialogue was absolutely atrocious. Some of the worst lines ever.  The sex scenes were goofy, a man and his wife having extremely awkward sex like they were first timers. One of which had the man raping his wife with her seemingly enjoying and welcoming it like in the infamous scene from Straw Dogs. Marie Bello's body looked like a dried up old woman and made me sick. And the cuffs did not quite match the collars.The initial scene is a rip-off of David Lynch with ominous bad guys acting mysterious, but then turns into typical Hollywood violence with just a couple of madmen on the loose apparently shooting everyone they come across.The pacing was slow with no reason for the viewer to think as there is nothing to think about or attempt to figure out. At the end when Viggo admits he is a gangster he suddenly adopts the most absurdly bad east coast gangster accent I have ever heard....that is until WIlliam Hurt started talking. Hurt gives one of the most ridiulous bad guy performances I've ever seen as a nerdy guy who is supposed to be some kind of bad dude but inspired no fear or forboding whatsoever. This was even worse then his Lost In Space atrocity. Of course in true Hollywood yahoo style Viggo kills everyone with extreme ease but nobody can kill him - like Die Hard except boring.The protagonist's kid gets bullied constantly in school and then all of a sudden morphs into a combination of Bruce Lee and Mike Tyson and kicks the living crap out of two tough guys which reminded me of Spiderman except at least that character had super powers which allowd him to turn into a one-man wrecking crew. Brutal. Total rip-off of Spiderman. I was expecting him to do a backflip or something.The whole Big Finale was a joke with Mafia guys with Irish names acting tough but looking stupid with unrealistic accents spewing silly dopey dialogue which sounded like it was written by junior high kids. The whole part when Hurt is telling Viggo why he never got married is an expmple of bad insipid writing. "Because there's so many beautiful women out there why commit to just one? And cheating is too complicated, its not even worth it."  !!! A gangster who can't handle the task of cheating on his wife. Like a gangster's wife would even care anyway. Really stupid and pathetic. Then they attempt to kill him with a garrot like this is some sneaky assassination scene. There are guys behind him, why not just shoot him? I was surprised that William Hurt didn't have a swimming pool with sharks with laser beams attached to their freaking heads. Then Hurt tries to shoot him from 8 feet away and can't get the job done. Tough guy! The whole Mansion/Finale scene may have been the worst five minutes in movie-making history. I would have laughed, but it was just so lame and boring...Lots more completely idiotic senseless things happen. At the end he leaves the mansion and washed the blood off in some muddy lake. Why not make use of one of the dozen bathrooms that must exist inside that castle and take a shower? When he returns home after driving both ways for 16 hours (!) and killing a bunch of guys between the two trips without eating sleeping or anything else he walks in the kitchen where his family is eating supper at this very small table and sits down. The young daughter (who provided the only decent acting in the whole flick) puts an empty plate down in front of him then the son (Peter parker) moves a plate of food from two inches in front of Viggo's plate to two inches beside his plate in an apparent symbolic gesture to show that the kids still loved their pops even though he is a murderous felon. They should have at least been at a bigger table because it looked dumb him moving the plate unnecessarily from two inches in front of him to two inches beside him. Nobody said anything at the table. Why didn't he just say hey or something? Then the  wife and him just stare at each with tears in their eyes. And that's it. There are no spoilers because there's nothing to spoil. Watch this movie if you like to be bored.It was the cheesiest flick ever, with the worst acting ever, the most terrible dialogue ever and extraordinarily amateurish storytelling. There was not a single interesting scene or conversation or worthwhile event or line or anything that would make this respectable. Bad acting, bad writing, bad directing, bad everything. This is the kind of movie that gives Hollywood a bad name. It even had the clueless local Sheriff!!Truly one of the worst movies I have ever watched. Everybody involved in this movie should commit suicide and film it as it would be more interesting and have a better storyline and probably better dialogue than this abortion. Did I mention that this movie was awful?

reviewText: One of the best and most compelling films this year, it seriously illuminates the violence inside of us, particularly repressed and past violence, and the force it has when unleashed.This is about small town Tom, who has a "perfect," "sleepy" life in semi-rural middle America, until some unscrupulous characters appear and propel him into life shattering violence.This is very well acted and directed, the pacing and fury of the violence, the relationship between husband and wife, father and son, brother and brother are all taut and tensely visceral.It excels as a social drama, as a pulp-noir-domestic-drama, and smart action film.

reviewText: I'm the first to admit that I'm a huge David Cronenberg fan, but I was rather disappointed in A History of Violence. His most acclaimed movie so far, is also perhaps his most tepid. There's no doubt that A History of Violence is a great movie, for about an hour. After that, the movie falls apart due to a lack of drama, and suffers from a pointless and seemingly tacked-on ending.The director does a fabulous job of creating an eerily quiet tone where the audience is on edge waiting for something horrible to happen at any moment, and perfectly films the violent fight scenes so we can see exactly what is happening. He also coaches some astounding performances out of his leads and fills the movie with raw emotion that flies off the screen, whether it is passion, hate or anger. But even Cronenberg can't save the limp second act, and the movie tends to drag, often straining the realms of credibility.Viggo Mortensen stars as Tom Stall - a quiet man running a diner in the small town of Millbrook, Indiana. Tom leads a simple and fulfilling life of a man who is emblematic of the American dream, as he raises his family on a small farm and madly loves his wife, Edie (Maria Bello). But his serene life is shattered when two killers on a crime spree decide to rob Tom's diner late one evening. He shoots the men dead and overnight finds himself a small-town hero, as well as the focus of the national news media.It's this notoriety that attracts the attention of three seriously unsettling shady figures, a crew fronted by the scarred and scary Ed Harris. These new villains seem entirely convinced that they know Tom from the past ... and that "Tom" is not even remotely the guy's name. So now this unassuming husband, devoted father, and mild-mannered businessman finds himself swept up into the harsh world of secrets, betrayals, deceptions, and a whole lot of violence.It's a simple story that Cronenberg handles reasonably effectively but his mistake is that he ties up the enigma, the question of who Tom actually is, to early which leaves us wondering how he's going to pad out the rest of the film. Literally, we understand the last half hour, but artistically it is several steps below the wonderfully crafted first hour and it all feels quite anticlimactic and pedestrian.The movie is mostly saved by the performances. Mortensen is absolutely sensational as Tom, the small town, shy, quiet family man who gets caught up in a world of trouble he never could have imagined, but he's smart enough to keep the mystery alive as he plays with his voice and eyes to make us question his past.Maria Bello gives us one of her best performances to date as Edie, Tom's loving, devoted, and gradually desperate wife; she creates a character entirely real and sympathetic. She's gutsy and raw, but also remarkable sexual in nature. It's a brave, fearless performance that also includes, some full frontal nudity.Sadly, William Hurt comes into the movie much too late and in the portion of the film that just doesn't work that well. He's hammy and over the top in a role he never should have taken. The audience in the screening we were at started giggle as he chewed the scenery and displayed one of the worst accents ever on screen; he was suitably creepy but also kind of funny.The critics are, somewhat unjustifiably, having a love affair with A History of Violence, maybe because the simplistic nature of the subject matter makes it Cronenberg's most accessible film, and it deals fairly obviously with the hereditary nature of violence - treating it like a chronic disease; something that can be treated, delayed, and possibly even cured.But as a tale of haunted pasts and borrowed lives, A History of Violence is sadly, Cronenberg's least interesting, settling for some genre set pieces and a pair of eccentric performances by villains, Ed Harris and William Hurt. The director certainly remains a master of creating unease and postulating complicated thematic interests, but with all its violence, the movie is ultimately bloodless, without any real body to it at all. Mike Leonard October 05.

reviewText: Two men walk out of a motel and get into a convertible. [No seatbelts?] What are they up to? Next we see a family at home. Tom Stoll works in a small restaurant in a small town. There is conflict in the boys gym. [Believable?] The parents spend time together when the children are away. [Does the film slow down afterwards?] Then those two men show up in town and start trouble in Tom's restaurant. Tom finishes it. This makes the newspapers and brings in more business, and unwanted attention. Three men show up, one claims to know Tom from Philadelphia. Sheriff Sam checks them, they have records. What's up? "Get the shotgun!" Is the family threatened? [Why does Tom have to run to his house far out of town?] Why did Sarah leave her Mom Edie when shopping? [Believable?]Jack is a chip off the old block, he knows how to handle Joey. [Too good to be true?] Will a court order keep Carl Fogarty away? There is action that was telegraphed in the earlier scenes. [Is this believable? The scenes seem to be concocted for violent dramatic scenes.] Will Edie and Tom get along? Will a voice from the past call Tom? [This is a new story that drags in spots.] his brother has a complaint. But Joey is like "Rambo", he is hard to kill. Can he wash away his sins in a pond? Back home in Indiana life returns to normal. [Believable?] This story just stops, there are no after effects from the action in Philadelphia, the City of Brotherly Love.The violent scenes seem to be the sole purpose of this film, like some kind of pornography of violence. Its as if the writers concocted graphically violent scenes then wrote a story to link them together. Some scenes would have made this X-rated back in the 1970s. Other reviewers pointed out the logical flaws in this story.

reviewText: Viggo Mortensen stars as Tom Stall in this psychological thriller from David Cronenberg, the director who brought us the classic chiller Scanners.  Cronenberg has always been known as a "weird" filmmaker, but this film seems to levitate him to new levels of oddness.  Tom Stall own's Stall's Diner in Midbrook, Indiana, and he leads a life of peacefulness.  In fact, the only drama going on in the Stall family right now is the son, Jack, having bully problems at school.  That is, until Tom runs into some "bad men" one night at the diner, and quickly dispatches of them in a brutal, professional style.  After the unavoidable publicity following this event, Ed Harris rolls into town, saying Tom's real name is Joey Cusack, and harassing the entire Stall family.  Tom denies all links to organized crime back in Philly, but the viewer is left to wonder what is really going on here.I am still on the fence when it comes to Cronenberg's films.  Scanners was a little too odd for me, Rabid was a gruesome, yet interesting film, and The Fly/The Dead Zone seem altogether too normal to warrant any acclaim.  This film, however, seems to set Cronenberg apart from other directors.  You can tell that he completely controlled this movie from beginning to end.  Whether it is the steady, unmoving camera shots that add so much tension, the awkward yet realistic sexuality between Tom and his wife, Edie, or the brutal, unflinching, ultra-realistic violence that is, when inflicted on the viewer, unsettling to say the least.  Cronenberg totally mastered this film.  There is no visible flaw to this movie whatsoever.  The characters are all identifiable, and the dialogue is absolutely amazing.  Particularly the dialogue from Ed Harris and William Hurt.  William Hurt was robbed of an Oscar for this film.  He should have won Best Supporting Actor, no question, but that is another topic for another day.  Even though Harris and Hurt are only in the film for a limited amount of time, they carry the first and second halves of the film, respectively.  Their simple, uncaring attitude towards the vicious acts of violence they participate in creates a very cautionary appearance to the viewer.  The characters are funny, and in Hurt's case, even likable, but you still have to be scared of them because of their power and what they are willing to do with it.A History of Violence is one of my favorite films of 05, and wish it would have gotten a little more recognition at the Oscars, but hey, the Oscars aren't really there to award great movies or actors, they are there so the Hollywood "insiders" all have one night to get together and announce their opinions to the known world.If you want to see a well-made film, with a deep meaning that even I'm not sure I totally get, you need to see A History of Violence.  One of the better films of the recent years...
summary: Disturbing, unnerving, tough to watch....a great film

reviewText: I was never a big Cronenberg fan although I have respected him as a filmaker. He constantly pushes the boundaries of his filmaking abilities and what he thinks an audience will find "exceptable." A History of Violence is an apt subject for him then, with scenes so gutwrenchingly real, in terms of peoples reactions to violence and what happens over the course of the incidents.It's also a study in the very real idea of violence begets more violence. This is never more aptly shown through Tom Stall's son. We see him confronted by a bully twice, both handled differently because of the violence he's witnessing because of his father.Viggo's face is a study of contradictions. We want to believe him, but we're not sure of what to believe. He handles it smoothly, as he does every other role he does, perfectly blending himself with the character. Maria Bello is perfect as his wife. Going, almost always, against what we think her character is going to do. The actor who plays his son is incredible with the role. I knew, and in some ways was him in high school. William Hurt was the surprising element in this film. He was incredible. All of these actors were fantastic.Yes, it's violent, but not without cause or meaning, the way any good action/drama should be.

reviewText: This movie was amazing: The back story, the outstanding characters and their acting, the violence. Nearly everything was gold.I can't fathom the reason why this rating is rather low. The movie had very few flaws if any.Things take place in a small, quiet town where you'd be a fool not to know everyone around you. Everyone's children grow up, and go to school with each other, and they press on as decent citizens just trying to make decent of themselves, settle down and have sex like rabbits do.David Cronenberg's character, Tom Stall is a decent man, making a decent living, running a coffee shop, down the road from his house. He's a great man with a extremely shady past; he used to kill people who didn't agree with him. Putting that in the past, he's made and raised outlandishly great children, and does right by them, up until he smacks his boy for talking back.The movie is NO stranger to violence either. Everyone seems to be after Tom, for his less-than-innocent past, and for good reason. He gives them what they want, WHEN he wants and that's that. Some mobsters come to his diner, scaring his wife s.h.i.t.l.e.s.s., trying to rape an innocent female worker, with nice breasts, and harasses the pants off of everyone. Tom demands that they come to terms, that they are all closed up and the dumbest of them all, says, "COFFEE!!"If it were my diner, I'd call the cops, to escort this loser out of my diner, and back onto the streets, where they all belong! But no, Tom wimps out, caving in, and giving them what they want, to shut the the F up. I don't blame him personally, and would have handled it much differently, never giving in. But I digress...Tom ends up smashing a coffee pot, right into the guy with a bad, bad eye (Tom barb-wired him up in the past XD), and makes sure these royal asspains don't return.But they do. Once. And they go to his house to retrieve what they want; Tom. He ends up shooting two of the bastards, and his son shoots the one with 1 1/2 eyes. Like father, like son I suppose. Long ago though, Tom had another identity: the name escapes me momentarily, but like I've said, he's done some dark stuff in his yesteryears.The sex scene in this movie later on is super-hot and super-steamy. Tom removes his wife's black panties, and lifts up her black dress. As her thighs yearn for a man strong enough, to be inside of her, she grows anxious, and all the hornier. He finally pulls his faithful, tried-and-true blue jeans down, just below his nice arse, and humps the brains, right out of his attractive wife's head, like nobody's business. Had it lasted another 1 minute or so, I would have seriously had to play a more active role in the situation at hand. =^)Overall, I think this is worth a BUY not a RENT, and you'd be good to watch it as soon as you make this worthy purchase. I know I will!Cover Art: B-Dialogue: A-Story: ACharacters: ALength: AOverall: A4.6 stars.

reviewText: I believe that everyone is entitled to his or her own opinion, but I have several thoughts about this movie which I would like to share, for fear that many people will fall victim to the rampant abundance of false reviews that have been posted about this film.A wonderfully selected cast of truly great actors deliver extremely flat and uninspired performances, and plot is lacking in many areas. Besides, who wants to watch a movie that pretty much has zero surprises? There was NO DOUBT in my mind as to Mortensen's true self, or of what the movie's end result would be. I am sure that the graphic novel which inspired this movie was better as written, since it is hard to imagine a less ingenious plot for a film.Maria Bello was the only actor who delivered a somewhat good performance, although I felt that The director just schlocked together the sex scenes, which could have been made to show the viewer some real humanity. These scenes sort of just appear haphazardly in the movie, and are reduced to mere gratuitous sex / nude scenes by their lack of development - they just aren't credible.For those of you who insist on torturing yourselves with this film, I highly suggest continuing the self-deprecation by watching the 'bonus disc' which has all sorts of goodies. I, myself, laughed out loud at the special 'making of' short about this movie, since the actors and director so obviously think that this film is a 'masterpiece.' It is almost painful to watch this group in self-adoration at the Cannes Film Festival, and I am reminded of the childrens' story - "The Emperor's New Clothes."
summary: No plot whatsoever! 1 star because I cannot give it a ZERO! *SPOILERS*

reviewText: Based on the John Wagner and Vince Locke graphic novel. At first glance, A History of Violence appears to be a mainstream action thriller, but if you pay attention, as in all Cronenberg films, it has a few layers underneath its skin.The movie opens with two thugs heading for the small town where Tom Stall (Mortensen) and his family live. The thugs stop by Tom's diner and threaten him and his employees at gunpoint. Tom fights back, killing them both. He becomes a local hero and gets much unwanted attention from the press and TV news crews. His newfound fame also attracts some mean looking men led by Ed Harris's character who believes Tom is somebody he once knew a long time ago. They began harrassing Tom and his family. Is Tom really who he appears to be? How come he's so good at killing people?When I saw this film in theatres, by the time the end credits rolled, I was so psyched that I wanted it to last for another half hour. The build-up to the final confrontation was well crafted.  Viggo Mortensen and Maria Bello had great chemistry on-screen and Mortensen's portrayal of Tom was right on the money. Ed Harris and William Hurt were amazing as usual. Cronenberg's vision made a world of difference in adapting a story that could've easily have left a lot to be desired and gone unnoticed in the hands of a less capable director. He gave it a lot of depth and took the revenge flick one step further, in my opinion.Check out the special features on the DVD for a look at Scene 44, a trademark scene of Croneneberg which he opted to leave out of the film. There's also a 60+ minute documentary plus a few interesting featurettes. Whether you like revenge stories or you're a fan of Cronenberg's, A History of Violence won't disappoint.

reviewText: Before watching this film I saw the recent film "Capote". In "Capote" he hear him say, when talking about his book, In Cold Blood, that there are two worlds; the quiet conservative one and the criminally violent. If In Cold Blood perfectly depicted those worlds clashing in literature, David Cronenberg's "A History of Violence" perfectly captures it in cinema."A History of Violence" is placed in a small Indiana town where Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) runs a diner. It's the kind of place where everyone knows your name. We are not in the land of Cronenberg's other films, we are in Leave it to Beaver land. This is one of those small towns where the local residents say, "here we look out for our own."One night as Tom is closing the diner two strangers walk into town. In an earlier scene we know they were part of a mass murder. Tom politely tells them it is closing time but the two men do not leave. They demand a cup of coffee. Later the scene turns violent when one of the men pulls out a gun and threatens to kill one of the workers. In that split second Tom acts, and his actions surprise everyone in the town. He kills the two men, making him a local hero.The next day Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris) shows up and claims Tom Stall is not Tom Stall at all. He is in fact Joey Cusack a mobster from back east, Philly to be exact. Tom explains to Carl he clearly has him mistaken for someone else but Carl starts to threaten Tom and his family. And so we are left with the question, who is right? Is Tom really Tom or is Tom really the person Carl claims he is?Cronenberg is exploring a lot in this film. First of all we have a depiction of the duality within ourselves. How seemingly kind gentle people are actually capable of violence. Next we have the small quiet town that isn't so quiet after all. And finally we have Cronenberg's message about how people seem to feel violence is the best way to solve a solution. And I've even heard some people get really politcal and say this movie is an examination of George Bush's foreign policy. I'm not going to touch that issue.One of the reasons I really enjoyed watching this film is because Cronenberg, in some bizarre way, makes the film seem somewhat believeable. The film is tightly crafted where it follows a path of logic and slowly build upon the lead character in a convincing and satisfing way. The big surprise in the film is not whether or not Tom is who he says he is or not, but the effect it has on his family and the way they come to conclude whether it is true or not.One of the most interesting relationships in the film is between father and son. Jack Stall (Ashton Holmes) is a passive kid. He is constantly getting bullied by Bobby Jackson (Kyle Schmid) and one day Jack fights back. Is violence hereditary? What about children from abusive households?Some people may complain the film is too violent. I wonder what planet they are from. Here we have a movie that is called "A History of Violence" and is directed by David Cronenberg. Did they honestly think this was going to be the sequel to "Finding Nemo"? The film's depiction of violence did not bother me in the slightest. And I'd really be surprised if someone told me they found it too gruelsome.I also have to mention how impressed I was with Viggo Mortensen's acting. I didn't care much for him in the "Lord of the Ring" movies but here he displays a pretty wide range. It is a tough part to play and he pulls it off nicely. Why he didn't get nominated for an Oscar is beyond me, yet William Hurt did. Anyone else see something wrong with this picture? And Maria Bello as his wife Edie also does a nice job. She shows the conflict a wife must go through when she has doubts about the man she has married. In fact everyone in the picture never goes over the top. Given the setting we are in the film has a sure touch and Cronenberg plays his cards just right. Mortensen, Bello, Harris and the children are all right on. They are fully developed, intriging characters. They are multi-dimensional.One can argue this is Cronenberg's most mainstream effort and maybe it is. But don't look upon that as a fault. The film still retains Cronenberg's twisted and sordid view of life. And just as his other films, "Spider", "Crash", "M. Butterfly" and "Naked Lunch" have pushed some buttons, so will "A History of Violence" and honestly, I wouldn't have Cronenberg any other way.Bottom-line: One of David Cronenberg's most mainstream attempts and one of his best. The cast is simply great to watch. Everyone makes their character believeable. These are multi-dimensional people. The script is tightly crafted and suspenseful.

reviewText: Hard to believe A History Of Violence is by the same man who gave us The Fly, Spider, Naked Lunch, and Dead Ringers, some of the darkest, most visually spellbinding, and daringly inventive movies of our time.  Cronenberg is truly among the greatest directors working today, but AHOV reads like he took a long nap and woke up in the mood to give a lecture.  It would be hard to imagine what the world needs less than another ultra-violent gangster movie, that said, Cronenberg has provided something much more dense and interesting than that.  AHOV works well as a chilling suspense picture, with nice twists.  By today's standards there is not that much on-screen violence, what there is occurs quickly, and it is always essential to the plot - never gratuitous.But the problem with AHOV is the heavy-handed didactic nature; indeed one can picture Cronenberg standing in front of the class.  "Today's theme is violence and we will be exploring it from the following viewpoints.  (1) What happens when a man's violent past catches up with him?  (2) Is mankind inherently violent?  Is this necessary and even desirable given a Darwinian paradigm?  (3) To what extent is a man's character defined by genetics and experience as opposed to being willed and self-determined?  (4) How many different types of violence can you define in this film? (5) Sarah had sexual encounters with both Tom and Joey, compare and contrast. (6) Tom's son Jack seems to undergo a radical transformation, from wimp to brute.  How does this dramatic duality reflect Tom's situation?"AHOV is exceptionally well made, the pacing is extraordinary, and the way we see Tom/Joey agonize as his personality morphs to and fro is terrific, Viggo Mortenson gives a marvelous performance, as does Heidi Hayes.  But AHOV would have been stronger had it not so obviously carried a tutorial agenda.  Ed Harris, who is always good, is exceptionally good while William Hurt, who is frequently very good, is awful. What others saw in this performance evaded me.  Hurt exudes not one shred of raw personal authority, sadism, or thuggish, lowbrow myopia; any South Philly deli counter man could have surpassed his torpid portrayal.  Overall, AHOV is an excellent film, had it been made by anyone else it would have gotten top rating.  But I've come to expect the best from Cronenberg, and this ain't it.

reviewText: The plot is basically two very, very bad guys come to town and threaten the staff and customers in Tom Stall's diner at closing time. In the ensuing fight Tom kills the bad guys. Tom becomes a town hero and is written up in the papers along with his picture. Then people come to town looking for Tom and insisting he's someone else -- a mafia-type hit man.The movie lets you see Tom prior to the incident at his diner and after with his family. They are trying to get back to normal but these strangers have put a wedge of mistrust between Tom and his wife and unsettled their teenage son who's been dealing with daily school bullying. Their young daughter takes it all in stride.You can see that the doubt is pulling them apart. Everything you've seen so far is Tom and his wife -- don't believe in violence as a way to solve problems and they had been a very loving and close family. Will these doubts pull them apart? Are the doubts justified? When you learn the answers you're faced with the same problems as all the members in the Stall family. If you make yourself into the person you want to be -- then who are you the person you were or the one you aspire to be. Who defines a person.It's an action adventure and there is of course a lot of the Director's usual violence (graphic and at least plot related) but beyond that is the question of who determines a person's identity.  Lots of food for thought here.
summary: Are you who you make of yourself or what others expect...

reviewText: "A History of Violence" is a thoroughly engrossing film.  The viewer is drawn into a web of intrigue like a moth to a flame.The essence of the story is that Tom Stall is a resident of a small US town called Millbrook in Indiana.  He has a beautiful wife, two kids and runs a small diner in the town.  He is well respected and regarded.  His world, however, is turned upside down when two low life criminals take it upon themselves to rob his business at gun point.  Tom seizes an opportunity and manages to unarm the pair and, in the process, kill them both.  He is hailed as a hero standing up for the small man against crime.It is also at this point that his world becomes even more complex.  Dark figures enter the town after having seen Tom on television.  These figures identify Tom as another man with a less than respectful past.  They know him to be a murderer from Philadelphia with a history of violence.  Tom tries to ignore the claims but is unable to avoid the consequences.  How he deals with this situation covers the balance of the film.The plot is tight and often violent.  The characters are totally believable.  Both Viggo Mortensen as Tom Stall and Maria Bello as his wife deserve accolades.  Ed Harris as the nemesis from Philly is truly unnerving.See this film!  The last two minutes without a word of dialogue end the work on an emotional precipice.

reviewText: When I first saw `A History of Violence' it was being toted as one of the best studies of human behavior of the year, and so I was really anxious to experience it.  When the film ended I sat there in odd amazement.  The film opens and closes so spectacularly that I think I was struggling to really identify what my true feelings were on the film.Much like Haneke's `Cache', which was released the same year, `A History of Violence' is a study of how violence relates to human interaction, and how the very idea of the act infiltrates our every action to the point where the lines our blurred and the violence is a part of us.  As a study I find that `A History of Violence' only gets it half right.  In fact, on almost every level I find that this film is teetering on greatness, but never really falling completely over into something truly monumental.  `Cache' is undoubtedly the superior film (it truly manages to be about so much more than you think), but that doesn't mean that `A History of Violence' isn't profound in its own right.  I think that there could have been something truly remarkable here though, and so it irks me a little to know that this has been raved as one of the smartest social commentaries out there, yet it pales in comparison to a film that tackles similar themes that was released in the very same year.The film basically follows a mild mannered man named Tom who owns a diner.  When he foils a robbery and kills some men he gets all kinds of attention, some good and some bad.  The bad comes from a scared face named Carl who claims to know Tom, and his accusations paint Tom to be anything but mild mannered.  The question then arises; does anyone really know who Tom is?As I mentioned, the film opens and closes flawlessly.  The open and close remind me much of Anderson's '07 masterpiece `There Will Be Blood', just in reverse.  Here, the film opens with a sadistic and brutal act of violence and closes with a quiet and defining calm, and much like with `There Will Be Blood', the brutality carries with it a strange calm, while the quiet sequence offers the audience a dread and almost haunting presence.  To say that Cronenberg doesn't completely own this film would be a lie.  My issues with the film do not have anything to do with the open or the close, but with the interior.For me the biggest complaint I have is that the film is not as resounding or as memorable as some make it out to be.  I remember feeling a vague feeling of blandness as I was watching the film the first time, and while it has redeemed itself in some degrees upon recent viewings, the fact still remains that as a film it just doesn't hit as hard as it could.  I love Cronenberg's ability to layer this film with a haunting atmosphere, but that creepy air is really all we are left with when the credits start to roll.  There are also, in my opinion, some odd plot points that don't mesh well with the film and wind up feelings rather awkward.  The side-plot involving Jack, Tom's son, seems like a wasted opportunity to me.  Maybe it was Ashton Holmes' performance, but the whole idea and execution of that point took me out of the film, in a bad way.  I know that it built an important message that the film was trying to get across (about the inheritance of violence), but to me it comes across forced and out of place.I also found William Hurt's hamming it up to be more of a distraction than anything else (and the big reveal feels like a letdown to me).  That ending felt like it was a generic effort to express violence.  I think that is why I appreciated `Cache' so much, and find it to be so much more expressive and poignant, for it found a way to make the travesty of violence accessible and relatable (and all the more shocking and haunting because of it).I could just tell that this film was `trying'.I know it sounds like I'm ripping this apart, and I don't mean to.  There is a lot to really enjoy and or gain from this film too.  I actually found that when the film was concentrating on the relationship between Tom and his wife Edie, it was very powerful and poignant.  In that frame it shifts into a very complex examination of marriage and the tiny seeds of doubt and or concern that can eat at the fibers of that relationship.  I also found that the violence Cronenberg inserts into that marital arrangement (the love making on the stairs for one) were the best examples of violence making an impact in the way Cronenberg desired it to.  Those scenes, for me, say far more about that ambiguity of violence and the instinctual and almost sensual idea of violence than anything else within this film.A lot of people I know rave Mortensen's performance here, stating that he gave one of the best turns of the decade.  I actually found his Oscar nomination turn in `Eastern Promises' to be far better.  For me, Mortensen comes across almost too somber, too controlled, to the point where his character reveal makes little sense.  He handles some of his scenes with a great deal of effective emotional transcendence, but for the most part I found him teetering on bland.  Instead, it was Ed Harris and Maria Bello who completely stole this film for me.  Harris is not an actor I am very fond of.  I often find him to be, well, boring.  Here he really sunk his teeth into the intensity of his character's sinister edge, without every falling into that hammy caricature that Hurt gave us (Oscar nominated the wrong supporting player here).  Bello is a picture of brilliance here.  Her natural gut reaction to her surroundings and the unraveling of her marriage is flawless.  I love the hospital scene especially; the panicked reaction she gives, the vomiting that comes so instinctually and so suddenly.  She really understood how to develop this character, giving her a truly layered and realistic identity.In the end I find that `A History of Violence' is a good film.  I'm giving it a B-.  It definitely has something to offer, and Cronenberg's direction is so inspired and so layered that one has to stare in awe of how well he weaved this films inner dread (the film carries an air of anxiety even when it isn't really progressing).  I just don't think this film is as effective in its efforts as so many critics and fans have claimed it to be.

reviewText: Reading the well-expressed reviews here is almost as good an experience as watching the movie itself.  I saw the plethora of one-star reviews and thought "oh, these are people who don't know Cronenberg and are turned off by the violence."  To the contrary, most of them are Cronenberg fans who feel like he screwed this one up.  There's some very good criticism about the flatness of the dialog (Viggo Mortensen's Tom Stall is indeed fairly monosyllabic), the gratuitous nudity (I agree with that - the point where that occurred was fairly odd) and, in general, a healthy skepticism about whatever type of 'message' the four- and five-star reviewers see in this work.That aside, I liked - did not love - the film.  Honestly, we watched it as a trial run for the upcoming and very intriguing 'Eastern Promises,' which again features Cronenberg directing Mortensen.  We figured if we could stomach 'Violence,' we'll pay the $9.75 to catch 'Promises' on the big screen.I was happy to see that Maria Bello got a Golden Globe nomination + scooped up some Critic Circle awards.  That's justly deserved.  She's beautiful and spectacular here - she's got to sell the audience on the revulsion she feels when her husband turns out to be not who she thought.  And, wow, does she make that work.  She's the movie's standout.  William Hurt got an Oscar nomination, but he's got no more than an extended cameo, tinged with some over-the-top hamminess.
summary: Bello shines, but reading the review of this movie is almost as good as the film

reviewText: First off I'd like to say this movie has little to do with previous Cronenberg's pictures. If you are a die-hard fan of Cronenberg, probably you will be disappointed. But if you try to watch this flick open-minded you'll like it for sure. The first twenty minutes show the idyll of a happy rural family's life. Parents and their two children are joyful, everybody loves each other, nobody yells like it usually happens in families... Everything seems so perfect and unnatural that you even feel the urge to throw up watching this. But then everything changes as Tom (Mortensen) kills two goons who try to rob his cafe. Later Tom appears on TV spoken as of a local hero. Soon he's visited by some don't-mess-with-us kind of guys who think he's a former gangster who once disappeared and have been hiding from them ever since. Who is Tom indeed? We see him as a loving and caring husband and father, perhaps an ideal one for every woman and child. On the other hand, when we see him kill, there's no doubts left that ordinary man is not capable of what Tom just did. Viggo Mortensen showed brilliantly the two sides of his character, I will not be exaggerating saying it's his best work to date.Don't let the title mislead you. It's not history in its general meaning as I first thought when I heard the name. It's history within a man. History of his relationship with violence, which is like a living creature, that can be born in us, can develop and grow up, it can sleep for some time, we may suppress it as well as unleash it. But the point is it exists in every person and we never can finally get rid of it or run away from it.The thing I liked in the film tremendously is that violence here is real violence. Cronenberg doesn't flirt with audience, but shows everything like it is in real life. And real violence is ugly, it doesn't choose whether it's for the right cause or not. Cronenberg's violence is extremely graphic and disturbing, I'm happy he's a man who doesn't care about ratings. And disturbing are not just the violent scenes. If we sum them up they will take only five minutes of the screen-time, I guess. The atmosphere in general is very uneasy, and you'll feel it with every fibre of your skin. And that's what Cronenberg does best - so I may be a little wrong about this picture standing far from his previous works."History of Violence" at first may seem a small film, but it's thoughtfull and thought-provoking and good-sized if you know what I mean. Besides it has an excellent cast: except above-mentioned Mortensen we meet Maria Bello, Ed Harris and William Hurt here. I'm sure you will not be disappointed by this new Cronenberg's tour-de-force.
summary: ONCE A KILLER, ALWAYS A KILLER

reviewText: Hearing about this movie, I had thought it was one of the most most violent movies to come out in a long time, and though there are moments of blood and gore, none of them are particularly long or graphic. For me, at least in this movie's case, this was a plus. It added to the surprise of this movie; it's kind of like driving up a hill at a quick speed, cresting it, and driving down it just as quickly. You get that feeling in your stomach that your organs are rising to the top of the neck, and then falling slowly back down to where they are supposed to be. When the violence happens in this movie, you feel the sudden lurch.As for the story, that wasn't so bad, either, but very vague at times, as if it passed over quite a bit of what was in the graphic novel. And the ending cliffhanger wasn't appreciated, at least by me. It follows Tom Stall, a lucky man who has a small business, a beautiful wife, and two children who rely on him as their father. But when two thugs make their way into town and try robbing his diner, he finds himself thrust into the spotlight as a hero. That's when people begin to show up, people who say they know Tom and his history, and though Tom doesn't seem to have any idea what they are talking about, they continue to bother him. Slowly, as Tom and his family gets harassed, the mysteries behind A History of Violence unravels... This movie follows two sides of a plot, and that is Tom's family and his past life, and the two are so starkly different that they collide and little is left behind. It's that strange dynamic that drives this movie from start to finish.As for the DVD, it contains all the norm you would find on other DVDs nowadays. It has a commentary track with the director, a documentary, three short features about the making of the film and all its publicity, and deleted scenes. But to me, they weren't enough to add or take to away from this film, so I won't comment much on them.Still, I will recommend this movie to anyone who likes emotional stories with some surprising moments, such as Hostage or the classic Psycho. The story may be vague at times, but it's still very easy to understand. And the acting is top-notch, with a lot of big names highlighting this film.
summary: Not-So Violent, Vague Story, but Not Bad

reviewText: Tom Stall (Vigo Mortensen) is a family guy who lives an idilic life with his wife and children, you know, the ideal american family. All seems to go perfect. But the life is always far from being perfect. His life changed the day he met the two delincuents we saw in the initial sequence of the movie. He became an hero to the town when he killed the gansters. He tries to return to his normal life but this seems to be imposible when he is visited by two old friends who claim he is another guy who betrayed them in the past.Cronenberg takes the story and make it personal movie. The Tom/Joey duality is worked magistraly. Humans are anturally violent but we can control this violent thoughts and actions in order to life with other people. Stall has chosen to hide his identity and be another person. But the anger still inside. The incident with the gansters has awaken the other-Tom. He can slap his son in the face and almost rape his own wife (in a magistral erotic scene in the stairs) He want to kill his demons, bury the past, return to normal life. After the visit of his old friends to the house the conflict is even more evident. His wife is distant, his sons don't know what to think and the police suspect about his true identity. Tom is alone again.An unexpected call in the middle of the night is the excuse to leave the house and try to fix his life. The final sequences of the movie shows us a Tom determined to expell Joey from his life. After the chatarsis, Tom is a new man, he throws his gun (the sin), washes in the lake (a paralle with the baptism) and return home. His family will be there, waiting. Return to the normality now seems to be so simple: His daughter put his dish on the table, his son approaches him the food and his wife... well, we will never know. To me, this is one of the best scenes in movies and has a lot of meanings. Redemption of man will take place in his house. A simple gesture can fix his life and bring him back to normality.The violence presented in the film is necesary, it has a meaning. Yes, it's a hard movie if you're not accustomed to see the life as it is. There is no happy endings here, all is implicit and you have to think about it and enjoy the movie as it is, an approach to the complex human being.
summary: Life is far from being perfect.

reviewText: What can I say about David Cronenberg's latest work that hasn't already been said by film critics everywhere? My answer to that has to be: not much. A History of Violence will remind people that David Cronenberg is one of the more underappreciated film directors of the last 30 years and also one of its master craftsmen. Using a loose-adaptation (yet echoing some of the book's themes) of the John Wagner and Vince Locke graphic novel of the same name, Cronenberg creates a multi-layered film dissertation about the nature of violence. I will pause for a moment and say that the film also delivers as a taut, gripping, thriller that looks to ape the action-films of blockbusters past, but Cronenberg's skill as a director manages to keep the film above it's B-movie aspirations.More well-known as the creator of eccentric and unusual fare with legions of fans and admirers in the horror community, David Cronenberg may have his most mainstream and accessible film to date since his remake of The Fly. In A History of Violence Cronenberg's existentialism continues to show as he probes through the dark and shadowy corners of human behavior and instinct. He posits a question of whether people as a whole --- no matter how saintly, well-balanced, and civilized --- secretly revels in the violence they see around them even as they denounce and feel uncomfortable around it. Some have seen this film as something of a historical commentary of the American history and how the nation itself has been shaped by its acceptance of violence and its many repercussions. I would say that those people are not far off the mark, but to compartmentalize Cronenberg's film to such a narrow focus is not fair to the film. Cronenberg deftly shows the brutality of violence and how its effect can be far-reaching and intimite at the same time.As his past films dealt with the horror of the body politic (Shivers, Crash, The Brood, The Fly) and the nature of reality and existence (Videodrome, Dead Ringers, Naked Lunch, Spider, eXistenZ) Cronenberg continues these themes with this film. Despite the gore and viscera being small in comparison to his past works, History still show the carnage and horror that violent acts can perform on the frail human body. The film also points out that people as a whole deceive themselves of the true world around them in order to hold onto the ideal and the quaint. This is really put forward by the dynamic interaction between the character of Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) and his wife Edie (Maria Bello) from beginning to end. It is a testament to the excellent performances by both these actors that the audience truly believe and care for their characters on-screen. I'll have to say that this is Viggo Mortensen and Maria Bello's best work to date and it would be criminal of the industry not to reward them in some way come awards season. The chemistry between these two performers is genuine, searing and very intimate. The very last can be seen in graphic detail in the two scenes of sex between the characters. One in the beginning is naughtily playful and shows how much in love the two characters still are and the second being more brutal and primal as the hidden layers of each character is slowly peeled away to show whats been hidden all along.For an art-film masquerading as an action-thriller, A History of Violence is very deliberate in setting up each violent outburst. There's an underlying dread that permeates through each set-up. We know that something is about to happen, but its not rushed and gradually builds-up until something has to break. The violence is not your stereotypical action sequence that looks staged, but comes and goes quickly with the brutality and lethality of reality. In fact, the violence has the feel of being very intimate. Everything is up close and personal. Nothing is done from a distance and each strike and violent act painful to see, yet in all instances each scene also gets a rousing response from the audience. This is particularly evident in a scene concerning Tom Stall's teenage son dealing with a particular high school bully in brutal fashion. Everyone in this film is touched by violence in some way or another. From the very young to the very old. The final scene at the dinner table is both haunting and familiar. With all that has been going on through Tom's life and that of his family there's a sense of acceptance of the violent genie that was unleashed in the beginning and one of "life must go on" mentality.I must say that A History of Violence has to be one of the best films I've seen since I've been watching them. For a film that is really just a revenge-thriller similar to Chan-wook Park's Oldboy, Cronenberg's latest has so many layers and depth to it that anyone who sees it are going to be tempted to talk about its themes and subtext lon after they've left the theater. Where Oldboy is like a hard kick in the gut then a devastation stomp on the neck, A History of Violence is more insidious, intimate and subversive --- like a sharp papercut just beneath the fingernail that lingers and tells one that its going to be there for awhile and there to stay. Some may end up not liking the film due to its deliberate nature or not having enough people dying in elaborately staged action sequences, but that will only show exactly what Cronenberg has been trying to show. That people nowadays have been so inured and desensitized by violence that we've come to accept it as entertainment and actually have come to yearn and need it like a drug-addict looking for their next hit. One of the best films of 2005, if not one of the best in the past decade.

reviewText: Viewed: 6/08Rate: 36/08: A History of Violence isn't as good as compared to Eastern Promises. The former seems to be unrefined, poorly handled, and ludicrous while the latter is much better done, sharper, and more focused. While the story behind A History of Violence is reasonably good, the acting is quite unconvincing. Ed Harris probably stole the film because he helped to jump-start the momentum since most of A History of Violence is very slow, especially in the first fifteen minutes. Viggo Mortensen's acting looks improved, but he is simply not believable as Crazy Joey. Maria Bello seems to think that getting naked in full exposure is acting and playing the anguished wife is dramatic. There is nothing I see of her that meets the requirement of her character, but she could have easily replaced Sharon Stone in Casino. Ashton Holmes, who plays the teenage son, looks like that he doesn't belong in Stall's family, and Heidi Hayes, who plays the daughter, is the least developed character of the film. William Hurt is overrated for his performance (hell, how many scenes was he in anyway? For how long?); obviously, he did better work during the 80's. Since his remake of The Fly, David Cronenberg has never been the same again. The more recent his movie is, the less David Cronenberg it feels. The same thing goes for A History of Violence; it's just not the same anymore. What made him the best director is the creativity he put in the older psychological horror pictures. A History of Violence actually feels a lot like a remake of Videodrome. Viggo Mortensen is Debbie Harry, and Maria Bello is James Woods. The latter is a newbie while the former is the old-timer; all there to do is create a catalyst and establish a bridge to connect both polarizing opposites. The angry sex scene on stairs is pointless. The tension between Tom Stall and his wife is simply not believable. Do you want me to believe that Tom Stall ran from his town to his house that is probably ten miles away while wearing long sleeves, long pants, stabbed foot, and wrong shoes? And he comes home not really all that sweaty? Believe me, I've run a good deal of my time, and something like that is not remotely possible for a man who is totally out of shape by the looks of his body. There is plenty of violence onscreen, but so? The high school bullying scenes are so 80's. All in all, A History of Violence is A History of Bad Movies.

reviewText: I have always been known to love a good action/thriller flick. And this didn't let me down. It was everything an action/thriller is meant to be. The narrative is a sprint. David Cronenberg just straps you in and takes you for a spin through the beautiful roads of a small town in Indiana. There are no pit stops or rest areas. This is not a marathon but a sprint.One of the most beautiful aspects of this movie, is the characterization of the 'bad guys'. Ed Harris and William Hurt play these with an exquisite blend of coldness and creepiness, that has been very rarely been seen on film. Also the shorter length of the movie (96 min) was a refreshing change.Tom Stall is your ideal family man. Great father, great husband and a diner owner who is loved by the people of this small town. The family portrait is disturbed one day when two criminals on a murder spree turn up at Tom Stall's diner. He reacts with alacrity to save his female worker and send these criminals to their fate. With that comes the swarm of TV cameras. And that brings some visitors from out of town. What follows is a peek into Tom Stall's past.Is he the family man that his wife, kids, community and us believe him to be?Warning: It has some serious graphic violence. Not over drawn out gore but authentic depictions of violence which may make you squirm.I should also mention that this movie contains one of the most intense sex scenes seen on film in the recent past. As with all the best scenes of this nature, it is not about the nudity but about the two people involved in it.

reviewText: If, like a previous reviewer here, expect A History of Violence to be a typical Hollywood mindless shoot-em-up, you're going to be disappointed. But you might just be the audience that would get the most out of the film anyway.David Cronenberg's thriller is violent, but more important than the fight sequences are their consequences for Tom Stall and the characters, each of whom changes over the course of the film as a result of being part of it, or merely witnessing it.The question of identity, both the one a person is born to and the one they create for themselves as an adult, is the other central theme, specifically the question of which is real. When faced with the revelation that she may not know the whole truth of who her husband is, Edie Stall has to figure out if she still loves her husband and how she feels about that realization.The film does not wrap things up into a tidy little bow: Unlike most movies, the violence done in the film does not end in a satisfying way and we know that the consequences of what happened will continue, for all of the characters, for the rest of their lives.A strongly recommended adult (in the true sense of the word) film.
summary: "Ask him, Edie, how come he's so good at killing people."

reviewText: The opening minutes of David Cronenberg's film are horrifying, even though the viewer actually sees very little happen onscreen. Two dangerous looking men exit their hotel room, get into their vintage convertible and then creep in it very, very slowly toward the hotel's main office. One of them gets out of the car, goes inside to settle the account, and we wait with the driver outside the office as he gets anxious and a little panicked. Because we've seen the title and because we know what kind of movie to expect from Cronenberg, the whole scene carries an undercurrent of dread. We just wait for the moment of shock, the moment of blood, and Cronenberg relishes in the wait. The opening scene is indicative of the entire film. It builds up long moments of calm so well that viewers are on edge, waiting for the explosion. Everything about main character Tom Stall's life, even his family name, seems to suggest inertia and peace. He has a cozy, happy family. He runs a friendly hometown diner. When a moment of violence interrupts all that, though, Stall's entire history comes into doubt, and the film takes shape as a really bloody, adult drama. Even though the film has thrills, it's about the secret of Tom Stall and how his family comes to cope with that. Though the setting is intentionally idyllic, Viggo Mortensen and Maria Bello invest their scenes of marriage with depth and meaning, showing how a real couple might cope with such startling change. The film, actually based on a graphic novel, also features magnificent turns from Ed Harris and William Hurt as colorful villains.
summary: Cronenberg directs a magnificent, creepy drama.

reviewText: I've been a sometime Cronenberg fan for a long time, since the 70s, but I thought this was the worst kind of trash.  Admittedly over time the films I one time thought were good -- like The Fly, Naked Lunch, Dead Ringers -- have gotten worse and worse until they are now unwatchable.  I still enjoy the really early films, but I now agree with Robin Wood that his stuff is contemptible and purposefully ugly.  Still, this has gotten good reviews, so I plunked down my money and sat in the theater and -- couldn't believe how bad it was.  From the ridiculously ugly opening sequence with the evil bad guys killing a child to the stupid "you must be mistaken" dialogue with Ed Harris to the high school kid suddenly turning into Superman, this was atrociously acted, horribly written, and meanspirited garbage for film buffs.  I swear, I never want to see another movie based on a comic book (graphic novel? give me a break).  This has a comic book mentality, which I guess is supposed to cover all the over the top lapses in intelligence that this film wallows in.  If it's a comic book, why does the violence have to be so bloody and graphic?  David Cronenberg has no respect at all for his audience.  He proudly proclaims he has no responsibility to the audience, but here he proves he has no respect.  This is the last Cronenberg film I will ever see in a theater and I hope his career ends soon.
summary: God how I hated this movie

reviewText: I was wondering why most people hate it (both here and on online boards) and saw that those people in a mayor proportion were under 20, My first question is: What are people under 20 watching an R film?Myself a person who has been a victim of violence in the past  couldn't agree no more with this film because it doesn't try to hide the true nature of violence like most action packed film does. The direction is awesome because it only focus on 3 things1) Do People deserve a second chance?2) The true nature of violence (Disgusting, Terrible and Horrible)3) Is violence the only solution to a limit situation?The movie catchs your atention since the beginning and do not let go until the end of it. Showing a "perfect" life ruined by violence and putting the main character in a limit situationI don't know if this one is anti-american (as haters claim) I personally don't think so but I believe this one is anti-violence but the only way to make people to walk away from violence is showing it as it is (and this is where so many people disagree).Finally I will say History of Violence has one of the strongest supporting peformances of all the time by the 3 supporting actors.If you are 20 or above don't miss this expierence because "You won't know what hit you"

reviewText: Viggo Mortensen (A Perfect Murder, Lord Of The Rings 1-3) plays Tom Stall, a family man in a small town. Tom and his lovely wife (Maria Bello) live a peaceful, ordinary life raising their kids. All is well until a pair of cold-blooded killers decide to rob the diner where Tom works. In the chaos, Tom displays incredible fighting skills, taking out both men w/ quick, lethal force. Tom becomes a media hero, but just wants the whole incident to be forgotten. A few days later, a trio of well-dressed thugs arrive in town, lead by a very sinister Ed Harris. What do these guys want? What secret is Tom hiding? A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE is a story of betrayal, lies, and murder. It's also the tale of a man's attempt to escape his past by becoming someone new, someone better. Mortensen is his usual calm / cool self, dispatching bad-guys like human dominoes. The physical, visceral stuff is easy for his character. Living a normal life is what becomes far more difficult. After all, what does murder and mayhem have in common w/ being a loving husband and father? As for the "shocking" scene on the stairs, I found it to be a perfect way to show the conflict between love and revulsion that Tom's wife must face. Unsettling, yet confusingly erotic. Bello shows great frustration and anger mixed w/ longing and release. A unique sequence to say the least! Buy immediately...

reviewText: Someone who just had to tell me what other movie the trailer reminded him of ruined for me the first fifteen minutes of History of Violence. Unfortunately, the distributors wish the fate for you. The trailers for the DVD reveled the same spoiler as did my friend and as does the synopsis the DVD packaging. I can't image Cronenberg is a party to this but whether he is or not, I won't be. There will be no spoilers in this review, unlike many others.So, I won't be talking about the plot but rather talk about this in terms of its director, the brilliant David Cronenberg. Cronenberg makes several genres of films, horror; Rabid, Scanners, The Dead Zone, Shivers, etc., metaphysical reality checks; Naked Lunch, The Brood, eXitenZ, Videodrome and the genre that The History of Violence fall into, the psychology of violence. His other efforts in this area are Crash, Spider, Dead Ringers to name a few but History of Violence is the best so far though Spider is my personal favorite.History of Violence is, as the title implies, violent as all get out, so be forewarned. It is emotionally charged, highly sexual and deals with family. Though it has humor to help you digest but at the same time it's a huge, sharp punch in the stomach. It's also flawlessly edited to the perfect length. It's short but epic.Casting, acting, scripting, screenplay, cinematography and direction are all superb. Special mention should be given for Ed Harris' performance and the choice of a slowly cruising black Chrysler 300 to epitomize evil.If you like Cronenberg (maybe you didn't know he made The Dead Zone or Scanners) or if violent, in-your-face movies is your bag or if you're a big Viggio Mortensen fan I would say this is a must-see. It is on any level a great movie by a great director.

reviewText: This is a fairly engaging film, it kept me interested from beginning to end.  For me it didn't live up to all the buzz and hype surrounding it but it was entertaining nonetheless.  Cronenberg eschews the typical horror genre that he's known for and rather opts for telling a pretty straight forward story.  However, in typical Cronenberg fashion we still get some gory violent scenes and of course his obligatory gratuitous sex scenes.  You'll still enjoy this if you're a fan of Cronenberg.  If you're new to him beware, this is not indicative of Cronenberg's oeuvre.

reviewText: I am pretty unfamiliar with David Cronenberg's work, so I can't review it in the light of his past efforts.  However, A History of Violence I can wholeheartedly recommend, just on its own merits.  The most striking thing in the film is the way normal, boring life is contrasted with shattering violence.  There isn't a large amount of violence in the film, but when it is there, it is very graphic, enough that it shocks you when someone is killed (something most movies are not able to do).  The plot is fairly straight-forward and "simple".  But there are subtle meanings and nuances that give the movie more of a punch.  However, do not expect them to be easy to figure out or in your face obvious.  Most of the people in the theatre with me did not seem to like the film, because it isn't a typical Hollywood movie.  It's much better than that.  It's an interesting, well-written, wonderfully acted film that raises questions about violence in our society that it cannot answer, that no movie could answer.  Overall, I highly recommend it.

reviewText: Anybody who seriously believes the all-important "wow" factor has gone missing from certain movies lately can now finally end their drawn-out disputes. "A History of Violence," put mildly, blew me clear out of my chair! David Cronenberg has totally redefined the action genre and shaped it into something all his own.He casts Viggo Mortensen as Tom Stall, a quiet family man and small-town diner owner who quickly becomes a reluctant hero after decisively silencing two would-be thieves. This story soon draws the heated attention of mobster Carl Fogarty who, along with his loyal followers, seems to feel that Tom may somehow be linked to their organization's shady past. As these men begin to methodically encircle Tom's frightened family, tensions rise and personal suspicions skyrocket. Is Tom Stall really the loving, dedicated husband and father he so adamantly professes? Or has his forgotten and abandoned prior life come back to haunt him in ways he could never possibly imagine?Discovering the answers to those two questions are what ultimately makes experiencing this barn-burner of a motion picture so much unapologetic fun! I cannot truthfully remember the last time a movie like this generated so much adrenaline-fueled excitement. The principal performers, between Mortensen, the wonderful Ed Harris, and William Hurt, are all standouts. But the pacing is absolutely phenomenal. This is a movie that very literally flies off the screen. Cronenberg throws so much at you throughout the entire film's 96-minute running time, and yet you're still left hungering for more. The violence is straight-ahead and in-your-face. It more than earns its coveted "R" rating.As far as the DVD, itself....you couldn't ask for a better package. The "Acts of Violence" documentary, along with three other featurettes, does an exceptional job at breaking down the deeply-layered particulars of the film. And you even get to hear Cronenberg, himself, interject his own thoughts as they relate to the film's storied production.This is an overall great movie and one you're not likely to forget anytime soon. I know I certainly won't!

reviewText: I actually like Viggo Mortenson, and Ed Harris is without a doubt one of my favorite actors of all time, however, to borrow from another review I read, this movie is just flat. Let me add shallow, jumbled and boring. It is hard, in my case it was impossible, to get involved or to connect with this movie. I'm sorry, but this movie is simply bad. I give it 2 stars because it had Ed Harris in it.  Some of the reviews here on Amazon.com hyping this movie, which seem like they were written by the studio, are pretty far off base in my opinion. I wonder if they watched the same movie I did.I had very high hopes for this movie, but the fact is this movie was simply a big letdown. I have read some who say Cronenberg offends some people, or that this movie is similar to Pulp Fiction and if you don't like that type of movie you will not like this movie either, etc... the fact is, however, I was so bored I would have welcomed the opportunity to be offended.The parts of the movie that feature Ed Harris are the only parts worth watching, but unfortunately, they do not save the movie. The sex and violence scenes are certainly graphic, but I am not sure what they are supposed to accomplish or how they help the movie. Once they are over, you just scratch your head and ask yourself, "What was that all about?", and that is probably the same question you will ask yourself about the whole movie.2 stars because of Ed Harris, otherwise, a zero.

reviewText: There is a lot to this movie.  It puts forward the question of who we really are.  Tom, his son and his wife, all have to face this issue.When life's situations present changes to us, can we cope?  Do we adapt to new situations in a positive and logical manner or do we revert back to previous behavior, which may be very destructive.This movie addresses earthshaking events in the life of a seemingly normal family in rural Indiana.  Tom has a confrontation with gangsters, his son has a confrontation with the school bully, and his wife has to determine how to cope with overnight changes in those she loves.After a while the movie appears predictable, and some of the action is a bit over the top, not quite credible.  But the reaction of the family to the changes they are faced with begs the question . . what would I do, what would those around me do, and how would we all cope in the next week, the next month, the next year.

reviewText: Tom Stall is just an ordinary man.  But then one day, two armed thugs break into his small business and try to rob it.  Heroically, Tom Guns them both down, an act which gets him large scale media attention.And that's where the trouble starts.  A man claiming to know Tom from his philladelphia days looks him up after seeing him on TV.  As the film progresses, it becomes obvious that this semmingly mild- mannered, model citizen once once a brutal killer for the mob.  The revelation triggers a caucophony of emotions from his wife and the audience.  We want to believe that Tom Stall is really who he says he is- that Joey, the evil side that Tom left behind, has taken over.Throughout the film Tom has to defend his family from the villains of his past.  The ending shot is worth viewing over and over and will probably studied by film students for years to come.  Its very sad, yet still hopeful somehow.
summary: The Most Powerful Ending of Any Film Of Seen

reviewText: So much has been written about this film and the title. For most, the movie is about the way violence is encoded in our lives and how we all have an underlying current running through us. I think the movie is really the study of the relationship between the two main characters--Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) and Edie (Maria Bello).These two actors are amazing the film, especially Bello, who deserves to become a household name. Their intereactions are always spot on as they drive the plot. The sideways glance, the tense look, the loving smile: every part means something.These two characters are madly in love after seventeen or such years of marriage, and we see it through different ways. The first half of the movie is there to set up their relationship and the love they feel. But then everything is turned upside down, and we realize that these two people who have shared everything and love one another dearly really know nothing about what lies beneath. It's as if they have only shared a part of themselves.It's this interaction and realization that makes the film so great. The plot almost seems beside the point; it's merely there to make use see the characters.I give the film four stars instead of five because of some of the scenes were out of place, almost as if Cronenberg couldn't decide what kind of film to make. William Hurt is good at the end, for instance, but his character didn't fit. Watch the movie for the main characters' interactions and go along with the rest.

reviewText: A History of Violence is one of the worst movies of 2005. This is fitting because its director, David Cronenberg, is the single most overrated filmmaker of our times. Whenever an overrated filmmmaker is given a large budget to make a flick, train wrecks like A History of Violence are the logical result.This movie starts with peaceful scenes of a happy family that Cronenberg generally uses to introduce the future victims of the flick's violence to the audience. Of course, in a Cronenberg movie, these scenes are interspersed with other scenes of a nice, calm series of murders in which crooks on the lam kill folks at a motel while exhibiting zero emotion. Of course, the killers and the happy family are obviously on a collision course. If this sequence of scenes were not in this movie, then this would not be a David Cronenberg flick. Cronenberg is basically a hack aka Hollywood creature of habit who always has to make his movies the more or less same exact way.Viggo Mortensen stars as Tom Stall, a restauranteur in a small Indiana town. He is not a native of the town, nor has he been accepted as a fellow townsman by many of the inhabitants. Tom and his family, nevertheless, have managed to have a fairly normal lifestyle. Of course, the bad guys show up and in a predictable bloodbath, Tom vanquishes the evil duo. Tom becomes a local celebrity, but he is traumatized by the whole affair and desperately wishes that it never happened.At this point, A History of Violence was at a crossroads with one path going down the formulaic way of the quick and the easy and the other path pointing towards what for Cronenberg and most other Hollywood types is new, uncharted territory. Naturally, Cronenberg opted for the way of predictable formulas. Even more violence awaits poor Tom and his family.Predictably, the battle-scarred Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris) walks in with a couple of goons and things heats up. Especially after Fogarty asks Tom's wife Edie (Maria Bello) why her husband is so good at killing people. If you have seen previous Cronenberg productions, all this is quite predictable since you will have seen sequences like this time and time again.The remainder of this movie plays out like a standard David Cronenberg formula trash flick. It even features William Hurt as a mobster, even though he is unintentionally ridiculous in that role. Of course, there is a lot of over the top violence that results in collateral damage wrought on Tom's family. The result is just another stupid movie.
summary: One of the Worst Movies of 2005

reviewText: Upon viewing this at the movie theatre, I thought it was kind of slow. I expected something different. I guess I was looking for ACTION, but it was more of a DRAMA. I guess I was looking for incredible events, but it was more of a STORY.We've been bombarded with such over-the-top junk in hollywood movies, that when we are given something REAL and gifted with deep emotions, we don't know how to deal with it. My initial reaction was disappointment, but then I realized... how awesome the film really was.Two of the finest and most underrated actors in the world give HISTORY OF VIOLENCE life.Viggo Mortensen (the dudes awesome), plays Tom Stall, a normal, small-town Joe, just trying to trudge through life, provide for his family and forget. So when trouble comes to town and finds his resteraunt, he reacts with swift and violent force. Propelling him into the world of newscast hero, a role, he doesn't want. And soon, even more trouble comes to town, as his story begins to play on newscasts in bigger cities.To town comes Carl Fogarty, played by Ed Harris (my favorite actor, and I think the most underrated actor of all time, GIVE THIS MAN AN OSCAR ALREADY!), a bigtime criminal and he isn't in town for a bake sale.Maria Bello also stars as the wife of Tom, Edie Stall, the source of Tom's passion. The thing that he most cherishes and the thing that most forces his emotions to respond. His passion for her is his driving force and... a little tidbit from the filming process... had to use heavy makeup in their SECOND love scene to cover the BRUISES from their FIRST love scene.I'm not gonna give away the movie, but there are some amazing moments in this film, moments that are anti-hollywood, different, REAL, sudden, shocking, intense and UNFORGETTABLE.In my opinion, A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE, is David Cronenberg's finest achievement. A director that is synonymous for giving us such other-worldly, trips into the unreal like THE FLY, eXISTEnZ and NAKED LUNCH, has achieved his best film by giving us something that is very REAL. With real emotions and real passion and real events.What will a man do to perserve his family? To hide his past? To protect the life that he's come to love? You have to see it to know. Oh... and one last thing... a perfect role for William Hurt (an actor that I DON'T LIKE ALL THAT MUCH, but he does do good)... a perfect role for him... YOU'LL SEE.
summary: SLOW SLOW SLOW... but strangely AWESOME
