reviewText: The idea that a movie with graphic depictions of murder could also be deep and incredibly interesting didn't cross my mind until I saw "A History of Violence." I understand now why David Cronenberg chose to direct it; his films are nothing if not bizarre and over the top, but they also have an underlying complexity that makes them fascinating to watch. Maybe that's because he chooses stories that focus primarily on the dark recesses of the human mind and the realities they create for the individual. In this sense, "A History of Violence" may be one of his darkest films yet, not only because it's disturbingly plausible, but also because it exposes the idea that a happy family life isn't necessarily without its secrets.This movie--based on the graphic novel by John Wagner and Vince Locke--doesn't attempt to reveal violence so much as it proves that it's always existed. And Cronenberg is certainly not afraid to show it in all its quick, brutal, and unfeeling splendor. But I'm using the word "splendor" loosely here: despite the fact that violence is quite prominent, this isn't a movie that glorifies it at all. It's simply presented to us in moments of raw imagery, such as in the opening scene when two criminals rob an out-of-the-way motel. We don't see them actually kill (except for one), but we do see the aftermath. You can tell from that scene that it wasn't a case of showing gore just for the sake of being gory. It was dark, it was unnerving, and it was real.And it gets even more real when the setting shifts to a rural, close knit Indiana town. While the filmmakers chose not to delve too deep into the lives of the townsfolk, it's still quite apparent that this is one of those places where everyone knows everyone else's business (something we've seen before in plenty of other movies). That aspect made the film's underlying message more unsettling: however long you may have known your neighbor, friend, or spouse, you never completely know who he or she really is. This is especially true for Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen), who gains sudden notoriety when he saves his diner from being robbed by two desperate criminals. We don't initially analyze how out of place his actions seem because we feel the same way the townsfolk do: we're praising him for his bravery.But then reality starts to sink in. Tom is a mild mannered man living the typical middle class American life, complete with his wife, Edie (Maria Bello), his teenage son, Jack (Ashton Holmes), and his young daughter, Sarah (Heidi Hayes). Why would someone like that know how to kill someone, even in self-defense? This is a question posed by Carl Fogerty (Ed Harris), a mysterious and sinister figure who suddenly arrives with an equally mysterious and sinister group of men. They claim that "Tom" is actually a man named Joey Cusack who used to live in Philadelphia. Apparently, he tried to kill Fogerty many years ago. While the truth of that has yet to be revealed, there is evidence of an assault in the form of Fogerty's half blind eye, a grotesquely cloudy mass surrounded by scar tissue (supposedly the weapon of choice was barbed wire).From here on out, it becomes a quest for the truth. Is this just a case of mistaken identity, or is Tom not everything he appears to be? It eventually becomes crucial for an explanation to come forth, as things are starting to unravel. Fogerty won't leave Tom or his family alone, continuously arriving in a new yet menacing shiny black car. What's worse is they resort to threatening Jack, who is having problems of his own in school (there were some incidents with an unjustly hostile bully). Edie starts having doubts about Tom, the man she thought she knew, the man she's loved for many years. All the secrets surrounding her husband's life have turned everyone's lives upside down, and she's clearly struggling to cope with the situation. On top of all that, Tom is eventually forced to meet a ruthless kingpin (William Hurt in his Academy Award nominated cameo) who clearly has an agenda. That scene in particular has Cronenberg effectively showing how human beings react when thrust into extraordinary situations; who would know how to handle such uncertainty? The truth is that no one really knows how to, and that remains one of the film's greatest strengths.The film's ending is a testament to Cronenberg's ability to dissect and observe behaviors and emotions, and he does it with stunning insight. I obviously won't describe the scene, but I will say that it's an interesting unfolding of little moments. It's so interesting that you can't quite put your finger on why it works. It's not really an enlightening scene, but it is an incredibly appropriate one, and it leaves it up to the viewer's imagination as to how future events will unfold for the characters. In other words, it's not one of those endings that tie everything up in a neat little package. We've seen many endings like that, and generally they work. Still, it's refreshing to see a movie that leaves some mystery behind for us to savor, as if to say that sometimes, the answers we're looking for will not be given to us.That's why I think David Cronenberg was the perfect director for "A History of Violence." Not only has he been willing to use unconventional storytelling methods, he's also unafraid to tackle subject matter that some may find disturbing. He's certainly never been shy about portrayals of sexuality, which in this case are heavy handed and indelicate (I'm surprised that a couple of very distinct shots made it into an R rated film). Ultimately, the notion of buried truths in the midst of a family life made this a worthwhile experience. It raises important questions and shakes the very foundation of trust. I think we occasionally need to see films like this, if not to entertain us, then to reaffirm that even those we love have strengths and weaknesses.

reviewText: Viggo Mortensen plays a diner owner in a small town in middle America. He has a loving wife and two children. A good man living the American dream. One evening two criminals enter the diner to rob it and assault the waitress. Mortensen's mild mannered Tom Stall suddenly leaps into action, knocking one of the men out, grabbing his gun and eventually shooting both of them. Tom becomes a hero and attracts unwanted attention from the national media. Soon a man from the Philadelphia mob shows up claiming Tom is actually Joey, an ex-mobster from the old neighborhood. The rest of the movie explores the question, is Tom Tom or really Joey?A History of Violence is interesting but moves a little too slowly for my taste. It also doesn't delve deeply enough into the mind of a man with a past he's trying to forget. It's all glossed over with no real exploration of his life. There is also a subplot with his teenage son, trying to show that his son may have inherited his father's violent tendencies. However, it all seemed contrived to me and didn't work at all. I didn't believe anything that happened with the son and it all felt tacked on.The performances are good, but the script needed work. We never got any reasons for why Tom/Joey was the man he was growing up or why he decided to change. The violent scenes were well staged and believable but there wasn't anything real connecting them.

reviewText: Before I get to the meat and potatoes of my review, let me make one thing perfectly clear.  I wrote a review for the graphic novel version of _A History of Violence_ last year, and I still find myself pleasantly surprised by all the positive feedback generated by that one review.  It may seem that since I gave the graphic novel a 5-star rating and the film a 4-star that I am picking apart the film for not living up to the graphic novel.  Not quite.  Granted, some comparisons are inevitible.  For instance, the names, places, and even some plot twists have been changed.  Adding to that, the graphic novel is FAR MORE violent than the film adaptation.  But whether you are talking about the film or graphic novel, it's the theme that's important here.  Both operate on the idea that one's actions will always produce consequences that will occur even if the initial actions have long been forgotten.  And when those initial actions are violent, violent consequences are to be expected.  So to make a long story short, I'm going to do the unthinkable.  I'm going to fly in the face of all those fanboys who expect 110% loyalty to the source material by judging the film solely on its own merits.I'm not going to elaborate too much about the plot since so many others before me already did that job, and I did it myself writing the review for the graphic novel - which to my knowledge is still a Spotlight Review for all to see.  At the expense of sounding redundant, we know that Viggo Mortensen (proving there is life after Aragorn) plays Tom Stall, a small town Indiana diner owner turned media sensation who is forced to kill two homicidal robbers who get just a little too familiar with his diner.  And we know that Ed Harris plays Carl Fogarty, a Philadelphia mobster who knows a lot more about Tom than Tom wants us to.  And we further know that Maria Bello plays Tom's wife, who is initially supportive of her husband but understandably cracks under the strain of discovering her marriage, and basically her whole life after she met him, is built up on lies.  There's not much more I can say other than these three do a fine job with these characters.Regarding the film itself, while I did say that I was not going to attack it for not being fully loyal to the graphic novel, I still have to throw in a comparison.  One thing the film actually surpasses the graphic novel in is dealing with the human equation.  We see the strain that Tom's deceit brings upon his family.  We see how his wife finds she can longer trust the man she married.  We see how Tom's son, who is strongly admonished for viciously beating up a bully, views him as a hypocrite.  And then we see the small daughter, who once lived a carefree childhood existence, suddenly thrust into a new arena of distrust and deceit within her family that no child should ever have to see.  These ideas weren't touched upon that much in the graphic novel.So now I'm going to answer the nagging question as to why I gave this film four stars.  For one thing, I did not like the sex scenes.  It is not based on moralism.  I just found the sex scenes overlong and boring.  The typical Spike-TV watching, Maxim-reading male often fast-forwards a film to get the sex scene(s).  Here, I fast-forwarded through them.  My second reason was William Hurt, an actor who is capable of great performances.  But not here.  He is hammier in _AHoV_ than the meat department at Kroger.  He must have been hanging around William Shatner or something.But other than these two flaws, I still recommend this movie.  I hate to keep harping on it, but it is one those rare films that at least stays consistent with, and sometimes even greatly improves upon, the spirit of its source material.  We see too much of how Hollywood Big Money takes a good idea made up by a writer and completely botches it up.  Here they left the central idea alone.  Why can't this happen more often?

reviewText: David Cronenberg always does films that tend to look at human nature in a different way: sexuality in Crash and changes in personality in the Fly. With this film, he gets into what makes people violent and how far it can go, particularly when it comes to saving family members and loved ones. It's a nice exploration but as a film it really left me cold, with highlights being 2 sex scenes and a couple shots of big violence.Tom Stall is a family man with 2 kids leaving in a small town. He runs a local diner which one night attracts some criminal attention, which Tom ends up disposing of rather cleanly. It attracts some more attention, this time from local news and including a strange guy with an even stranger eye and tells him that Tom had a much different life than he does now.While David Lynch likes to make really weird surrealist films, David Cronenberg likes to do films that take a look at transformation and ways people react to things. These 2 will always make interesting movies but I kind of lean towards Cronenberg ones, even though I don't really watch many of them. To me it's a misstep though as the film after it ended didn't really last with me on any level.Casting is quite solid across the board, including William Hurt, who finally puts in some menace into his "woke up too early" voice. Viggo is always great although he does have this tendency to mumble sometimes and Maria Bello is always good. Ed Harris is effective as a villain, with a very uneasy feeling you get whenever he's around.As for the violence in the film, it's not incredibly violent. There's a couple of shots that are cringe-inducing such as what happens when you punch someone in the nose a bit too much but it's actually not as violent as you would think. The 2 sex scenes are not that graphic but it's definately not candlelight and blowing curtains, you don't really see much during them but using your imagination they'll get graphic.After the film was over I remember thinking "what was the point of this one?". Unlike the Fly which was entertaining or Crash which was incredibly erotic in the strangest sense, this doesn't have any kick to it. It's worth a rental but I wouldn't buy it unless it was a gift from someone.
summary: Not exactly a big fan of it

reviewText: A History of Violence stars Viggo Mortensen, Maria Bello, Ed Harris, William Hurt & is a David Cronenberg film. That is reason enough to see it.The storyline of this mob movie is definitely one that is hard to develop but they do what they can. There are all kinds of moral dilemmas in this show but they are generally exposed & then left unsettled or even ignored. That lowers the quality of the story. As a mob movie though, it is in unusual territory so I'll make allowances for that & get to what is right.Is there hard core violence? checkIs it fast & brutal? checkIs the home life entangled? checkAre the bad guys really bad? checkIs the good guy not very good? checkIs the wife put on the hot seat? checkHow about the kids? Are they confused & conflicted? checkDoes everything work out in the end? Well that's the question & the moviemakers leave it for you to decide but there's just too many things left unanswered by this film for it to get a high rating from me. Too many things that are passed over in the interest of moving the story forward.Yet I'm recommending a viewing because of the talent of the actors. It's seldom you get to see two male support roles filled by the quality of William Hurt & Ed Harris & they are stunning. Viggo Mortensen is way out of his league currently with these two but he puts in a marvelous performance as Tom Stall et al. Maria Bello is- all I can say is to paraphrase a line from Pretty Baby used by Brooke Shields & say, 'I can feel the steam rise up in her right through her dress.' God Bless the cheer leaders of America. Every guy that sees this show will want to be Tom Stall. Ashton Holmes plays Viggo's son, Jack, & should receive notice for the quality of his portrayals also.See it for the acting & see it for the moral ambiguity but I say rent don't buy.  3.5 stars. If you just like up-close & personal violence then this might just be a buy for you.
summary: A Moral Dilemma for the viewer

reviewText: I want to be clear, I did not hate this movie - however I did not love this movie, nor did I even really enjoy this movie.  With all the hype and my heightened expectation I rented A History of Violence KNOWING I would be wowed. But I wasn't - not even close.  I really felt disconnected from the plot in this movie - often an unbelieveable story becomes plausible with the right direction and the careful unfolding of plot - this was not the case for this film.  Our story jumps so violently from it's hum-drum pace to flat our action, and our characters digress so quickly from loving family members to monsters that I find it difficult to believe or enjoy.  I see this film as "a ground breaking shocker" to the unjaded, blockbuster film freak who has never ventured far from Bruce Willis or Tom Hanks, however for those of us who long left the safety of the shores of Hollywood this film just doesn't cut it.

reviewText: I agree with the other reviewers that this is thought provoking, yet imperfect.  But compared to the usual sequels and comic books we get these days its pretty interesting.The story line is nothing more than the "guy who can't remember where he learned to do that" used recently in Bourne Identity.  Then comes the innocent guy forced to defend his family which goes back at least as far as Straw Dogs.The problem?  First, Cronenberg just can't make a film about the Johnsons, living at 123 Main Street, Anyplace, USA.  The town looks right but sorry to say, hardly anybody in small town Indiana looks like Viggo Mortensen.  And Maria Bello looks like Kelly McGillis minus 20 pounds.  That's fine in Malibu but in Indiana....Problem #2 is that it isn't possible to accurately portray gun violence and still have an entertaining movie.  So there are brief glimpses of blood and guts but the survivors seem to return to normal functioning almost immediately.That said, the acting is just fabulous.  Everyone is right on the money, with this difficult material.  Think of Tom Cruise defending his family and then watch how Viggo Mortensen does it.  And of course you can't go wrong with Ed Harris and William Hurt.As for the sex scene I think guys will get it.  Its about a man watching everything that's good in his life, everything he has built literally slipping from his grasp.  Its not as though it comes out of thin air as some people have suggested.
summary: Nicely done but not quite real.

reviewText: WARNING: This film contains strong brutal violence, graphic sexuality/nudity, explicit language, and brief drug use.In the film A History of Violence, director David Cronenberg (VideodromeandCrash) examines America's fascination with violence. At the same time, both compelling and disturbing, the film shows the way that violence affects the residents of a small town in the Midwest. Utilizing his sense of irony, as well as his cinematic ability to create suspense, Cronenberg focuses on the characters, their motivations, their actions, and their regrets. He forces viewers to ask themselves what the consequences of violence are and whether or not killing can ever be justified?Tom Stall and his family seem like your typical church-going, honest American family, but all of that changes on one fateful night when two psychotic criminals threaten the patrons of Tom's diner and Tom shoots them both, in self-defense, and kills them. Suddenly Tom finds himself a quasi-celebrity and the dynamic of his family shifts. His wife Edie, his son Jack, and his daughter Sarah become aware that Tom is more than what they thought. Their lives are intruded upon when a group of hitmen from Philadelphia claim that Tom is really a killer named Joey Cusack. Lead by a man named Carl Fogarty, the hitmen target Tom's family and Tom begins to show a paranoid and aggressive dark side that scares his loved ones. After a final confrontation with Fogarty and his men, Tom and his wife's marriage is fractured and their lives are forever altered. Is Tom really Joey, a killer for the mob? And if so, can he find redemption or is he always going to be haunted by this history of violence?The film is certainly Cronenberg's most commercial endeavor and this is in part because of the brilliant cast featuring Viggo Mortensen as Tom Stall, Maria Bello as Edie Stall, Ed Harris as Carl Fogarty, and William Hurt as Richie Cusack.When New Line Cinema released A History of Violence, they advertised it as an action/thriller, which isn't entirely accurate. While the film contains action and is sure to thrill, it's really more of a character study showing the dualism of one man's identity and his attempts to forget his past. It's also a stark reminder of what desperation can drive us to do.Also recommended:Straw DogsDeath WishTaxi DriverThe Bourne Identity(1988 television version)The Films of Michael HanekeRansomMementoRoad to Perdition

reviewText: This film is so utterly preposterous, I had to take a step back -- "what the?" -- and reconsider everything I "relied" on to guide me to a worthwhile cinematic experience.CAUTION: I can't really discuss what it is about this "work" that so boggled my mind -- albeit, in the opposite direction of "awe"; we're talking real "incredulousness," here -- without a few "SPOILERS," so I'll try to give advance notice as I proceed (though -- let's face it: the TITLE ITSELF is practically begging for it!).[SPOILER ALERT #1]: He really WAS in the mob!No, really?  Is that a surprise?  'Cause, guess what kids: if that were REALLY true -- REALLY REALLY true -- as soon as the Ed Harris dude shows up (the one with the scratched-out eye & scar across his face, which "reminds" him of the main character), one wouldn't really get much time to hang around afterwards.  He could B.S. his way through the first convo -- sure, fine -- and then dash home to get his family out of town, go on the run, explain it to wifey & son later ...WAIT A MINUTE: That's NOT what he does, does he?NO!No, apparently, we -- the viewers -- are supposed to swallow that he'd just hang around -- new haircut, and all -- and figured ... like, what?  The mob guys would get so tired of his constant evasiveness ("No ... REALLY guys!  I'm REALLY someone else entirely!  Honest!"), that they'd lose interest, out of irritation, and drive ALL THE WAY BACK across the county to Pennsylvania with a "Well, I guess that WASN'T him after all!" sort-of attitude?Um ... nah.  Not so much.  There's, like, NO WAY that would've happened -- and there's NO WAY the Viggo Mortensen character couldn't have, uh, KNOWN that -- so ... what do we get, instead?A bit of "narrative sleight-of-hand" -- the hinge of the premise, the title, & the "big truth" of the film -- flying in the face of all "traceable," outside-the-film logic.[SPOILER ALERT #2]:  Killing someone with a shotgun -- especially if you're a teenager (from a sheltered, suburban upbringing, no less) -- does NOT make you a "samurai warrior," or even an "angry, violent-type" fighter: it's a TRAUMA!The kid would've needed COUNSELING -- or, more specifically, exhibited the sort of behavior that would lead people to recommend counseling -- because pulling the trigger and experiencing the viscera/energy-loss/psychic-"maxing out" of taking a human life would leave him in NO OTHER state.(This, in a sense, gets at what I find most disingenuous about this film: the way it plays with genre conventions & art-film "truths" willy-nilly, whenever it feels like it.  Clearly, the teen son "saves" his father in a "cliffhanger" fashion -- we won't go into how his dad manages to overpower & outwit everyone but the mob boss character, since this is a Sylvester Stallone film, and we expect that ... er, wait ... WHAT was the premise of this film again?)Right.  "Deep truths."  Of course!SO: the kid goes to school, and ... overpowers two (2) jock "bully" types, because ... the diegesis (& David Cronenberg, the screenwriter) see fit to reveal this as a "life truth"?Hmm ... no.No, because fighting's like anything else that requires experience: on top of the fact that the kid would likely be home from school that day, anyway -- suffering night tremors, horrific nightmares, vomiting, etc. (and, what: I'M being "melodramatic"?) -- he's able to "best" two (2) opponents who -- jerks though they are, and limited though their "arsenal" of approaches may be -- pound other guys faces on a semi-regular basis?Right.  Sure.No problem ... for a "Die Hard" movie![SPOLIER ALERT #3]: Ultimately, this is point #1 "brought home," to the denouement of the film: leaving aside the fact that no-one in the mob would, ludicrously, try to kill someone lured into a we-have-all-the-advantage trap with as outmoded and troublesome a method as strangulation with piano wire (???) -- allowing the Viggo Mortensen character to "escape," while the audience rolls their eyes & the William Hurt character makes a weird, semi-ironic joke about "f***[ing] that up," (which is sort of lost in the shuffle, given that, obviously, the screenwriter painted the characters into that particular corner; which are we supposed to "believe"?) -- besting all the adversaries (again: ACTION MOVIE realism!) hardly means the father has "escaped" these folks ... I mean, like, what supposed to happen next?  The DEATH TOLL of high-ranking dudes in the mob the father's escaped is WAY HIGH ... you think they won't, like, NOTICE?  And, uh, take RETRIBUTION?  Y'know ... like ... EVER???Duuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuh!Gimme a break!  What crap!
summary: The Movie that Made Me Stop Going to Movies for a While

reviewText: This was a very intriguing movie, for the most part. I liked the fact that the action, although violent at times, was not overdone. Most of the movie is pretty low-key.What I didn't care for  was our hero's wife, who was way too big-city-hard looking and profane to be some small-town country girl who would marry such a nice guy as "Tom."William Hurt gets third billing in the film but only shows up with 14 minutes left! Granted, his role is a memorable one, however. Ed Harris also had few lines for someone who gets good billing. Another guy I thought was pretty cool was the sheriff, played by Peter MacNeill. He had bigger roles than Harris or Hurt but got no billing. Go figure.Overall, this was a unique film and one I would would watch again.

reviewText: This is not a pleasant film.  It is about the nature of violence and how humans are forced into violence and its consequences.  Master of visceral angst, David Cronenberg, tackles the subject of the present haunted by the past in small town America in A History of Violence.  Although its subject matter is disturbing and the visuals are unnerving, it boasts some of the best acting in any film this year and is the most accomplished of Cronenberg's cinematic canon.Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) is a family man who runs a quiet diner in a small town and has the idyllic life of husband to a beautiful, loving wife, Edie (Maria Bello), and father to an adolescent son, Jack (Ashton Holmes), and younger daughter, Sarah (Heidi Hayes).  One fateful day a pair of serial criminals barges into the diner looking for trouble in the worst way, and Tom must protect his patrons and staff.  What transpires is a remarkable display of self defense and marksmanship as Tom becomes a local hero for his bravery.  Soon after, a mysterious, black car begins to stalk Tom and his family at his diner and home.  A hardened looking man named Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris) approaches Tom.  It seems Tom's notoriety in the media has attracted Fogarty's attention leading him to believe Tom is not who he appears to be but rather a man named Joey with a very dark, violent past.  Years ago, this Joey had run from the mob after causing a lot of trouble and mutilating one of Fogarty's eyes.  The uneasy tension bubbles over when Fogarty and his men confront Tom at his home as his family watches in terror.  What happens then and afterwards leads to traumatic discovery and the reevaluation of relationships that culminates full circle at a mobster's mansion in Philadelphia.Adapted by Josh Olson from the graphic novel by John Wagner and Vince Locke, director Cronenberg displays a sure hand in his scenes of conflict whether they are emotional or violent.  How ironic that the Canadian born director comments on the violence in the U.S.  He does a nice job of setting up the scenes and characters methodically as we first see a loving family amid an innocent town. Subsequently, an ominous atmosphere of foreboding hangs over the rest of the film.  There are some terrific set pieces that culminate in startling violence, and the confrontation at Tom's house is quite memorable and results in a moment of truth.  Let it be said that the violence is organic.  It grows out of necessity and is carried out brutally and swiftly.  The scenes have a lingering trauma on the characters and the audience.  The visuals are stark and powerful by cinematographer Peter Suschitzky with a brooding score by Howard Shore (ironically a veteran scorer of previous Cronenberg films and Mortensen's Lord of the Rings trilogy). In fact the film, with its small, peaceful town contrasted with an evil menace, feels like a David Lynch film, and is thematically very much akin to Blue Velvet or Twin Peaks.Ed Harris makes a grand entrance early on and he grabs this juicy role and never lets go.  It is certainly one of his finest performances.  William Hurt makes you realize just how talented an actor he is in the relatively short but brilliant turn as a mobster from the past with an agenda.  But it is lead actor Viggo Mortensen who shines as the reluctant hero.  He balances just the right amount of paradoxical innocence and cunning.  He is a man about to peer over the precipice and lose everything he has.  His brooding, quiet but strong avenger is constantly riveting.  Maria Bello is quite touching as the affected wife and mother who is confronted by fear and uncertainty.  Even Stephen McHattie registers strongly as one of the baddies (very reminiscent of the scum in Natural Born Killers) at the beginning.Some directors are accused of making movies of interminable length.  Not so with Cronenberg as he may be accused of being too economic and concise.  While the pacing is tightly edited for maximum impact, some relationships needed to be fleshed out more. During the course of the story, there are two graphic displays of sex between Tom and Edie (one playful and the other angry) which serve as emotional counterpoints to their relationship. We need to understand what is going on in Edie's mind and how she faces the future with her family.  While there is a promising development of the early bonding between Tom and his introverted son Jack, we want more exposition of Jack as he goes from harassed school kid to a coming of age.  We just needed a bit more character development, but what we do have is pretty thought provoking and unforgettable.  The final scene is memorable.A far cry from his notorious horror films, this film delves into the true nature of self and identity.  This is Cronenberg's most accessible film since The Fly and The Dead Zone.  While his early horror films like Scanners and Videodrome dealt with physical transformation, this film deals with metaphysical transformation.  He comes dangerously close to his earlier, notorious cult film, Crash (not to be confused with Paul Haggis' current film), another film about human behavior dealing with psychological change. His films often deal with ugly, sordid truths and secrets that lie beneath what is perceived superficially.  A fascinating study and exploration of human behavior under the most extreme duress, A History of Violence is an intelligent, brutal gem of a film not for all tastes, but for those willing to peer on the other side of sanity and complacency, it's a dark slice of unsavory life.
summary: A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE Disturbs the Senses

reviewerName: Damian Gunn "The Dark One is I"
reviewText: David Cronenberg paints a dark and disturbing picture, a deep and meaningful look at human nature and the parts of us that we wish weren't there.  'A History of Violence' is the story of Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen), a laid back family man living a normal life working at his family run diner.  He has a loving wife Edie (Maria Bello in a brilliant oscar ROBBED role) and two kids.  He has a normal life, and he likes it that way.  His 'normal' life is disrupted when two thugs try and rob him.  When the robbery goes a bust and the thugs try and murder one of Tom's employees Tom, in an act of bravery (and instinct) kills the two men and becomes the town hero.  Hero has a nice ring to it, but when it brings with it unwanted attention, and not just media attention, then 'hero' is not what you want to be.  When a man by the name of Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris) shows up at Tom's diner and accuses him of being a man by the name of Joey Cusack things start to change for Tom.  You can sense some truth in Carl's voice and some terror in Tom's eyes.  (I just want to say now that Viggo Mortensen, while not one of my favorite actors, does a GREAT job of acting with his eyes throughout this film, subtly doing SO much with just his stare.)  Even though Tom denies everything questions are still raised as to the truth behind what Carl has said, and as Carl continues to harass the Stall family those questions eventually answer themselves and Edie begins to see the man that her husband really is, the man that her husband kept hidden for so long.  On surface level this film seems standard, seems 'been-there-done-that' but it's quite the opposite.  'A History of Violence' is more about our inner person and our inbred traits then about 'violence'.  It's about the inability to change who we are just because we want to and the fact that somethings we're born with (as is seen in the way Tom's son Jack decides to deal with the school bully).  The final confrontation between Tom and his brother, kingpin Richie Cusack (William Hurt in his brilliant oscar nominated role) explains the backstory for the viewer but also sheds some light on who Tom/Joey really is...what type of man he is, errr, was.  This film is a great charactor study and a movie that should be watched, and as some have suggested, studied.  What makes this movie by far is the acting, especially on the part of Maria Bello who blew me away with her brilliant performance.  Just watch the seen in the hospital when she finds out the truth about her husband.  Her movements, her words, everything is so sudden and tense you'd swear she wasn't acting.  This is by no mean the 'best' film of 2005 but it is worthy of all it's praise and is deffinitly top 10!
summary: "Tom is who he says he is."

reviewText: Since the dawn of man people have been kicking the crap out of each other.  Our myths, our religions, our fiction, and are non-fiction are paved with violence.  From a simple game of dodge ball the ongoing war in Iraq our lives are filled with violence.  David Cronenberg's A History of Violence is a tale of a simple act of heroic violence and how even if you don't plan on "living by the sword" sometimes the sword is thrown into your lap.Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) has a simple life.  He owns a diner in a tiny little Indiana town.  There he makes sandwiches, slings burgers, pours coffee, and make a darn fine piece of pie.  He has a beautiful family, his wife (Maria Bello) adores him, his son looks up to him, and his daughter is just so darn precocious.  His world is rocked when two men try to violently rob the diner.  Tom shoots to kill, setting up a series of events that will shake him and his families life forever.A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE is one of those movies that tries to turn  the familiar thriller on its head.  It succeeds sometimes and at other times it clunks along offering very few questions as to why things are happening.  When the film finally reveals itself, your left holding a bag of half thought out ideas, and performances that aren't quite believable enough to add up to a film worth spending your hard earned time and energy on.Mortensen and Bello carry the film.  It's a tough job and you can tell both actors are trying really hard to save it.  Unfortunately Mortensen is given a character that has no real life.  He just floats in and out of reality, and when all is said and done I wasn't sure if his Tom could be who he says he is.  The final act puts him in a house with John Hurt.  The scene is so stilted it's as of Cronenberg told Mortensen to back off.  It's Hurt's time to shine.  Hurt mugs to the camera creating a character who is all performance and no life.As for Bello she's asked to pull her character through some even bigger hurdles.  But again the material she's given leaves no room for subtlety.  So you watch as this character runs the gamut of emotions for what?  I'm not really sure.  One minute she's big and brash the next she's sullen.  Some better motivation would have lifted her performance out of the gutter.  But alas she's good, just not that good.A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE is another head scratching question asking ride that will have you leaving the theater ready for a night of discussion.  But at the end of the road you'll probably find that there was nothing profound to learn from it, and you won't really be entertained by it.  You might like this film bout you probably won't love it.
summary: You might like this film but you probably won't love it.

reviewText: The story of "A History of Violence" is quite simple: a professional killer, fleeing his past, becomes a family man to have his identity discovered when he kills in self defense.  When we first meet him, Tom Stall is the owner of a diner in a small Indiana town carrying out a daily routine of work and family.  An interesting part of the story involves Tom's teenage son Jack who is being harassed by a bully at school.  Like Tom, he keeps a mind mannered demeanor until pushed too far when he puts the bully in the hospital.  Tom admonishes his son for what he has done but soon his own violent past (by all accounts a sadistic past) intrudes.Viggo Mortensen gives a measured performance as Tom Stall.  He is very ordinary as he pursues the routines of his life.  Maria Bello is very good as his wife Edie; they make a good couple, and are very much in love.  The children were well cast and played: Ashton Holmes is very good as the teenage Jack who looses the father that he knew and Heidi Hays is equally good as Tom and Edie's young daughter.  She has a pivotal role in the last scene of the film that indicates to us as to whether Tom will be able to resume his Ed Harris is excellent as usual and unforgettable as Carl Fogarty, disfigured by Tom Stall in his former life as Joey Cusack and looking for revenge.  He generates a feeling of menace just by being in a scene.  It was interesting to see William Hurt in his cameo as Tom/Joey's ruthless brother.  He has only one scene but that one is played beautifully as Hurt's Richie Cusack muses about how his brother could become such an unheard of think as a family man, going on to tell Joey how much he has cost him over the years.My wife thought that the film started a little on the slow side but I think it is important to establish Tom Stall's solid, if boring,  family life.  Once the violence begins - and it is a graphic film - the pace is unrelenting.  Beyond the violence, however, are the questions the film raises about the violence of our society and even though we know it is wrong people fall into it willingly and unwillingly.  For Tom Stall aka Joey, even though he has renounced his violent past it is so much a part of him that he acts from pure instinct.  I think that I will never forget the final scene in the film, set to wonderfully brooding music by Howard Shore, when Tom returns home and is reluctant to enter the kitchen where his family is having dinner.  You can read the uncertainty in all of the faces - Edie, Jack and Tom.  It is his young daughter who settles the issue of "inviting"  Tom in, to be a family again. We all know that things will not be the same but all of them need each other.  So, David Chroenburg has given us a thought provoking story offering many perspectives on the workings of violence.

reviewText: I knew that David Cronenberg would make another film that would receive serious attention and critical acclaim, and here it is.  Tom Stall (Viggo Mortenson) is the owner of a small-town cafe who has a very dark and violent past that he has managed to bury deep inside himself.  The attempted robbery of his diner by a pair of sociopaths triggers a series of events that will force Tom and his family to come to grips with his past and his hidden nature.Cronenberg's specialty as a filmmaker is couching serious, fascinating questions about the nature of personality and perception within compelling, violent narratives, and he is in top form here.  How much control can we really exercise over our basic natures?  To what extent are we ruled by our genetic wiring and to what extent can we consciously choose the kind of person we want to be?  Did Tom earn his idyllic small town existence by having the strength to change, or is it just that he be punished with the consequences of his former life?  This is a film that can be enjoyed for ninety minutes, then contemplated for hours afterward.

reviewText: David-and-Goliath fantasies have been a part of many people's daydreams since, well, since at least the times of David and Goliath, and very long ago, authors of all sorts discovered there was an eager market for such stories. In our own times, in the early 1970s, David Carradine starred in a TV series called "Kung Fu," playing the sort of quiet, unassuming, peace-loving fellow that bullies love to beat up. Week after week, viewers were treated to the spectacle of bullies (often criminal bullies) getting the crap kicked out of them when they foolishly tried to mess with THIS guy. It made no difference if they were armed with knives or guns and in groups of five or ten or even twenty--the bullies never had a chance. From the early1980s to the mid-'90s, a series of KARATE KID movies starring Pat Morita had similar fantasy plots: nobody, no group, regardless of their weapons or their skills, had better mess with elderly little Mr. Miyagi--or his pupils.A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE combines this sort of heroic fantasy with some erotic fantasies in a fairly satisfying way. Viggo Mortensen (best known as Strider/Aragorn in THE LORD OF THE RINGS) here plays a quiet fellow who runs a diner and who, to our delight, efficiently disposes of a series of tough guys who are trying to kill him. Elements of mystery are stirred in (who is he really? what sort of past has he had?), and depth is added by having his wife and son struggle to accept the hidden facets of him that suddenly appear.Ed Harris and William Hurt are excellent as the chief villains, and Maria Bello is wonderful as the hero's intelligent and sexy wife. The action scenes, both violent and erotic, are skillfully choreographed, including a fight that the hero's son has with bullies in high school.The special features on the DVD include some interesting commentary. There we can discover that the film's director, David Cronenberg, is at least partly sending a kind of message--which many viewers probably missed: he wished to make us a bit more aware of our divided feelings about using violence as a solution to our own problems, whether as individuals or as a nation. Just as Mortensen's character has "a history of violence" (as a prosecuter might say), many of us--including many of our leaders--have a long-term preference for the use of force rather than other solutions. My own impression is that this message was an afterthought and was not fully incorporated into the plot of the film.Considered chiefly as a fulfillment to our David-and-Goliath fantasy needs, this film has one major plot weakness that could easily have been corrected: we never learn how, when, where, or why Mortensen's character acquired his superior martial-arts skills. His "moves" are clearly not things that he would have been picked up in bar fights or street fights. Imagine the KILL BILL movies with such a plot-gap: the audience HAS to know where Uma Thurman, Daryl Hannah, David Carradine, and many of the rest learned to fight so well. Even in "Kung Fu," we got many flashbacks to the Shaolin temple where Carradine's character got his training, and in the KARATE KID films we found out that Pat Morita's character was taught karate by his father on Okinawa.If you would like to watch a 5-star heroic underdog fantasy, buy, borrow, or rent BAD DAY AT BLACK ROCK, a 1955 film in which Spencer Tracy plays a one-armed WWII veteran who "takes out the trash"--um, single handedly.
summary: HEROIC FANTASY WITH (PERHAPS) A HIDDEN MESSAGE

reviewText: I thought that overall this film was quite good, the plot was intruiging like an old gangster/mafia flick, the acting was most certianly up to par on every part (though I thought that William Hurt's performance was to small and quick to be nominated for best supporting actor), and the action was nothing short of very exciting. "A History Of Violence" makes you believe something one minute, then completely mess's with your mind into making you think and believe in somthing else. Though I thought that the ending for some reason seemed a little to short overall every aspect was pretty good.I watched this film after I read that Rolling Stone magazine thought that this was the BEST film of the year, but after seeing the film on DVD and reading some other reveiws on it I relized that the writer of that specific article was mistaken, "A History Of Violence" was simply not at the same caliber as of the films that have come out the past year or so.I havent seen a movie with so much scene to scene non-stop action a little while and it was most refreshing to finnally see one after some time. I would recommend this movie to just about everyone over 14 or so due to the fact that is does have some gore that exceeds most films as well as some of the more "aggressive" sexual content you will see. Any thriller or action lover should and in my opinion will enjoy this film, Go ahead and buy it, it's one of those movies you will probably want to see more than once.Grade: B - B+

reviewText: "Horror-meister" David Cronenberg (AKA "King of Venereal Horror," or "the Baron of Blood") began directing movies in the sixties, mostly made-for-TV fare, and then moved to the big screen in the seventies with some forgettable scifi/horror flicks.  But then in the eighties he perfected his art (if you can call it that: I prefer to call it "the cynical seduction of the audience by playing upon their worse fears," but, hey, I never had to make a living in filmland) with e.g., Scanners (1981), The Fly (1986), Dead Ringers (1988), etc.  Here he settles for plain, ordinary two-fisted psycho/mobster/killer-type violence.Viggo Mortensen stars as Tom Stall who runs a diner in a small midwestern town, a likeable guy with a wife Edie (Maria Bello) and two kids.  He's just your average joe until one day some cold-blooded killers visit his diner and decide to rape and pillage.  Tom manages to take their guns from them and send them to meet their maker in a bit of surprising heroics that draws the attention of some mobsters from Philadelphia.  They apparently think Tom is a onetime mobster/hit man named Joey Cusack who had done them some grievous harm in the past.  They want revenge.  The question is, have they got their man or is this a tragic case of mistaken identity?  Interesting premise.(Possible spoilers to come, so proceed at your own risk.)There is one thing especially wrong with this movie and that is the adamant reaction of Tom Stall's family when they learn the truth.  I can't say more without revealing too much plot detail, but for those who have seen the movie, you may know what I am saying.  His family, regardless of what they learned, could not help but be one hundred percent on his side.  The most they should have said is, "You should have told us" and yet even that is too much.  They should come to the realization of what kind of man he is as the audience does, slowly and only after the final scenes.  This is the kind of cinematic mistake that directors sometimes make.  They are completely familiar with the material.  They know how it ends and so they sometimes put their characters in the frame of mind that their characters would have if their characters knew everything the director knew.  But Edie and the kids did not know who their father really was even after the scene when the black Cadillac Escalade pulls up into their yard.  I know if my spouse or father had been such a good man for so many years, I would not turn on him just because he kicked a bit too much tail a bit too successfully, especially when saving other people's lives.Otherwise this is a kind of brilliant movie.  The ending is perfect.  The psychology is straight out of evo psych; a kind of forbidden truth is told on several levels, and when all is said and done, the little girl goes and gets the plate and the silverware, and the son passes the roast to his father.  What else is there to be done?  One can imagine that this is how it is and has been for tens of thousands of years in the household of the warlord, the house of the man who managed to survive--never mind how.  Such is the nature of human beings.There are a couple of very true to life sex scenes in this movie that will be too much for people who have cliche ideas about sex or like to kid themselves a lot.  Again those of you who have seen the movie will know what I am talking about: well, the one in which Edie says we never experienced high school together is one of them.  The scene on the staircase is the other.  They are both well done.The redeeming factor for the hero is that we never see him do anything except in self-defense.  He has an amazing ability to protect himself and to put those who attack him out of their misery.  It's almost comic book, cowboy movie quality.  Yet I think Cronenberg made it so realistic that you almost believe it could happened.  Mortensen's character is part of the hero/superman/ninja/two-fisted/John Wayne type of guy who can win a barroom fight against a half dozen other men, a guy who can beat a trio of armed toughs, stripping them of their weapons and using them against them because he is quicker and more deadly.  A nice bit of supporting psychology is all of the business with the son and the school bully.  The way the son handles him actually supports the violent-hero mythology: like father, like son.  It's in the blood.The title of the film suggests a documentary.  But if you think instead about something that somebody would say about an individual's past you'll see that the title is apt.Nice supporting work by Ed Harris and William Hurt.  But let's face it, this is an R-rated movie without much in the way of redeeming social value, and is in fact a very nice seduction of its targeted audience, which is what one would expect from Cronenberg.
summary: Beware of people in black Cadillac Escalades

reviewText: In "A History of Violence," director, David Cronenberg, creates a masterful study of the human psyche adapted from the graphic novel of the same name by John Wagner and Vince Locke.  Performances by Viggo Mortensen, Maria Bello, Ashton Holmes, Ed Harris and a particularly enjoyable one by William Hurt intensify from one frame to the next, bringing to life the simple plot line that unfurls a deeper metaphor with as many tasty layers as an Outback Steakhouse Bloomin' Onion.Rather than reiterate the story once again, I will state only that when an unforeseen event catapults Tom Stall's other self back into action, he and his family must deal with not only the repercussions but with a new understanding of someone they thought they knew and trusted.Where many of the other reviewers focus on the film's violence that we, as 21st century denizens thoroughly familiarized with the Newtonian ideas of action versus reaction, experience on an almost quotidian basis and subsequently either absorb or repel, I suggest that this engrossing film flicks on an inner light that illumines and asks us to explore those hidden secret parts of ourselves.  Either through reinvention or suppression, we all decide to tuck away certain aspects of our true nature.  The legendary party-goer, for instance, once becoming a parent, may, out of a sense of responsibility or respectability dispense with the accoutrements of those wild Friday and Saturday nights.  In order to be eligible for that special promotion, one may opt to cut one's hair, have that tattoo lasered off the ankle and change one's vocabulary to reflect the individual worthy of earning more cash.  We take on different roles as we move forward (or backwards) in life; we become someone's spouse . . . someone's boss . . . someone's parent . . . someone's someone that infers evolving into a role model that knows all the right things to say and do that will keep us positioned and functioning as this archetype.Like Tom Stall, played to perfection by Viggo Mortensen in the film, we are subject to the events of the past.  Suggestive of the scorpion in the fable whose nature it is to sting the frog he is helping to cross the river and hence, destroy himself, we will find ourselves reverting back to that self---that real identifying "me" without any of the qualifying subtitles (wife, mother, father, sister, etc.)  that we either reengineered through self-reinvention or suppressed in order to forget or seemingly progress.Perhaps Cronenberg poses the question, "Can one justly suppress one's true nature?"  Does he suggest in the form of this story that like others who at one time or another in their adulthood undergo what is commonly called a "second childhood," that Stall like ourselves will mid-life-crisis out and struggle to regain that piece of himself that was his and only his from birth despite what other standards he has attributed to or acquired for himself?Bottom line?  See the film.  Yes, it has its moments of violence, but look beyond that and examine the theme of reinvention and self-identity that Cronenberg so wisely pushes up from the depths of the subconscious.  Check out the differences in the two sex scenes between Mortensen and Bello and revel in the last few minutes of the film where silence conveys a wealth of emotions which range from hopefulness to acceptance.  Recommended to all that are not thrown by a graphic novel's sense of violence.Diana F. Von Behren"reneofc"

reviewText: Recently I had a break in and was able to scare the person away without much incident.  An hour later he was apprehended by police a block away breaking into another house.  Since, I have added more security to my residence, not totally for my protection but also for the safety of others.  I found out shortly after the incident that the person who broke in was a drunk 16 year old boy who at the time of the incident wore a closed hooded sweatshirt and it was dark, so I had no idea.  I could have killed him, I have 3 loaded pistols around the house and that would have been an easy task.  But, seriously, does a drunk 16 year old need to be shoot for a dumb mistake.  He was only drunk and cold, I think not.  So every time I set up my security I always say to myself, this is not for my safety, but so I don't have to unnecessarily kill some one.I don't have a history of violence, but I do have the ability, I know!. reviewText: This film has a definite deliberate slow paced feel to it. This pace is utilized brilliantly for this film. The viewer is cast into a small town in Indiana. David Cronenberg (Director) develops each character just enough to spoon feed the viewer into doubt.Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) is a small town diner owner. He is married to Edie (Maria Bello) and has two teenage kids. All seems normal until would be murders stop at his diner. He thwarts the murders but is cast as a hero in the national media.When Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris) a big time Philadelphia mobster stops by his diner for a conversation with Tom a shadow is cast. Is it a case of mistaken identity? Secrets will be revealed. William Hurt's performance of Richie Cusack is portrayed majestically.The action sequences are detailed and graphic. But violence is always graphic right? The relationship between Tom and Edie is a mystery but portrayed as layered. I really enjoyed this film because of the Director's filming techniques. (I.e. Quentin Tarantino films) This is a signature film that is maintained consistently throughout the filming process. I recommend adding this DVD to your collection.

reviewText: Contrary to many of the reviews I've seen on here, I thought A  History of Violence was an amazing film. The film takes it's time getting started, which is a good thing. It sets up the two criminals as violent, cruel and heartless men, as evidenced by the one guy shooting a small girl down in cold blood. Once the film moves to Tom Stall's town in Indiana, and the killers show up in his store, the story takes off and kept me fascinated till the end. The plot line certainly led me to completly believe it when the son in the family fought back against a bully who'd been harrassing him in and out of school. The violence, while vivid at times, was certainly justified by the story. The nude scene with Maria Bello could have been done without, but it didn't completely ruin the story. At the end of the film you're left with a family that is pretty much destroyed by the events of the film. I kept wondering what would happen to them and found the final scene particularly moving, with the parents both in tears for the ruin their happy lives have become and the teenage boy aware of the problems, their young daughter quite oblivious to it all in her innocence. The only thing that surprised me was William Hurt getting an oscar nomination for this film, since he's barely in it at all. I highly recommend this film for anyone who wants to see an intelligent and moving film of a family torn apart by violence, accusations and the recriminations of doubt that can happen to people who are accused of something that no one is completly sure that they're innocent of.

reviewText: Tom Stall runs a diner in a small town. He is well liked by the people and well loved by his family. reviewText: Viggo Mortensen portrays a character named Tom Stahl.  There is nothing salient or remarkable about Tom;  he lives a simple life, owns a coffee shop in a small town in Indiana and tries his best to be a good husband and family man.  Tom Stahl would be an excellent subject for a Norman Rockwell painting.However, Tom has a deep dark secret that is exposed via a random chance encounter with bad guys who wish to rob his coffee shop.  Tom was formerly Joey, and Joey was a hit-man for the Philadelphia mob.  After the incident, Tom's buried past is disinterred.Such is an outline of the plot line.  The movie is well worth seeing to see the psychological struggle between a man who almost has a sort of split-personality complex.  Both Tom & Joey would like nothing better than to live the  mundane, unglamorous life of Tom Stahl.  However, the abilities of Joey must be called upon to preserve that life of normalcy & protect his family.I very much enjoyed this film as it is something of a "switch" from what we're used to.  So many times, movies center around every-day characters who fantasize about being secret agents and such.  In this case, the main character is a highly trained killer who wants nothing more than  a life of peace, simplicity and obscurity.Even though I'm not huge on mob movies, I would highly recommend this one.  It's a sort of mob movie with a "twist" if you will.  It's a well done film and Mortensen does a good job of going back & forth between his two antipodal alter-egos.

reviewText: In director David Cronenberg's latest thriller A History of Violence we follow the story of Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen), the local town family man with a pretty wife and two kids. Tom owns a diner in the middle of the small town of Millbrook, Indiana, where life is simple and quiet. That is until two killers show up looking for trouble. One of the guys draws a gun and tells Tom to empty the cash register and threatens to kill the remaining customers. He responds by leaping over the counter, and gunning down the two men in an instant. Tom is considered to be a hero for taking down the two criminals, but he says it was just shear luck. Or was it? That's when Carl Fogarty (played perfectly by Ed Harris) shows up thinking that Tom is actually a man named Joey Cusack; a hit-man from Philadelphia, who nearly killed him many years ago. So who are we to believe? Is this all just a case of mistaken identity, or does Tom really have a dark past that he's tried so hard to keep a secret?A History of Violence is based on the graphic novel by John Wagner and Vince Locke. The film is quite effective, especially in showcasing how fragile the human body really is. The brutal violence of the film is quick and sudden, and always justified. It's not shown in slow motion to "milk" or glamorize it, but to show it as Earth-shattering and vicious, which you hardly see in modern movies, because it's often stylized to look pretty and entertaining. But even as the violence is entirely justified in A History of Violence, it's also a startling reminder of just how ugly it can be.David Cronenberg's A History of Violence is not a film for everyone, some will really like it, and others will hate it. But whether you liked it or not, anyone who claims to know anything about films in general has to be able to admit that it is undeniably well made and acted, and at only 96 minutes long, doesn't waste any time doing anything other than storytelling that advances the plot and characters. That being said, A History of Violence isn't really about plot twists as much as it is about characters and character development. Only upon multiple viewings can you really appreciate the great performances from this cast. It's the small things, body language, gestures, eye movements; all of these things allow us to read what's going on in the character's mind at a given moment. And this is important for understanding A History of Violence, because this is an emotionally complex film, and sometimes it's the things that people don't say that speak the loudest.Cronenberg himself has said that he is a complete Darwinian, and the idea of survival of the fittest fits perfectly in context in A History of Violence, because deep down inside Tom is Joey, and Joey is the fittest to survive in a world of violence. But Tom is the person Joey wishes he was; an illusion of peace and happiness. It's not until Joey can finally come face to face with his own history of violence, that he's tried so hard to escape, and has successfully done so for quite some time (that is until he became a hero), that he'll be able to escape his past once and for all. That's why it's called A History of Violence, because it asks the question can someone change their own past history of violence and create a true, and authentic new life that's free of violence?
summary: Stunning and well executed, one of the best films of 2005

reviewText: I won't go into details about the plot because it has been covered in numerous other reviews on the site. But basically we have the story of a man trying to escape his violent past, and doing a good job of it, until the past catches up with him because of a quirk of fate and his own heroic actions.  As the main character, Tom Stall, tries to deal with his past in the menacing form of Ed Harris, as a very convincing mobster, sub-plots are also playing out.  These include the relationship between Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) and his wife (Maria Bello), the relationship betwen Tom and his teenage son, and the tension between the son and the school jock/bully.  There are two very steamy sex scenes between Tom and his wife.  (I loved the cheerleader costume.)  The producer's commentary points out that these scenes are notable for two reasons: first it is rare to have sex scenes only between a man and his wife in a movie, and second, this is the first American film to show the sexual technique known as "69".  The movie is also unusual in that the two best known actors (Ed Harris and Wiliam Hurt) play relatively minor, though critical, roles.  The actor who plays the sheriff is also excellent, as he tries to balance his duty towards the law and his love for his friends. The editing is tight and the action fast-paced.  One reviewer called the ending  "too cute by half."  I found the ending to be both convincing and moving, although a little frustrating in that alot is left hanging and unresolved.

reviewText: This film was a yawn on so many levels it's difficult to know where to begin.Let's see, film opens with two unnamed guys making a tedious exit from a motel. There are no signs hanging from their necks that actually say "Bad Guy" but there might as well be.The first clue that this film is little more than a B grade movie is when the obvious leader of the two tosses the car keys to the obvious underling with the instructions to "bring it up to the office." Audience is immediately perplexed to learn that the office is approximately ten feet away. I kid you not. The underling gets in, starts the car, moves it forward about ten feet, then slides over to make room for "the boss." Okay, maybe this seedy-looking down and outer has done something exceptionally naughty and worries about car bombs.Meanwhile... despite trudging all the way up to "the office" on foot, the boss still has the chops to emerge from same and walk clear out the car again. After making a quip about "having trouble with the maid," he then discovers they are Out Of Water. Not appearing to be in the high desert, one is left to wonder why this is a problem, but apparently it is.Underling must now go in and fill up the gallon milk jug. While laboriously meandering toward this task, the audience is treated to the sight of two dead people lying in pools of blood. Audience is left to wonder whether this was a comment on the quality of service, a robbery, or simple inability to pay the bill. Whatever the cause though, "the boss" must have used a silencer, as no gunshots were heard during the road trip to the office.After finally making his way to the water cooler, underling proceeds to begin filling the jug. A small female child emerges from what appears to be family living quarters. Underling peruses her for a protracted moment as she fearfully strokes her dolly's hair and whimpers.(da dum, da dum, da dum)Then The Gun Is Drawn From His Waistband!CUT AND PRINT!The film goes downhill from there.Judging from the trailers I saw, this sounded like it was going to be a worthwhile flick. The cast (Ed Harris, Viggo Mortensen, etc.) cemented that notion, and I was really looking forward to seeing it. Between the vague, uneven, plodding storyline, completely gratuitous sex (really protracted gratuitous sex no less), and the fact that the whole "mystery" of who Tom Stall really is was obvious the minute he whacked the would-be robbers with such skill, this film was a complete waste of time.Better luck next time folks.

reviewText: Small-town diner owner Tom Stall stops a brutal robbery by overcoming two thugs with a surprising display of bravery and fighting skill that makes him a hero to his fellow townspeople. The ensuing media spotlight draws the attention of a Philly mobster with a mutilated face, who insists Tom is not who he says he is. The question of identity posed by the mobster becomes the central theme of "A History of Violence."Tom appears to be the decent ordinary guy his family and friends have known for years. Yet as the mobster and his henchmen begin to stalk Tom and his family, disturbing clues begin to suggest a different personal history for Tom. A violent ending in two parts posing a haunting question to Tom's family, whether they can learn to live with who he really was."A History of Violence" has a first rate cast, with Viggo Mortensen as Tom Stall, Maria Bello as his wife, Ed Harris as the mutilated mobster Fogarty, and William Hurt in an Academy Award-nominated turn as another Philly mobster. Recommended to those viewers with a strong stomach for a fairly violent film.
summary: Violence is as violence once did

reviewText: The hero of "A History of Violence" is Tom Stall, played with great sensitivity and strength by the virile Viggo Mortensen.  Tom owns a diner in Millbrook, a small Indiana town.  Millbrook is a warm and friendly place, and Tom is a popular businessman.  He is completely devoted to his beautiful wife, Edie, and their two children, Jack and Sarah.  When Jack retaliates after being mercilessly bullied and humiliated by a classmate, Tom feelingly tells his son that beating people up does not solve anything.Tom's life changes when two psychotic criminals come into his diner at closing time.  The thugs make no effort to hide their intentions.  When Tom manages to quickly and effortlessly disarm the intruders, he is hailed by his friends, neighbors, and the media.  He becomes a celebrity, with his name and photo splashed all over television and the newspapers.  Although his fame is good for business, Tom's notoriety has some unpleasant side effects.  Three tough guys from Tom's past spot his picture and decide to pay him a visit.Cronenberg elicits fine performances from an excellent cast.  Mortensen is a sympathetic and strong protagonist; the lovely Maria Bello plays Edie Stall, a woman who suddenly finds out that there is a hidden side to her husband.  Ed Harris, always an outstanding character actor, is terrific in the small role of Carl Fogarty, a sadistic brute with a long memory. Finally, William Hurt is delightfully over the top as Richie Cusack, a mobster with attitude.  He imbues his character with an offbeat combination of vicious humor and menace.  The movie is stark, spare, and well-edited.  The scenes of carnage are particularly shocking when viewed against the backdrop of everyday life in a small town where nothing much ever happens.  Cronenberg and the screenwriter wisely do not supply us with facile explanations, leaving the audience to ponder the issues raised themselves."A History of Violence" poses these thought-provoking questions: How well can an individual ever know the person he or she marries?  Can someone successfully reinvent himself?  Is it possible to continue living with a spouse who has lied for years? This movie is not meant to be realistic.  It is an allegory about an insane culture that celebrates selfishness, greed, and aggression.  "A History of Violence" is a shocking and disturbingly explicit film that will stay in your mind long after you leave the theater.

reviewText: For the melodramatic premise it looks like it's going to present, this movie shouldn't have worked. But leave it to veteran director David Cronenberg to defy expectations and capture lightning in a bottle with a searing exploration of violence and duplicity. The movie opens with a chilling scene of the aftermath of a harshly bloody act that leads inevitably to another shocking act, but then it shifts gears to a pastoral, Thornton Wilder-like town. The story then focuses on Tom Stall, an upstanding citizen and owner of the local diner. He's been happily married for twenty years to Edie, still a knockout and now a successful lawyer, and they have two children. An unexpected incident in the diner makes Tom a media hero much to his chagrin, and it also brings the attention of some obvious mobsters who think Tom is someone else.While the vigilante set-up sounds like a tribute to the Warner Brothers film noir crime drama of the 1940's, the 2005 film is surprisingly a thoughtful and downright chilling meditation on the causes of violence and the unexpected, almost inevitable ramifications. To say anything more would ruin the plot, but suffice it to say that the movie haunts and resonates with flashes of unflinching violence that only Cronenberg can do graphically without being gratuitous. The foreboding title signals the necessity of the violence, though the shots are relatively subdued from the man responsible for the memorable head explosions in 1981'sScannersand the gooey transformation in the 1986 update ofThe Fly.A gallery of superb performances brings out the wired intensity of the characters starting with the always underrated Viggo Mortenson who is ideally cast as Tom. Looking almost like Gary Cooper but with a dark edge, Mortenson powerfully plays the role right on the balance between decency and denial. Even more impressive is Maria Bello, who simply electrifies as Edie especially as the revelations transform her existence. The stairway scene with Mortenson and Bello elicits a visceral energy that scorches the screen. Ashton Holmes is terrific as their teenage son Jack, who unexpectedly taps into his own anger with a high school bully.In smaller parts that sometimes threaten to broaden toward stereotype, Ed Harris taps into the feral side of his screen persona as Carl Fogarty, a one-eyed mobster who is convinced he knows Tom, and a surprisingly ferocious William Hurt holds his ten minutes of screen time as Richie Cusack, as he provides the key to the unraveling plot. Based on a graphic novel by John Wagner and Vince Locke, the film is ultimately a parable about violence as much as Paul Haggis'sCrash(not Cronenberg's film with the same title) is a parable about racism. However, the major difference is that Cronenberg and screenwriter Josh Olson do not layer contrivances to hammer down on obvious points in their story, and the ending is effectively and hauntingly open-ended. This is a gripping cinematic work strongly recommended.The DVD package is excellent with one of the best making-of documentaries I have seen for a major release, an hour-long feature called "Acts of Violence". It is divided effectively in eight acts with particularly thoughtful comments from Cronenberg, Mortenson and Bello. Cronenberg also provides terrific commentary on an alternate audio track, and there are actually two extras related to a deleted fantasy scene that reflects the more typically gory side of Cronenberg's style. The only feature of lesser interest is a featurette tracking the film to the Cannes Film Festival.
summary: Gripping Meditation on Violence Superbly Rendered by Cronenberg and Stellar Cast

reviewText: A History of Violence:While I didn't hate this movie, I did feel that it left much to be desired.  The movie starts out with us witnessing without witnessing two shady men murder the staff of a roadside motel for no apparent reason.  Next scene, a young girl is screaming, awakened from her sleep by a nightmare.  She is soon comforted by her father, her older brother and her mother.  They seem to be the prefect small town family.Tom Stall, the father, runs a diner in their picture perfect Indiana town and it is within the next few moments of the movie that we are once again introduced to the shady men from the beginning, as they enter Tom's diner.  Not much time passes before we learn they are not in the diner as customers, and definitely mean to bring harm to the owner, his employees and the patrons.It is at this moment that we learn that Tom possesses very finely tuned self-defense skills, as he saves the day by expertly "taking care" of the bad guys.  Such skills as those are not common in ordinary, small town people.  The media, always loving a heroic story, flock around Tom and soon his story is broadcast far and wide on several news stations.  Tom, who isn't welcoming to the idea of being a national hero, comes off as being modest to his family and friends, but is quite obviously to us, the viewers, hiding something.The truth begins to unfold when Tom is visited by a couple of mobsters who believe he is actually Joey Cusack, a man who had violently crossed them years ago back in Philly, and caused one of the men to lose his eye.  Naturally, Tom denies this is true, but that doesn't last long and what follows is a short-lived stand-off between Tom and the two mobsters.There is another part to the back story, involving Tom/Joey's older brother Richie.  He's a successful, very wealthy mobster still living in Philly.  When Tom is summoned to pay his older brother a visit, you just know it isn't a request made out of brotherly love.  Richie is angry because Joey has made it difficult for him to reach the status he wishes to acquire within the mafia circle.  Another short-lived stand-off ensues, and what we are left with is just about the most boring and seemingly incomplete ending to a movie that I've ever seen!Overall, I think the movie was all right.  It had great potential, and I wished it had gone into more detail of Tom's past.  What I'm thinking is that this movie needed about another hour's worth of story explaining the details of Tom's past.  96 minutes is extremely short, especially by today's running time standards.  In any case, I feel that all of the actors did well with what they were given, and the general idea behind the story was very good.  I'd recommend this, sure.  But as a rental only - I don't think it holds much replay value.**Edited to include the the fact that I wasn't aware that this movie was taken from a book when I watched/reviewed it.  Had I read the book, I might have a different opinion on the movie.  Just thought I better include that bit of info to be fair!

reviewText: Willing suspension of disbelief is pushed to the limits in this movie.  One has to believe that the cops can't put all these deaths together.  One has to believe that twenty years of clean living make up for being a sociopathic murderer.  When the movie ended it took a minute for me to realize how much the movie was manipulating me, wanting me to sympathize or even just empathize with this character, just because he wanted to be good. Well, just unlock all the prison doors, 'cause those guys are going straight!  Honest!  And one last gripe - I don't understand the necessity of the graphic oral sex scene.  Luckily I was watching with my husband, because if it had been anyone else, I would have been uncomfortable, and I'm no prude.  I give it two stars instead of one because it has made me think about our justice system, and punishment in our society.  Any movie that makes me consider issues has at least some value.

reviewText: 'A History of Violence' is an examination of the grip and depth of human violence fleshed out in the life of small town family man Tom Stall (played by Viggo Mortensen).  The worst and best of man are portrayed, needy depravity and sublime potential.  The movie exposes the futility of man's contrivances to both escape and avoid evil (pain, chaos, unhappiness).  In addition to plenty of violence, there are a few sex scenes showing both frontal and behind nudity as well as some violence, but the sex is between a married couple and integral to the story.  The portrayal of violence is raw, realistic, graphic and necessary, rather than the kind of overchoreographed thrill scenes from Mr. & Mrs. Smith or the dark, artistic hyperbole of Natural Born Killers.  'A History of Violence' has no tidy wrap-up ending, leaving the viewer to come to one's own conclusions; it is not an upper nor a downer, just a glimpse of an ugly part of reality worth contemplating.  The movie unwittingly has a Christian message in that it presents the bad news of sin and bondage that must come before seeking deliverance; through certain scenes (lake, dinner table) it subtly points the Way to the "good news" of redemption.  A+ performances and screenplay, very unique.
