reviewText: A history of Violence is a first hand look at what happens when the right man gets the wrong kinda attention for being a hero. Tom Stall was an everyday man until he became a town hero by defending his diner from two thugs brutally.Ed Harris gives a rare perfomance for his delightfully non-chalant evil character.There are some moments that are brutal and somewhat disturbing but I think this does something different. I don't know how do describe it but it does. It's sort of like a spagetti western without the western setting. But there is a sort of, "western atmosphere" you might call it.There are some scenes of strong sexual content which, I tell ya, the movie can definetly do without.As for the special features, I'd have to say that I'm surprised that they didn't talk about teh writers of the graphic novel or that they didn't even add a documentary on how closely the movie was trying to match or resemble the images depicted in the graphic novel that made it so great. Little disapointed by that, but, oh well. Maybe they'll come out with a new edition.But, all in all, there are still a lot of documentraires and things for you to get a good chunk of information on.Final verdict: Better than LEAGUE OF EXTRAORDIANRY GENTLEMAN but as brutal as FROM HELL.
summary: "Why do you think he's so good at killing people, Mrs. Stall?"

reviewText: Critics call movies "the best movie of the year" all the time.  Just because it happens does not mean its true.  Ok, so this movie is not bad, but its nothing fantastic either.  The acting is good, (when they actually act), and the story is decent, (when there is story).  The real problem is the bare-bone script, (even the actors and director admits that there isnt that much to the script calling is simple and slim).  Not a whole lot happens.  I mean sure, it is about human nature and blah blah blah but in all reality, i doubt any of these events would happen in the real world so it is just a fake study.  Tom (viggo mortensen) would never act the way he does.  He acts one moment like he doesnt know what to do and the next like a super professional who has done it everyday of his life.  there are a few sex scenes that I guess are supposed to show something deep about the characters but I just think the director wanted to put some sex in just for thrills because its not like the made sense, especially the second one.  I mean would two people really have sex right then?  i think not...The movie moves slow, which i dont mind.  Also the action is borderline kill bill at times, which i can deal with.  There is a good cast and a few tense moments.  My one wish for the movie is that there be a solid ending.  I hate endings that lets the audience imagine what happens next.  I would rather you just tell me.  The movie ends right at the part i wanted to see.  It could have been the emotional peak of the film but instead you just see the credits role.  Oh well... in all this movie was decent but nothing that will go down in history.

reviewText: David Cronenberg is all about how bad people can be and in this movie he shows that "family ties" matter and don't matter a bit.Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) is a nice guy with a nice wife (Maria Bello) and two great kids lving in a little town in Indiana.  He owns a diner where comfortable folks come to eat and the town's the kind of place where people care about each other.  Tom and Edie are so much in love that they can act out their erotic fantasies in middle age as if they are for the first time.  (And of course Edie as a cheerleader is a really cute sexual fantasy.)  These are the middlest of middle Americans.  Or are they?Tom's living a double life and his cover is blown by, of all things, doing a good deed.  (Now there's irony for you.)  From that moment, the moment where he kills two intrusive animal types, all hell breaks loose, revealing by degrees Tom's not-so-middle American background.  (It also establishes Tom as the movie's good guy and mighty man.  And indeed, he pulls off some pretty impressive escape acts.)Turns out Tom is a bad guy from Philly who's been trying to conceal his background and lead a new, scrubbed clean life in Indiana with Edie and the kid.  The movie unfolds as Tom confronts and then tries literally to kill the vestiges of his past:  first, Carl Forgarty (Ed Harris) and then his own brother Richie (William Hurt).The movie is a kind of reverse "Straw Dogs."  An idyllic, apparently happy lifestyle is rent apart until the emergent alpha male can put Eden back together again.  Dustin Hoffman's bifurcate man becomes known to him and us only because of the violence that is thrust upon him.  Tom Stall/Joey Cusack's split personality is one that he wanted dead, never to return.  Once again, however, it is violence thrust upon him that he must deal with, first with someone who intrudes into his idyllic life and who threatens his wife and kids and then, journeying to gangster hell (Philadelphia, it seems), in the "heart of darkness."  (It's not coincidence that Joey must kill his own brother finally to be free of himself.  His brother is of course his bad man alter ego.)Mortensen and Bello render decent performances, although the latter's was rather over the top in some ways.  The true stars are Harris and Hurt, both of whom are aided however by playing bad guys. (This is easier to pull off than Mortensen's task.)  Of the two, by far the better acting job is Harris's, who is extremely convincing as Carl Fogarty.  Hurt relies on too much acting schtick and puts baffles between us, the audience, and his character.  Indeed, his "Ritchie" is a kind of caricature.Fans of Cronenberg will both rejoice in and despair of this movie.  On the one hand, Cronenberg brings violence to such a peak of shocking reality that it cannot fail to impress.  However, that he had to resort to formula here to do it suggests that his more artistic trajectory has been highjacked or at least waylaid.In sum, the movie offers too much that is reminiscent of other older movies (righteous man defends home and family)to rank it among great films.  True, Cronenberg alters the formula to some degree.  But the result is not satisfying as truly original ... or truly Cronenberg.

reviewText: Because one embarks into the theatre thinking about the kinds of violence. So, what kinds of violence come into play here? Lets see: senseless, pointless violence; violence in self defense; gory violence; juvenile violence; plenty of operatic violence; violence as revenge; longstanding vendettas; playful sexual violence; mutual, non-fatal violent sexual release; violent teaching of important lessons; fratricidal violence; deliberate renunciation of violence by violent men; violent men chosing love and family over violence.That would have been all, but most disturbing of all, my enjoyment of vengeace especially when conducted in self-defense. I was one with the protagonist in hurting those who wanted to hurt him, although the protagonist was himself a very violent man who had killed many people.Those who think this is a story, that must follow the canons of storytelling do not get it. This is a meditation on violence, and I came out of it concluding that we are fundamentally violent, and the choice of non violence is a deliberate and studied choice, that must be constantly cultivated and supported.

reviewText: David Cronenberg has outdone himself with his take on a graphic novel, History of Violence. Although it does not resemble much ofthe book Cronenberg has done a great job of direction and of casting this movie. Viggo Mortensen plays a small Indiana towndiner owner who along with his beautiful lawyer wife (Maria Bello) lives a quiet, satisfying life. Until he has to play herowhen thugs try to rob his diner and threaten to kill people he takes the law into his own hands and does it suprisingly well.After he has shot the two thugs, he becomes a local hero. But there are consequences, of his new found fame. Seems like a mobster thinks he recognizes Tom (Viggo's character) to be someone else. The suspense in trying to figure out who Tom really is is thrilling and very Hitchcokian. Maria Bellodeserves an Oscar nod for her role as a frustrated loving wife,who all of a sudden doesn't know who her husband of 20 years is.Great performances by all. Viggo Mortensen, Ed Harris and even asmall delicious part for William Hurt.
summary: History Of Violence/ A Cronenberg masterpiece

reviewText: I was asked by someone who had not yet seen this film if it contained a lot of violence.  "Yes, in many scenes, in which it takes various forms," I answered.  The next question was: "Is it difficult to watch?" And my answer to that question goes to the core of what this film is about: "It depends upon which scene."If you thought you had a clear, defineable, unambiguous attitude toward violence, this film will make you guess again.Quite a learning experience, this film is.It is not to be missed.
summary: Previously unknown mixed emotions toward violence

reviewText: The bargain-rack movie for last night was"A History of Violence" starring Viggo Mortensen and Maria Bello. Of course, the movie lived up to it's name here and there, and in some very graphic ways. Well, you were warned and there was the R rating. It was quite a good movie that demanded a certain amount of mayhem. Mortensen played a small-town restaurant owner and family man who strongly and abruptly put down a couple would-be robbers and received a lot of acclaim via the press and television news media, although he was quite modest about his heroic act. However, his bravado act attracted the attention of the Philadelphia mob who came to investigate whether or not he was "Joey," a prime long-lost target on their hit list. After about a third of the movie devoted to tensely examining the mob's questions, it turns out that he indeed was Joey. Confrontations follow along with a great deal of domestic unrest as this little secret was now out in the open. It was an interesting confrontation pitting family values against one another in a somewhat unusual way.The movie was well done. I noted a few lapses in the story, but they were minor. The acting was excellent. The characters were believable, for the most part. The photography and sound were good. The pace never allowed boredom to set in. It was a well done, somewhat suspenseful movie that never lagged and kept you wondering until the end, and afterGary Peterson
summary: You Were Expecting A Tea Party?

reviewText: `A History of Violence' appears to be fairly controversial, not from a censorial perspective but an artistic one.  This comes as no surprise really, as here they've taken a fairly conventional story and presented it in an unconventional manner.  Some people, I think, have overrated the innovation of this film in terms of theme.  It's not as if no one has ever looked at the implications of violence from a more psychological perspective, and notions of whether or not it can ever be left behind.  In many ways this is simply `Unforgiven' set in a modern age.  What really makes this film so intriguing is how it approaches the situation in such a calm, everyday fashion.  Though you can doubtless point out many implausibilities in this film, there's no denying that, for me, this film has a sense of reality to it which is far greater than I've felt in  any other thriller I've seen.  This is, no doubt, why so many people dislike the film, as it is has a strange, ambling rhythm to it, and at the end it'll probably seem like not all that much has actually happened in the film.  I think this method works however, and helps to create a rather unique film.  That, and it is all just exquisitely crafted and well-acted.  Definitely one of the best films of 2005.David Cronenberg has almost always worked with characters that were outsiders if not outright freaks, and as an extension of this I think his films have generally felt kind of cold and distant.  Of the films of his that I've seen I think `A History of Violence' has by far the strongest human element.  We don't get to know these characters entirely, indeed one major point of the film is that they don't really know themselves, but I felt for them in a way that I never did for any of his other characters.  Cronenberg's films usually had enough interesting ideas to make them worthwhile anyway, but the human element elevates `A History of Violence', and makes it his best film.  (I'd put it ahead of `Videodrome' followed by `The Dead Zone', if anyone cares.The film opens, after the violent prologue, with a look at the everyday life of one Tom Stall in a small Indiana town.  His life, and the life of his family, is so ordinary and average that it almost verges on parody:  He works in a small diner, picking up litter outside the front door just prior to opening it; he consoles his daughter after she has a nightmare; his son, Jack, has problems with bullies and just sits around main street, watching the cars cruise back and forth etc.  The calm is interrupted late one night when a couple of murderous thieves come into the dinner, clearly planning on robbing the place and killing everyone inside.  Tom acts quickly and dispatches the thieves, and becomes a media sensation.  Trouble is, this attracts the attention of some ominous easterners, mafia types who claim to know that Tom isn't who he says he is, and that they have unfinished business.  And then things get really bad.Again, the film is unusual because it doesn't have a traditional plot arc: After the first major encounter the film doesn't slowly build, but rather intermixes significant encounters with the everyday lives of the Stalls.  These characters do not seem to be in a movie; these things begin to happen to them, but their life doesn't just stop, they move on and on, at least until it becomes impossible to do so.  The film refuses to show it's cards:  One day Tom sees the gangsters car drive away from his diner, and alerts his wife rushes home to find that nothing has happened at all.  Conversely, the second major incident appears out of nowhere quite spontaneously, as does the final confrontation, Tom's apparently having decided that he simply can't run anymore, and must go face his past.The acting is uniformly excellent.  Viggo Mortensen is very good as Tom, exuding a small-town charm and simplicity that is utterly believable.  Maria Bello is even better as his wife, and should've been nominated for an Oscar.  She's got the most flashy role, as her performance is a veritable emotional roller coaster, but she makes it all fly.  I also particularly like Ed Harris as Fogarty, the scarred leader of the gangsters who come to town.  He's deliciously ominous and evil, yet you can't help but like him a little.  William Hurt is also good as the big boss behind it all, though I've gotta wonder about his Oscar nomination.  He definitely plays the role very nicely, but I'm not sure it's substantiative enough to even deserve nomination as a supporting role.  But whatever, he's certainly good which is all that really matter.Though this film isn't a conventional thriller it's still got quite a bit of killing which is nicely done.  The action scenes are sudden, both elegant and sloppy and really very gruesome much of the time.  I've seen plenty of horror films, I've seen a lotta gore, but this film allows a sort of intensity to the violence which is rarely matched else where, such as when we catch a glimpse of one thug whose face has been shredded by a bullet coming down through the back of his head, and another who has his nose shattered and driven up through his brain, limbs still trembling.  Needless to say, this film is not for the squeamish.The movie comes to a satisfyingly intense climax where all if finally revealed, but it ends on an ambiguous note.  This will doubtless disappoint some, and I've always felt that excess ambiguity is an easy way to appear provocative or intelligent, but I think it works here.  The film offers no cheap answers, and doesn't seem to be saying that 'You the audience must decide what happens next' but rather, 'I don't know where it goes from here.'  Besides, after all that has happened, what more is there to say?Grade: A

reviewText: David Cronenberg in his most mainstream film gives us the adaptation of the graphic novel of the same name.This film questions on the how far you will go to use violence to protect your family and how deep its connection with all of us.As we all know its human nature.The film is fairly close to the graphic novel with minor little differences like for example names have been changed,also the town's name plus there are a couple of sex scenes that are not in the book.As the film starts we meet two bad guys in the middle of nowhere that cause the whole plot to unravel for Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) and his lawyer wife (Maria Bello) and his two kids Jack (Ashton Holmes) and Sarah (Heidi Hayes).While the two men are on the way to the small Indiana town that Tom lives.We see how life is in a small town and for Stall family.Its quiet, no fuss and hassels.Everyone knows everyone its most of the time a nice and quiet to live.While Tom and Eddie are ending a night in their diner that they own the two bad guys we saw in the start arrive.As they attempt to rob the place and threaten the people inside Tom in self defense kills both of them and saves the day.Now the hero,the event is all over the news.This as a event brings attention to mobster Fogarty.He believes Tom is a guy called Joey that he new from Philadelphia.This endangers the whole family.As Fogarty kind of stalks the family for Tom to reveal truth of who he really is.Is he Joey with Mafia connections or really Tom and its just a minor misunderstanding.Every great film needs a great cast.Viggo Mortensen as Tom is one of his best roles yet.As a family man,husband and somewhat violent man Viggo is just great.Maria Bello in a great performance that will get her a Oscar nomination and already a Golden Globe nomination.Ed Harris is very good at playing the mean and stalking Fogarty.And last William Hurt.His part not that big,but its one of those performances that you just cant forget.He might get a nomination for a Oscar but its still not for sure.This film asks the questions of what kind of history of violence do we have or anybody else has.Do you really know a another person.What person he truly is.And where is the limit of using violence to survive.And to protect those closes to you.And you can go also to the Darwinian sense the survival of the fittest.Also I cant forget even though that this film is Cronenberg's most mainstream film this does have Cronenberg touches everywhere.From the blood that has his touches for being quick,unexpected and disgusting for some people but its needed.And how he deals with characters to the fullest so we can understand them and feel in danger with them.Also the sex scenes in the film are needed to show the connection between the character's and their love and trust that they have.On the DVD the film will be presented in 1.85:1 anamorphic widescreen,with both a English Dolby Digital 5.1 and DTS 5.1 tracks.Extras will include a feature commentary by director David Cronenberg,a deleted scene with commentary by director David Cronenberg, a documentary called Acts of Violence and a Violence's History: United States Version vs. International Version featurette.Ending the special features will be an Unmaking of Scene 44 featurette, a Too Commercial for Cannes featurette, and a theatrical trailer for the film.This is one of the best films of 2005.Almost on every list of the top ten films of 2005 by critics and already nominated for many awards.This is one of Cronenberg's best films next to The Fly as his best in my opinion.Plus this a New Line Platinum Edition that tells you one thing that this DVD is going to be worth the buck.
summary: Tom Stall had the perfect life... until he became a hero.

reviewText: A History of Violence is almost the kind of film that Warner Brothers made in the 1930's and 1940's with James Cagney and Edward G. Robinson.Almost. Those films didn't have the nudity, the gore, or the language in this film. And I'm not passing judgment on those aspects either.This is a really good film. It's a character driven story that introduces us to a devoted family man, his loving wife and children. It then sets that reality on end when he becomes a hero and unwittingly sets in motion events from which no one can return the same.Filled with dynamite actors (Mortensen, Bello, Hurt, and the venerable Harris), A History of Violence fairly crackles with energy. And the director? Who'd have thought? David Cronenberg.Cronenberg, best known for weird and creepy horror style films delivers a one two punch with some of the best filmmaking in years. Though many of us have thought him a talented director, the Hollywood elite have now been forced to countenance that as well.I don't want to give away the storyline as that's what makes this film so darned good.Suffice it to say, you'll enjoy this film over and over.
summary: Edge of your seat character driven film

reviewText: If you're planning to watch this, don't expect high octane violence like Kill Bill.  There are a couple gruesome scenes accentuated by make-up and prosthetics, but they are quick and not enough to make you cringe or jump out of your seat. The DVD extras attempt to explain that the movie was trying to highlight how violence is reenforced and widely accepted in America, but there is no indication of this at all. This is purely a character drama with a few violent scenes.At it's basic core, this story is about a small town family who has to come to grips with a member's checkered past.  I give Viggo props for playing the part of a man who hid his past so well that even he believed in his new identity, but the gentle side of his character seemed a little too gentle.What had long been talked about in the media was the explicit and violent sex scene between Viggo and Maria Bello's character.  It's not that way at all.  There was some slapping, and pushing, but it was more hungry agressive sex between a husband and wife than so called "gangster sex" as the director proclaimed.Worth maybe one rental, but that's about it.  Otherwise, I would pass on this one.

reviewText: David Cronenberg has a style with his films that is unmistakable: he is unafraid to address the darker aspects that lie within us all.  That he pushes this idea over the limits of viewable film is reflected in some of his popular films such as 'Dead Ringers', 'The Fly', 'Spider', 'eXistenZ', 'Naked Lunch' etc.  Yet despite his apparent love of gore he drives home a point that should be considered.  Most of the time he works with a good script.  For A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE he is hampered by one of the most pedestrian, hackneyed, adolescent scripts trying to pass as a big time movie - Josh Olson's adaptation of the grisly pulp novel by John Wagner and Vince Locke.Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) is introduced to us as the head of a Hallmark happy-wappy family in Indiana - with his wife Edie (Maria Bello), son Jack (Ashton Holmes) and daughter Sarah (Heidi Hayes).  Sure, Jack is harassed at school as a 'faggot' by a group of losers, but he takes it on the chin.  Tom owns a diner where everybody just loves him - until one day when a couple of thugs disturb the placid boredom of the place and end up dead at Tom's too facile hands.  Tom becomes a town hero, but the glow soon fades as big time crime enters in the guise of Fogarty (Ed Harris) plus thugs who enter the diner and confront Tom that he really is one Joey Cusack, a 'previous life' killer from Philadelphia.  Tension mounts and ultimately Tom kills the intruders only to come to grips with some realities that are threatening and unpleasant and turn his family 180 degrees against him (in one of the most absurdly written reversals of family commitment ever written) in a fraction of a second.  The rest is resolution of the Joey Cusack enigma and then the film just stops.The actors try to make this mess work but the lines they are required to murmur are just too bad to digest.  But if you like gore and battered bodies and spree killings and dark motives with secret agendas, then the film may please.  But how it got attention in the first place is a bit difficult to believe.  The accompanying featurettes on the DVD show all the secrets behind the gore and include scenes eventually deleted for good reason.  Grady Harp, March 06
summary: A Good Idea Flawed by a Thunderously Bad Script

reviewText: The graphic novel this is based on by John Wagner and Vince Locke is quite different but also very similar to the film version. The opening to this movie is one long shot with no cuts, which is very well executed and sets the tone and pace for the film, which is slow and steady but builds tension to a very cool third act. Some of the acting is hammy from the family members (which is to be expected from child actors) but Ed Harris as usual gives a great performance. I think this is an underrated movie, especially for being a "comic book movie". The Blu-Ray transfer is clean and sharp, nothing extraordinary though. If you like action movies that have a bit more story than the typical 1980's kind of action film and does a good job setting mood and atmosphere and tension, you should watch this movie.

reviewText: David Cronenberg one of my favorite horror directors of all time has struck gold once again, this time showing that he can a lot more than sci-fi and horror. This time he chooses to makea violent, but powerful acted and character driven movie called "A History of Violence"."A History of Violence" has a very familiar storyline that some ignorant audience members might use an excuse to not see the movie, but boy would they be missing out on a great movie!!!!Yes the story is nothing new in today's time, a guy living the normal life has a past that he doesn't want to reveal and has been hiding. Then during one instance, in a life or death situation, his identiy is revealed.The story then has Viggo Mortensen (in perhaps his best role since the Lord of the Ring movies) as Tom  Stall who is the owner of a small restaurant/coffee shop. He and his wife both work side by side. He has two great kids, one daughter and older son. He has everything a guy could want then one day, a group of lowlifes try to rape an employee and thus he springs to action. Like a hired killer, Tom disposes of these trash quite easily. He is labeled in the media as hero, and while Tom enjoys this and thinks none of it, an old friend is watching.Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris, who is equally great in this movie) comes looking for Tom. His wife Edie Stahl and Tom don't recognize him. Carl eventually tells us all about Tom's ratherelusive history. It seems that the guys Tom wasted are aligned to the mafia, and that Carl is their "main" guy.Carl thinks Tom is actually some guy named Joey from his crew. Of course Tom doesn't recall him or so we think. Not going to spoil the end for you people but what I can say is that "A History of Violence" much like "The Constant Gardener" is another memorable film from 2005A very good film and for Cronenberg, man this is quite an accomplishment. Most ignorant critics will say wow what a breakthrough!!!! But really there are some Cronenberg traitsin this movie like his other ones. For one the characters are pretty darn likable, the characters are real and gritty, there are some violent imagery that pushes the film to present us very discussionable moral themes at the end, and the best part is that is it very well acted.This is a great Cronenberg flick, it shows to those snobby critics that he can do a lot more than horror, but I've always known that every one of Crony's film has good drama, and character development.See this movie now!!!
summary: David Cronenberg does it again with this good movie!!!

reviewText: This movie as a metaphor of American society is to the art of cinema what a Miles Davis or John Coltrane composition is to music, or a Kaiga painting is to Japanese art, or an unexpected winning Bobby Fischer or Bent Larsen move is to chess. Its very power lies in the utter subtlety and understatement of its intrusive imaginative truths, and in the skill and necessity with which these truths are forced out into the open and acted out as an unerring narrative (or drama) about what lies underneath the human and the American condition. And what lies beneath it is the manifold terror of violence -- which is an enduring, ugly, almost inexorable existential subtext and leitmotif of the human - and especially of the American way of life.There is no longer a need to get excited about violence in the U.S., for in its many and various sublimated forms it is to be found everywhere. We are trained not to see it but it is always there: in our national bloodstream, in our collective DNA, in our fantasies, in our passive-aggressive natures. All of its multi-layered, multidimensional, and hydra-headed components emerge and intersect in subtle ways in this movie. It is in our past, in our present, and sure to be in our future. It is the grim reaper of American society. The movie shows how violence stalks us from every dark corner of our consciousness. First it is far away and buried deep in our past; then it is close up, intimate, and then from out of nowhere it is suddenly "in our faces." It is in our homes, our cities and on our farms. There is no way to insulate ourselves from it, or hide from it. Indeed it is within us; it oozes from our skins. It is in our children heads. As domestic terrorists and meth-amphetamine labs, it is in our pastoral rural communities too.With uncommon skill, depth and subtlety, this movie demonstrates that in the U.S., no one is ever far away from either the next "staged" or the next "random act" of violence. Our lives are centered on and shaped not by what we pretend is the main problem, "violence in the streets", but on how to avoid the structural violence implicit in the very American condition: The movie makes clear that the center of gravity of violence in our society is the passive aggressive violence closer to home in our own minds. Our conscious lives are no longer regulated by or animated by violent acts per se, but by how best to pretend there is no violence inherent in the American condition. And that, to the extent we are willing to admit to this at all, that we are animated by the lie that its cumulative historical impact on us, that is on who we are, and on our way of thinking and acting, and on our community as a whole, has nothing at all to do with how violent our society is, has become, and has always been. That is to say, it is about the continuing lie that past violence has no present day consequences.We keep telling ourselves in so many different ways that all of this homegrown American violence is external to the American condition: that it has nothing to do with America's ugly accumulated history of violence. All these images of America being a violent land, is just so much anti-American propaganda working overtime. This image of us as being a violent nation is a mirage, a figmentation of overly active and fertile imaginations, a pure anomaly, an aberration completely alien to, and having nothing to do with the American condition. Yet, each morning, we cannot trust our own neighbors enough not to walk our kids to the corner school bus stop. To do otherwise is to risk the chance that they will be abducted, raped and murdered by the nearest local sexual predator. And oddly enough, the statistics bare us out on taking this profoundly prudent defensive measure.As the movie underscores, every American instinct is an instinct whistling pass our own self-made graveyard, with one foot in a camp of colossal collective denial about how violence has not colonized our very existence; and the other attributing what violence there is to safe acceptable but far away targets -- "distanced" so that they do not contaminate our pristine thoughts of ourselves. It does not matter much that the character "Joey" or "Tom Stall" (superbly played by Viggo Mortensen), had a violent past, for as Americans, we all know that we too all also have a collective violent past, the one defined by the trail of violence left in the wake of our nation's violent history. To wit:There is the unspeakable and psychologically still unresolved genocide against Native Americans, slavery and the still unresolved century of violence against the Negro (a half century of Apartheid and segregation, Jim Crow and lynching, and now voluntary re-segregation) that still shapes and animates the social lives of all Americans; a Civil War that the South lost on the battlefield but actually won in the hearts and minds of most white Americans, and which is still being fought just beneath the American consciousness, labor and race riots from the early 1800s forwards; two world wars, and a series of lesser ones -- from Vietnam to Panama and Grenada, and now on to Afghanistan and Iraq -- and the wars within the organized crime underworld that have become a signature of the American way of life.Then there are the perpetual, unending wars: wars on drugs, on terror and on the poor, that is the class and culture wars; and of course within them, the war against abortions, the war between the rice and the poor, and always, the wars against the Jews and the Zionists. And then there is the war of the corporations against the rest of us - especially the oil and drug companies - not to mention just plain raw violence as in "domestic in-the-home-violence," continued racial violence, prison violence, and an annual crop of serial killers; street crime -- dope, whores, drive-by shootings, gang revenge, 7/11 stick-ups, mob violence and cop killings - an epidemic of sexual predators, killers and abductors, school, job and restaurants mass killings, and political assassinations, to name just a few.America has not only been colonized by its own homegrown history of violence, but has been shocked into a perpetual fearful defensive state of existence. It has been defined and shaped by, then numbed by, and now collectively compartmentalized by, its casual ability to accept its own homegrown violence. Today, any political demagogue who can make 911 the predicate of a sentence, no matter how incompetent or illiterate, is surely to be elected U.S. President.But even knowing that this is our history, the movie demonstrates with disturbing skill that somehow we still have learned to live in a cocoon of self-imposed denial, a virtual mental Potemkin village. We have trained ourselves to compartmentalize as Edie (Maria Bello) who played the role of "Joey's" wife, was forced to do. And thus we have become numb to the pervasiveness of the violence that is an integral part of us, and our ethos. As a nation, we have crawled into the fetal position, waiting to be rescued from ourselves by some imaginary moral hero. It seems we have no choice but to endure, deny and accept our lot; and then try to live through the denial of the knowledge that we have created the very incubator for our own self-destructive and violent society.The great irony of U.S. society, which this movie draws out in the only way good art is supposed to do -- with great subtlety and understatement - is that we only become animated; act surprised; we only react when violence shows up uninvited (that is unforced from the subconscious) at the dinner table of a well-adjusted, white, suburban, middle-class, Middle American family. For instance, as the BTK killer did at the geographic center of America, Kansas, where not coincidentally the movie was situated. Or, as Ted Kaczynski did at the idyllic foothills of the Montana mountains. Or indeed as Timothy Mc Veigh did in the bombing of the Murrah Building "in out-of-the-way" Oklahoma City.) Otherwise "the violence that we see and (that we are)" ceases to be real to us.After this subtle, understated, David Cronenberg movie, "The History of Violence," we no longer have the comfort zone of taking the national fetal position and waiting to be rescued. For those with the courage to see it, he has shaken and disturbed this nation's conscience to it very core. His art reverberated deep inside the brain. It is a scary truth that sticks there. It cannot be easily expelled, ejected or excommunicated.The very act of raising this hidden truth openly -- especially about the cumulative violence of the past - will undoubtedly be seen, by those willing to see, as an unpatriotic betrayal of the highest order. Put simply, to admit to ourselves that our society rests on an edifice of violence, structural and otherwise that is then covered up by denials and lies; is to admit that violence is the only true and enduring constant in the American way of life. This, in the end, is an intolerable truth and an almost unbearable betrayal of the deepest held national unconscious secret.  Yet it is a truth from which we can no longer recoil, shrink and then hide.  It takes, not just an extraordinary artist, but a great artist, to be able to drill this message back into the brain-dead and morally challenged American conscience as David Cronenberg has done. One does not get hit with the full force of the message until long after he has left the theater: and then boom, like a ton of bricks you are shaken forever!That important truths such as this, "that the psychological impact accumulated violence has had on the American psyche" can only be told through the most sophisticated and carefully coded art forms, shows in devastating relief how fragile the American way of life has become. Teetering as it does on a thin precipice of proto-Fascist political maneuverings and rumblings, self-styled hero worshipping, and on a thick veneer of pretend humanity, all of which is backup by state and societally-sanctioned violence or the threat of violence at every level, we are a nation rapidly spinning out of control and down into the vortex of full-scale Fascist-like tyranny.Fear, but especially the fear of violence, is forcing us to eat our young, and to consume our own democratic institutions. From the purse-snatching ghetto thugs, to organized crime, to intimidation by crooked street cops, their rent-a-cop auxiliaries and security mercenaries, to sexual predators, and inner city gang violence, to law enforcement officers that are supposed to defend us -- such as the IRS, CIA, DIA, FBI, Homeland Security, etc. -- by home-grown criminals and terrorists, and ultimately by the American military, we are slowly and almost imperceptively becoming the police state we keep telling ourselves we are not. Strangely all of these agencies mandated to defend us from violence against ourselves, are more and more beginning to look suspiciously like Nazis in Halloween masks, salivating while anxiously awaiting with their attack dogs, high voltage tasers, hollow-point bullets and automatic weapons for the last democratic restraints to be stripped away.This movie captures the full essence of the impact violence has had on contemporary American history both as it is played out "one random act at a time," and as its accumulates, and is encapsulated as systemic and structural violence over an embarrassingly long period of time. And it does so in a way that is so subtle, so deep, so stunning, so honest, so original, so moving, and so economical that it staggers the imagination into silence.If there is a better American movie in history, I have not yet seen it.Fifty stars!
summary: An artistic triumph of monumental proportions: An astounding work of Art rarely achieved in the American cinema.

reviewText: Directed by David Cronenberg and starring Viggo Mortensen (Tom Stall), Maria Bello (Edie Stall), Ed Harris (Carl Forgerty) and a cameo performance by William Hurt (Richie Cusack), "A History of Violence" is as good as this kind of movie gets. Tom Stall, a mild-mannered family man with a wife and two children, runs a small diner in a small Midwestern town. His peaceful life is changed forever when he becomes a local and national hero after taking out two goons who try to rob him at gunpoint. Even if one had not seen the trailers for this movie previously, he would be suspicious of the shooting prowess of Stall. He and his family are soon visited by Carl Forgerty and company who accuse him of being someone else, Joey Cusack of Chicago. Much of the plot is predictable from this point forward as Stall has to deal with his past that he thought was buried forever. There is enough murder and gore to satisfy the most blood-thirsty of viewers. On the other hand, the film rises above the typical blood-and-guts crime movie as there are nice twists in the plot and the Stall family members to a person are real people that we care about, including the angelic daughter (Heidi Holmes) and her teenaged brother (Ashton Holmes) who has his own violent streak to contend with. The ending is really quite moving.There is some terrific acting here by Viggo Mortensen, Maria Bello and Ed Harris and the small but dynamite performance by Willaim Hurt as Tom/Joey's brother Richie. If I had to describe the film in one word it would be "chilling."
summary: As Good As This Kind of Movie Gets

reviewText: I finally got to see this wonderful masterpiece and absolutely adored it. It blew away my already very high expectations. Yet even as I left the theater and thought about this wonderful movie, I heard people saying that it sucked horribly. I am afraid that a lot of people will feel that way. Why? Becauseit progresses very slowly and therefore is relaistic. The characters might stare at each other for 5 minutes straight because mr. Croenberg wanted to make a realistic movie. All of the violence is incredibly realistic and very gruesome.The movie is about family man Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen), a bartender in a small town in Indiana who has a beautiful wife (Maria Bello) and a little girl and an older boy. The movie at first shows how well this family gets along and how much they love each other. But, that quickly changes during one seemingly ordinary night at the bar. Two very aggressive men walk into the bar and threathen everyone in it with guns. When one of them is about to kill a waitress, Tom reacts with feline instincts, taking out the two men. He is pronounced a hero and is followed around by countless reporters. Yet, he is strangely weird about it. When a man comes into town addressing Tom by Joey and calling him someone he really isn't..right?What follows is a remarquable film with very sad moments but that also has very funny moments. I got attached to the characters and supported them. The cast is brilliant with Viggo Mortensen and Maria Bello great and with supporting actors Ed Harris and William Hurt FANTASTIC! These two actors add so much to the movie notably Hurt in the end who delivers great dark humor.The movie also has two sex scenes which are actually important to the movie. The first is sweet, lovable, and humorous but the second is brutal and savage showing an abrupt transformation in the relationship between the couple. Yet, I do have a regret that these scenes went on for that long. That was unnecessary and movies lately have been getting too sexual. And the one scene where Tom's wife comes out of the shower, full front naked, what was that about. Nevertheless, movies this good don't come along that often.A history of violence is probably the best movie that I have ever seen because it made me think, and allowed me to connect with characters and witness wonderful acting. This movie is vastly superior to any movie this year and it better win best picture.
summary: A marvelous movie...the best of the year

reviewText: David Cronenberg explores the outer edges of humanity (e.g., Scanners) and reality (e.g., Naked Lunch; Dead Ringers) in his movies, and continues his practice here.  Sometimes his efforts are stupendously successful, and sometimes they fall flat.  This one is definitely in the "successful" end of the spectrum.  As much as a two-hour movie can, it addresses such questions as:*  Can you escape or change your nature?(Answer: yes, because Viggo Mortensen's Tom Stall's past and past nature would never have come to light but for coincidence.)*  What is the extent of forgiveness?(Answer: quite broad.)*  What would you do to protect your family?(Answer: anything.)*  How should we confront evil?(Answer: reluctantly but without hesitation, without mercy, and without a second thought.)I suppose I especially liked the film because by and large I agree with Mr. Cronenberg's answers.  I cannot condemn those who give the film only one or two stars however, because there is some merit to their complaints.  The movie is not without its flaws, foremost in my opinion being the cliched view of small-town life that Cronenberg imagines.My recommendation: buy or rent the DVD if you're interested in the questions Cronenberg answers, and you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: The redemption sometimes implies to clean up the mess of a dark past. An abnegate father of family will receive the unexpected visit of some guys of the underworld who identify with another name.The story is clearly exposed in three movements; in the first we will witnesses the existential parallelism between his violent response to the first sudden incursion in his grocery and the way his own son reacts against the violence of  a teenager who really disturbs him twice before the hidden rage; the second movement is the unmasking fact about his real identity before his wife and his son  and finally the conclusion, the final solution.The progressive psychological deconstruction and psychological reconstruction obeys to a necessity of self redemption. Original treatment of David Cronenberg, whose stylistic approaches respect the dark corners of the human behavior, makes of him the closest filmmaker to David Lynch. A solid script supported by excellent performances, although I must admit William Hurt (this unexplainably underestimated actor) stole the show in the last fifteen minutes of the story.Totally recommended
summary: The violence as vehicle of redemption!

reviewText: A Very well done action thriller with an actual plot and characters they took the time to develop. There is a lot of violence, so if you don't like that in a film, stay away. Then again, if you take a look, don't complain, you watched a movie named: The History Of Violence!The 'hero' of the story is so effectively portrayed as a simple, family man, with a loving family, that when the story unfolds, when things start to unravel, its something of a shock.You see it coming, and still you feel the family's devestation upon learning that "Dad" is not all he appears to be. Or maybe he's a lot more than he appears to be.Some great witty dialogue at points, it never has a slow moment really. Not a great classic, just a good solid movie that thoroughly entertains.

reviewText: When Tom Stall (Viggo Mortenson) is threatened by two killers in his diner, he reacts in a way that surprises and thrills his neighbors.  Taking both men down makes him a hero to the small Indiana town in which he lives and to the news media nationwide.  Wounded in the action, he recovers by going back to his life and downplaying what he did.  But a history of violence can't be ignored forever.Carl Fogarty and two men arrive from Philadelphia accusing Tom of being Joey Cusack, the man who took Carl's eye over a decade before.  Tom denies it, but Carl will not be denied.  He threatens Tom's children and wife and this Tom cannot allow.  That situation dealt with, and before anything can even gain a semblance of the old normality, Joey's brother Richie calls from Philly, inviting Joey to come see him.  His motive isn't brotherly love.As things went from bad to worse, Tom's wife Maria Bello doubts him, his teenage son rebels, and the sheriff wants to know the truth.  Tom continues being his gentle self, telling Edie that Joey has been dead for a long time.SPOILER:  The remarkable thing about this story and Mortenson's performance is the fine but hard line drawn between Tom and Joey.  Try as Tom might to remain the small-town husband and father and businessman, when the need arrives to protect himself and his family, Joey Cusack is willing and able to do whatever is necessary.  Writing, direction, and performances are all topnotch and the personal agony of the Stalls family is there for all to see.  Only this view is the gentler, kinder one.

reviewText: This movie is a series of plot switches, pointless sex scenes, unsympathetic characters that doesn't have an ending. Don't worry about any spoilers in this review because you'll thank me for avoiding this pseudo intellectual, pompous, disjointed yarn of uninteresting fodder.Opening scene: boring. No, it doesn't build to anything accept a child being shot which you don't see. Two bad guys rob a motel and kill the desk clerks. No action, you don't see anything and there's no reason to fill in the blanks because even though you think this movie will be about Tom Stall defending the town against these bad guys, wrong, because they both die 10 minutes later. Switch to plot "B"...Stall's Diner where the bad guys show up. Will our hero defend his store with a climactic shoot'em up in act three? No. Bang, bang, they're dead and it's over with deadly expertise. Is our central character a sympathetic secret agent trying to retire to a new life? A member of the witness protection program, hiding, trying to protect his wife and two lovely children? Someone we can at least like? Someone we can root for? No, no, no because he continues to lie about his true identity to the entire town including his wife and family, nice guy. Don't like him already. Switch to plot "C"...So now the mob from Philadelphia shows up having seen Tom Stall on the news from his heroic actions and IDs him as a mob enforcer from Philly. Ed Harris as Carl Fogarty is lame as the bad guy with the bogus eye. So THIS is the new plot. Tom Stall battles these mob guys defending his wife and family to the bitter end in act three. No...10 minutes later Stall kills two of them, the third dieing at the hands of Stalls' son Jack played by Ashton Holmes. The same son who originally appeared so mild and meek, then just pounded the living crap out of a school bully like he just turned on the kill switch. Switch to plot "C"...Ah ha, the REAL plot. Does the apple fall far from the tree? Even though Tom was and still is at heart an unapologetic mob enforcer, has he passed those traits reluctantly on to his unsuspecting son? Is there any hope to prevent the son from revisiting the sins of the father? He seemed like such a nice boy at the beginning of the film. Wait, before we deal with that, let's have a pointless sex scene on the steps between Tom and his wife Edie who has finally come to he realization that Tom isn't the man she married and her life's been a lie but what the heck, bang, bang, bang, let's do it on the stairs! This is of course after the pointless and boring sex scene in the beginning of the movie with Edie dressed up as a cheerleader. Whatever. Oh my God, a husband and wife having sex. Ah now I understand everything now. Bad guys kill people. Shocking. Whatever. Now let's get back to the son's issues... too late. Switch to plot "D"...But Wait! It's Richie Cusack, Tom's brother who Tom screwed over in Philly calling inviting Tom back for a powwow and off Tom goes without concern his for family who he's been valiantly protecting throughout the movie or even a reason for his departure. At this point, why anyone would care remotely about Tom and what happens to him is simply beyond me. The guy has been lying to his family and delivering some serious pain, murder and mayhem though the last 70 minutes of the movie in little vignettes of stylized violence in a sea of disjointed crap.So we're getting close to the end now. Tom shows up at his brother's place, they talk and Richie tries to have his goons take out Tom(no surprise). Bad idea as Tom cleans up the place with the hired help then blows the back of his brother's head off. How William Hurt gets nominated for his performance for anything but a Golden Raspberry is beyond me. What an uneven, unbelievable, unspectacular performance in his 5-7 minutes of screen time. He would have made a better career move by appearing in "Lost In Space II: Danger, Will Hurt! Danger!"So Tom, returns home to his family at the diner table, his life turned upside down, which you don't really care about the guy anyway. He sits down at the table and no one speaks to him. The End. And this is not a Dustin Hoffman/Katherine Ross in the back of the bus in 'The Graduate' "What have we done" end, no, just the end, whatever.I don't know what kind of political/moral agenda driven crap David Cronenberg and Viggo Mortensen had in mind here because this movie is simply uninteresting and doesn't really make any sense. And don't think for a second that you're not part of the intellectual entertainment illuminati and just missing the point. No, this movie is just crap. I wish I had my $3.89 back from the video store and in my pocket, but I don't. Crap.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A languid opening sequence reveals portents of violence. The initial counterpoint is an idyllic family life; love permeating wife, husband and two children. The first episode of violence is understated yet explicit in result. In time, the shadow of `organised crime' casts its ugly and at that moment, potentially brutal shadow over the family and its little diner. The next violent episodes are emotionally surprising. The plot thickens. There is a very powerful love-making scene. The power is from both sides, sequentially then simultaneously. There is a final phase of violence, like the showdown in Westerns, only a 21st century version. The film captures the principle that `less is more'. There are no explosions, car chases, crashes and mayhem; just brooding atmosphere, underlying threat and sharply focused violence. As in life, ultimately, love is the central character.Ian Hunter.Author of `e-Love'.

reviewText: What would you do if you worked so hard to conceal a questionable past and it was all shot to hell in one brief moment? That pretty much is the situation at hand in A History of Violence. Tom Stall seems like a average guy. Ya know, kids, hot wife(okay that's not too average, but you get me right?), and a small local business in a small town. One day, some shady characters pop into his diner and start some stuff. Tom naturally saves the day and becomes a local hero. This, however, brings up some people from his past and that ain't good. I don't spoil movies for people, so thats all I'm gonna give you as far as plot. This movie is great. Most people are saying that they don't get it. There is really nothing to get. It basically is showing you what extremes a person would go through to protect his loved ones. The title is appropriate as this is a violent movie. But not long, over the top violent. This is perhaps the most realistic portrayal of violence I've seen in a long time. Quick and brutal. After all, who has honestly been in a 15-30 minute fight? Great acting, great story, great movie. As I said, it is brutal so be prepared to see some nastiness. But, Dammit!! I liked it.

reviewText: Is this a thriller? Last time I checked thrillers were supposed to be exciting and keep you on the edge of your seat..Tom Stall (Mortensen) is an average man married to they lovely Edie (Bello), father of two, working at a diner in a peaceful small town. One day two bandits passing through decide to rob Tom's diner, but their plan backfires as Tom kills them both and becomes hero overnight. Then enters Carl Fogerty (Harris); a mob guy who is convinced Tom Stall is in fact Joey from Philadelphia (an organized killer). He won't take no for an answer..The movie begins with a dry scene where the bandits have just made a stop somewhere, then followed by an awkward sex scene between Tom and his wife. Things pick up quickly when the bandits enter the diner and things start to happen. The idea is original. Mortensen and Bello do a convincing job (Bello seems like she's cut out for the thriller genre). In between there's scenes with their son being bullied at school and you're wondering where the movie was going with that.It's a good movie for about an hour. After that it seems like the creativity ended (and you will know what I'm talking about when you see it - and if you do; told you so).

reviewText: Cronenberg does excellent work in this film whose title is ambiguious as the dynamics of his main character played with just the right tenor by Viggo Mortensen.  This film is a meditation on the things we hide inside us--either our true histories or our fantasies--that can come back to haunt us, and, depending on the way we've been able to put all the threads of our life together, can either overwhelm us or, if we have the ability, return to the fabric of our lives so that we can find some form of inner peace.  Based on a graphic novel, Cronenberg is able to make the transition to a realistic film that contains marginal and scary believable characters, played well by among others, Ed Harris and William Hurt.  Every sceneand every shot in the movie contributes to the overall effect and theme.  Like any excellent film, this one is excellent for many reasons: direction, acting, art direction, cinematography, etc. Also, listen to the articulate commentary by Cronenberg on the DVD, who delivers the entire thing alone--providing a purposeful and reasoned analysis of a visceral movie.
summary: Feature film production values, independent film smarts

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: This Cronenberg film is unescapable in its logic. The rhythm is always extremely slow, nearly realistic, and accelerations are rare and always motivated by some moment of violent explosion. Violence itself is shown so coldly that it becomes some kind of simple and ordinary action hardly different from having cornflakes for breakfast. But the really original dimension of the film is the fact that Cronenberg is not telling us a story but is speaking of the History of violence in a family, in society. The two brothers share the great propensity to use violence. Normal, they are brothers. One tries to evade this violent History but he can't. Sooner or later he goes back to it. Violence is never forgotten, lost. Circumstances will take care of that. Worse, the son of one of these brothers is depicted as a non-violent person and yet one day he will know, without any initiation, how to beat up and defeat three bullies who are quite bigger than he is and a lot more trained in the field. He will naturally know how to do it... naturally, it will come from his History, his genes in other words. This is extremely pessimistic about humanity, and yet... What is difficult to swallow is that there is no improvement possible, no reformation possible. Civilization becomes then only some kind of varnish on top of the mess and an enormous make-believe lie.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, Université Paris Dauphine, Université Paris I Panthéon Sorbonne

reviewText: With a cover that looks like the cheaply designed ones you find in a $2 dollar store, in fact I originally thought this was a documentary on violence throughout cinematic history of something, I didn't have high expectations for this one.  But I'm glad I picked it up.  Basically the plot revolves around Tom, a small town diner owner, who obviously cares about the appearance of his town (he picks up rubbish in the street) and the people who live there.  He's got a nice wife, a young daughter and a teenage son, a perfect family life if you will.  Then one day a couple of thugs walk into his diner when it is closing and demand service.  We viewers from a previous scene know these guys aren't there to eat and its not long before the other diners also work out theirs lives are probably going to end shortly.  But these violent killer thugs picked the wrong diner.  Now Tom's a reluctant celebrity, but his experience with violence doesn't look to be over when a disfigured man and his entourage enter the diner and insist his name is Joey.  Tom of course tells them their mistaken, but these mob guy's don't seem to think so.  Is this just a case of mistaken identity?  Was Tom someone else before he met his wife and had his kids?  What is a family to do when the mob guys just won't leave town and keep insisting Tom is Joey.This book is based on a graphic novel by John Wagner, I've never read that or any of his work but the storyline reminded me of a good Dave Zeltserman novel.  I quite liked the movie, of course you wonder why the mob guy doesn't just shoot him when he thinks he's Joey instead of playing the games he does, but we wouldn't have a movie then would we?  The DVD needed better artwork on the cover though to do this movie justice, it just looks amateur league to me that way it is.  There are some interesting special features that come with this though, showing how they filmed certain scenes, the actor who plays the school bully talks about the injuries he got while filming the locker scene, there's deleted scenes and commentary on things like how the Cannes Film Festival reacted to it.

reviewText: The legacy of vigilante justice movies like Death Wish lives on for one primary reason: we love to cheer for the everyman and we are sick of the scum never being visited by karma.  Nobody wants to see the captain of the football team bed the cheerleading captain in the back of his rich lawyer father's BMW.  Similarly, there is no desire to learn about a complete social leech preying on others and never receiving a comeuppance.  All of this is why History of Violence is so awesome.As a hard working, small business owner in Millbrook, IN, Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) is, outwardly at least, a humble American whose work ethic is the foundation on which the country succeeds and progresses.  He lives a quiet life with his wife Edie (Bello), his son Jack (Holmes), and his young daughter Sarah (Hayes).  When a few thugs with intentions of senseless violence walk into Stall's diner, the world of Millbrook changes.  Immediate media notoriety transforms Stall into an unwilling hero, putting his face on televisions nationwide, and unravels a mysterious past tied to Philadelphia organized crime.In this first pairing of director David Cronenberg and Viggo Mortensen, a combo that would later produce the awesomeEastern Promises, we are presented morality lessons in a seldom seen world that is teeming with ruthless killers.  A world where men like Carl Foggerty (Ed Harris), a scarred villain, ostensibly the scariest hitman that could be sent, are sent to tie up loose ends like those in Millbrook.  Little does anyone know, Foggerty isn't in town for revenge; he's in town for Stall...except he keeps calling Stall by the name Joey Cusack.The levels of violence in this film are deeply intertwined.  Not only is the aspect of revenge present, an idea that violence can and should be used to solve disputes (especially when confronted with a situation that restricts diplomatic approaches) but also the Darwinian "survival of the fittest" concept.  How violence begets violence, and lives are molded by the acting violently as well as being placed in a violent situation.  Mortensen is brutal as Stall, changing from mild-mannered to savage in an instant; although, the depiction of his transformation is spliced with reluctance.  With Stall's somber, conclusive act, Cronenberg gives resonance to the positive importance of family, and provides hope that a history of violence can be overcome by a recent history of love (and an entrancing bedroom scene between Viggo and Bello).This movie is critically acclaimed, full of tension, and highly recommended!Jason Elin
summary: I KNEW I should have gone to Denny's!

reviewText: David Cronenberg has made some very memorable movies, Scanners will always be one of my favorite horror movies, and he also did The Dead Zone, and The Fly 1 and 2, also very good. Even when he makes a below-average movie, such as Dead Ringers or Crash (not the 5-star Oscar winner from last year, the 1996 soft-core film) He still manages to get the actors and actresses to perform brilliantly. History of Violence is no different, although not his best work, it is so well acted, that it makes you forget about the plot holes and the silly un-necessary scenes. It's actually the supporting actors that really did it for me, Viggo Mortensen is rather bland in the lead role, I felt he should have played it with much more emotion considering the elements he was surrounded by.Let me get into the supporting cast, they are stellar, top-notch performances, with two, in my opinion, worthy of best supporting actor and actress nominations. The first is Ed Harris, this man is definitely one of the better actors in film today. and he is at his evil best here, playing Carl Fogarty, co-founder of a very evil crime family, who is trying to get to Viggo's character for some double-crossings from there past. Viggo has gone clean, playing the good hubby/dad role but when he is seen on TV after foiling an attempted robbery at his restuarant, Harris show's up wanting revenge. The chemistry and tension between Viggo and Harris is sensational. Harris has a contempt in his voice and personality that just totally made his character. I know he has played in a couple of duds, but even then, the man always delivers.The second performance that was brilliant was by Maria Bello, you talk about intensity personified, she was absolutely incredible. If you thought she was remarkable in 'The Cooler' wait 'till you see her here. She plays Viggo's wife, unaware of her husbands dark past, she desparately tries to keep her family together even though they are being pusued by Harris and his goons through many cat and mouse like games and confrontations. I really felt for her character, and the hell she endures for them is nothing short of amazing.Now, incredible acting aside, I did have a couple of issues that didn't set well with me. Although I said Viggo's acting was average, Maria Bello made me totally believe how much these two were in love, I didn't need the silly love scene with the cheerleading outfit. Don't get me wrong, Bello is hot, and kinky sex scenes are part of Cronenberg's forte', but not necessary here. Then later on in the film after she finds out Viggo was lying and they have an intense fight, the violent sex they have during this fight was not needed, in fact, it made me feel dirty, like I needed a shower or something. I have read that a few viewers had trouble with the violence saying it was too graphic and, get this, real. Huh? are you kidding me? I thought it was done very well and was valid in telling the evil nature of the business they were in.Two other strong performances are by William Hurt as Viggo's brother and head of the crime family, and surprise, surprise, he is awesome as usual. A big surprise was the acting of Ashton Holmes, who plays Viggo's son, very strong and emotional. The scenes with him laying into his dad were very heart-felt and real. So, in all a pretty good movie, but don't watch it thinking you are going to get your usual body-count hero saves the day movie. Although there are some good action scenes and some great fighting scenes, overall its very dark and disturbing. Not Cronenberg's best, but real close.acting........4.5 stars, A little more of an emotional Viggo would have garnished a 5-stardirecting......4 stars, Cronenberg has a style all his ownspecial effects....N/Aaction rating....3.5 stars, Viggo kicks a little ass, but that's about itqualty.......4 stars, No grain, nice country setting, the sex was not very, well, sexy.
summary: Not a happy movie, but very well acted...........

reviewText: A diner owner's Philly ganster past catches up with him following publicity over his heroic action during a robbery. Now Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) must make things right with his wife (Maria Bello) and son while looking over his shoulder to protect his family from mob wackers. Ed Harris and William Hurt are at their best projecting mobster sadism. Mortensen and Bello work perfectly together, especially in the steamy "gangster sex" scene on the stairs. A History of Violence has good fast-paced gun action and never becomes bogged down in unnecessary detail.This film is very good even though it lacks big production grit and things unfold too conveniently, as good continually tromps over evil; but this is not a problem since you'll always be rooting for Viggo as he fights off more than a fair share of mob low-life creatures. The BD had very good picture quality.

reviewText: Which of these words best describes David Cronenberg's A History of Violence? Shocking? No. Brutally Violent? No. Run of the Mill? No. It's funny but I really can't find that one true word that sums up A History of Violence. Cronenberg's A History of Violence is very much akin to David Lynch's The Straight Story. Much of the crucial conversation in the film is non-existent but simply relies on the intuition of the viewer to fill in the blanks. In terms of Cronenberg this is by far his most commercial piece to date, I mean this is the guy who made Scanners. In terms of violence, there is some but nothing that will stick with you.  Viggo Mortensen turns in a steller performance as Tom Stall, a small town diner owner who foils a robbery at his diner by killing the two gunmen. The film is an obvious study of violence and it's duel nature. Why is violence glorified in some situations and villified in others? The line between the two is a razor's edge and Tom Stall has walked it. Ed Harris and John Hurt turn in good but brief performances and essentially Mortensen is the whole story here. Overall, if your looking to be shocked, look elsewhere but for a good, psychological character study check out A History of Violence. Recommended.
summary: As transparent as they come but with strong performances...

reviewText: The acting is good. The sets are good. The direction is tight. The action is violent. The plot is fairly straight forward. However, after the movie is done, it makes you think. The father talks to the son about a fight the son got into at school. The father does not know the son has been bullied all year at school so the father doesn't understand. The father's own violent actions was the "occasion" for the fight. The boy, who appears to go out of his way to stay out of fights, after the diner incident, knocks two bigger classmates' heads off. Obviously, the movie has a lot to say about what we passed down to the next generation. How can a father discipline his son for fighting when his own past is so violent. Is the propensity for violence inherited?The movie also has a lot to say about identity. Is Viggo's character Tom or Joey? Who does the wife love Tom or Joey? Does she really know Joey? Joey spent more time as being Tom in his life than Joey. He just wants to return to this life of non-violence. Is identity by choice or heredity?Mortenson handles the action sequences and playing the decent man very well. Hurt has a great part later in this movie and he delivers. Ed Harris is as competent as always. The movie is very violent and has some sexual content so be warned. I enjoyed the movie and I recommend it.
summary: A simple plot that gives food for thought

reviewText: David Cronenberg's latest film may not have exploding heads or cockroach typewriters, but rest assured, the creatures are still there. The bad news is that they're inside the hero."History" is the story of Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen), who lives in a small town that's probably a lot like yours -- it definitely reminded me of where I grew up in Vermont. He lives happily with his wife Edie (Maria Bello) and his children Jack (Ashton Holmes) and Sarah (Heidi Hayes). He runs a diner surrounded by old friends, and the only unusual things about his life are the sex games his wife initiates, and the level of bullying Jack has to endure at school.This all changes when a pair of killers hold up the restaurant late one night. Tom dispatches them handily -- and mortally. His grateful friends praise him to the local news, and Tom is hailed as a hero, who modestly tries to get past all of it as soon as possible. This even inspires Jack to stand up to his bully, though in a way no one quite expected.Word continues to spread, and soon more come to visit - a group led by a scarred thug, Carl (Ed Harris), who claims that Tom is in fact someone else entirely, someone who has other obligations. It is up to Edie and Jack to decide which of Tom's lives is the true one.Much of this is familiar territory, but Mr. Cronenberg casts a fine shadow on the proceedings, especially in the first hour. The performances and storytelling are strong, evoking memories of the original "Cape Fear", another story of a family threatened by a father's past. "History" goes a step further by insinuating that the future is tainted as well, possibly beyond repair or redemption.The last half hour is less compelling. The events make sense in the scheme of the story, but the execution seems abrupt and lacking character interplay. William Hurt is especially jarring as Tom's brother Richie - his accent erratic, he seemed a poor choice for a such a coarse antagonist. Still, thought the resolution may be unsatisfying, conceptually it's quite disturbing, making us re-evaluate what we thought the characters were capable of, and by extension, the capacities of all of us.

reviewText: A history of violence is filled with bravo performances by both leads and wonderful, delightful, mysterious, guest appearance by (oscar nominated this year for his role) William Hurt, who plays a betrayed Godfather. A much more convincingly memorable Ed Harris, playing a disfigured Thug, not satisfied with how things appear, and with his appearance turns the mood of the film. Every thing about this film sticks in my mind, and I can't really sum up the reason why. In the end, I'm happily settled with the naivety of the matter and continually enjoy this film. David Cronenberg has a knack for endings, precisely capturing that feeling of complete fullfillment, and satisfaction a viewer has come to expect from a wonderful movie experience. What remains after viewing this film is deeply moving late into the night. The silence, and energy in the air remains vivid in my head today.
summary: One of the top ten movies of 05'

reviewText: After hearing much praise for this film, my girlfriend and I rented it one bored Sunday night.  After seeing it, I ask myself what Hollywood means when it says it 'only wants the best scripts'.A History of Violence is an ironic movie that mocks its supposed message.  At least what I thought was the message.-Possible spoiler alert below-Viggo Mortensen plays Tom Stall, a reluctant hero with a violent past he left behind long ago.  Or so he thought.  After saving a waitress in his diner from thugs, he is put in the spotlight and people show up to collect on his old debts.  Enter Ed Harris, the only interesting character in the entire movie.  Watch him while you can, because sadly, his part is short.  Tom constantly reminds his son that violence is bad, but it seems that violence is Tom's only means of solving all his problems.After a ridiculous sex scene with his wife, Tom gets a call from his brother.  He decides it's time to end all his troubles... with violence.  In keeping with his message to his son that violence solves nothing, he seeks out his brother, a crime lord in Philadelphia, and kills EVERYBODY... VIOLENTLY.  What was the lesson/message in the movie?  I think it was that violence solves nothing... I think?
summary: Wait, what was the lesson again?

reviewText: This movie tries too hard to be too many things at once.  If your goal is to be entertained and have a few puzzling moments--and if you don't mind some horrendous murders happening very quickly every now and then--give it a go.  Otherwise, director David Cronenberg (who is brilliant but never quite reached the level of David Lynch, who he imitates too much)hit a real low point with this.The performance by Viggo Mortensen is fantastic and chilling as hell.  You literally cannot get a grasp on the essence of this kind and when you do just want to back off.  IS he a reformed, average, timid man who has undergone some inexplicable kind of internal transformation of his own accord, or is he a mafia psychopath in raging denial just waiting to froth over?  He is both in a way.Unfortunately this can't save the rest of the film, with embarrassingly obvious symbolism and a kind of schizoid confusion that should have been restricted to the characterization of Tom/Joey, not the sequencing of scenes and dialogue.The surreality Cronenberg attempts right from the beginning is interrupted by Tom/Joey's relationship with his wife and family.  It isn't intriguingly confusing, just annoying.  The scenes in which we see "what lies beneath" with Tom/Joey are frightening indeed and well done, yet the whole gangster bit comes across with about as much as reality as a film with James Cagney.Cronenberg is trying to make some kind of commentary on Americans and their attraction/repulsion to violence but it doesn't succeed because it is too short and too mediocre.  This isn't "Dead Ringers" or even "Mulholland Drive" where you don't understand anything and then, day by day, you begin to understand it and watch it repeatedly.  It isn't that rich.  It sucks when a film has great potential and a great plot, then goes down the tubes slowly.

reviewText: Viggo Mortensen (Lord of the Rings) stars in this dark gripping and dramatic film. He plays a family man Tom Stall who's life turns for the worse after he kills two mad men while defending his diner. Shortly after he's all over the news, some mobsters come along saying he's not who he says he is. Ed Harris is creepy as the head of the mobsters who won't leave Tom and his family alone. He claims Tom is really a former mobster named Joey Cusack that took his eye with barbed wire. William Hurt who's usually sort of wooden gives his most lively performance in a supporting role as a mobster as well.Maria Bello is solid as Tom's wife who's trying to deal with the fact that her whole marriage could be a lie. I mean she thinks she married an innocent nice guy who wouldn't hurt a fly. Then finds out she may have married and had kids with a mobster who may have killed a lot people in the past. Ashton Holmes is also really good as Jack Satll, who's used to just letting the school bully pick on him and getting out of it by wussing out and telling jokes. When his dad becomes a local hero for the diner incident and showed his violent side Jack finds that he too has a violent side. By the end everyone is changed and everything is different for the Stall family than it was in the beginning. It's just a brilliant and gripping piece of work. I guess I shouldn't leave out that it's very bloody and violent as well.
summary: Truly one of the best films of 2005
