reviewText: Poor Viggo.  There are actors that get huge breaks, like Viggo did with Lord of the Rings trilogy, but then flop (Hidalgo).  Then, he get's a role with a great concept with a director that has been in the business for a long time, but has not done any real work that would be considered great (most notably known for "The Fly.").  Why did he (Viggo) get the role, he really isn't leading man quality-Probably  because of lower end salary and his ability to play a small town conservative good guy.  However, a gangster, no.  But when you think of it, who could of really played this role?  It is a very complex role, it would be tough for anyone to pull off.  This isn't a movie for "A" list stars, although I think Nicholas Cage has enough diversity to pull something like this off, so other than him, I really can not think of another person to do the film.  When you think of it, this movie was probably almost impossible to cast.  Maria Bella was excellent in the movie, Ed Harris and William Hurt were both very good, though their screen time was very limited.  Their accents?  I couldn't figure out what they were-They were supposed to be out of some crime family in Philadelphia.  Were they trying to be Italian, because that is just ridiculous or maybe they were trying for a New York accent-But why?.  I really am not sure about the mob deal.  I know you don't stereotype folks, but mobs are usually Italian, Russian or some Asian country and I am not sure what Mob ties they had.  Maybe I am just too big of a Sopranos fan.  At any rate, you can get a synopsis of the movie from Amazon.com.  I enjoyed it, Bella's performance was extremely good, Viggo's was sub-par.  The supporting cast was very good.  The movie is very violent (hence the name, History of Violence), so those that don't like violence, stay away.  When this movie was released, it was supposed to be an Oscar hopeful.  It was close, it had a great concept but just fell a bit flat with the leading man and some other casting issues and some holes in the script.  He (Viggo) could not pull off the duel personalities/hidden past part of his role-He just can not play a bad guy, although he did a good job pre-Lord of the Rings with G.I. Jane.  Summing up, it was an entertaining movie, it had many layers and the director really went out of mediocre past to direct probably the best film of his career, but it just did not have "it."  It was so close, maybe I am just not a Viggo fan, but Viggo, in my opinion was the "it" that kept this movie from reaching its full potential.  This movie has several sex scenes (nudity) and scenes of violence, therefore, keep the kiddies away and for those adults that don't dig the stuff above, keep away.  However, though, not the best, the movie was definitely not the worst due to a very slow year at the movies.  So, for 2005 movies, this movie still would fall in my top 10 of best movies despite all of its faults.
summary: So close, yet you lost me at the mob (3 1/2 stars)

reviewText: In a small quiet town, diner owner Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) was just minding his business working until two criminals interrupt what happens to be closing time taking the diner hostage. Tom kills off the two crooks and becomes a local hero especially with his wife Edie (Maria Bello), son Jack (Ashton Holmes) and daughter Sarah (Heidi Hayes). However, a mysterious man named Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris) and fellow mobster Richie Cusack (William Hurt) starts stalking Tom as they refer to him as a person named Joey but Tom doesn't even know what they are talking about even strange talk about the old days in Philadelphia. But is Tom really who he think he is? does he have a mistaken identity? can he find a way to solve what is really behind his secret past?A thrilling and smart psychological action drama thriller based on a DC/Vertigo graphic novel is wonderfully directed by masterful filmmaker David Cronenberg (the man who brought you "Videodrome", "Dead Ringers" "Scanners", "The Fly", "Crash 1996", "Eastern Promises", "The Brood" and "Rabid") brings another excellent film of his. The performances are nothing but great and the direction is well done. Howard Shore's score is riviting and graphic bloody violence shown, this is truly the best movie of 2005 and another winner from Cronenberg.This DVD contains a bevy of fine extras like audio commentary from director David Cronenberg, "Acts of Violence" documentary that takes a behind the scenes look at the film, three featurettes, Deleted scene and trailer.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Based on the graphic novel,"A History of Violence" introduces you to the life of Tom Stall,a mild mannered owner of a local small town diner and family man.A late night robery puts him into a precarous position and in defense of his life,fellow employees and patrons kills both perpetrators.This in turn puts him on the local news and beyond,a place that he finds uncomfortable and unwelcomed.A series of events follow,shortly after his heroisim displayed,some strangers from out of town come looking for him...looking for Joey Kuszac.But he isn't Joey Kuszac..is he?His life little by lttle is picked appart,and the man who his wife believed was her husband isn't really him.A borrowed name and identy that took years to build is torn down by a series of unfortunate events where these gangsters want to resolve some unfinished business from Tom's/Joeys old life he long believed dead.In a final encounter,he again kills all who threaten him and his way of life.This in turn causes much turmoil and in a desperate attempt to keep and hold onto his family,Tom travels back to Philidelphia to end things with his older brother Richie once and for all.A bloody finale brings this film to an uneasy end.A History of Violence is sort of a case study of violence in general and the way its rippling effect reacts to everyone.Viggo Mortensen puts on a fantastic portral of a bad guy turned good but with a past that comes back to haunt him. Ed Harris is a great addition to this film as is William Hurt as the older brother Richie.A great storyline,suspense and dramma to satisfy the film lover in all of us.Well worth watching,A History of Violence delivers all the way.
summary: "When you dream at night,are you still Joey?"

reviewText: My measure of a truly great movie is whether or not I'd enjoy watching it a second time, already knowing what happens next. In that sense, "A History of Violence" doesn't measure up. For all its harsh realistic depictions of violence, this story never seemed plausible as presented by the director, David Cronenberg.In piecing this film together, Cronenberg was often praised for his "economy." Not a wasted frame, more than one critic gushed.Excuse me, but add a few minutes to the runtime and plug some gaping holes in the plot. Like a previous Amazon reviewer, I can't believe Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensoe) would have been foolish enough, considering his history, to grant a single TV interview after his shoot-em-up in his little café. Then, supposedly the media sharks didn't come swimming back for more, in a far greater frenzy, after this "quiet" everyman has a second deadly gunfight - this time on his own front lawn with known gangsters. Hey, that's the kind of thing CNN, Fox, Inside Edition, Dateline, just might have noticed. And do you think the state police, FBI, someone beyond the local town sheriff might have, at that point in time, started taking a bigger interest in Tom, too?Secondly, the most intriguing aspect of the movie was the mystery surrounding Tom Stall's true identity. Once that mystery was revealed, far too swiftly, the movie loses steam - never mind what some might consider the steamy sex scene between Tom and wife Edie (Maria Bello) when she's apparently both repulsed and aroused by his history of violence.  Personally, I watched that on-the-stairs "mad love" thing happening between Tom and Edie, thinking "only in Hollywood, never in real life.""A History of Violence" may focus on man's primitive side - his inability to escape his truly brutal nature lurking underneath a civilized facade - but it fails miserably to recognize a smart audience wants to be respected for being logical. "A History of Violence" may be appropriately bloody and even messy, but for a movie striving for realism - to be more than a mindless action thriller that asks you to take leaps of faith and forgive plot twists that don't add up - it was absurdly illogical and, thus, terribly unsatisfying.
summary: More Plot Holes, Than Bullet Holes

reviewText: Not since STRAW DOGS (1971) have I seen a film that so strikingly makes the point that the capacity for violence is an inseparable part of the human condition. Even the meek inheriting the Earth have it - if pushed far enough.Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) and wife Edie (Maria Bello) live in a small mid-western town with teenage son Jack (Ashton Holmes) and young daughter Sarah (Heidi Hayes). The couple own, and Tom manages, a diner on Main Street. One night at closing, two psychopathic killers enter the eatery to rob the place and have some bloody fun. (We know they're psychopaths because the film's opening sequence shows them brutally murdering a family that owns a roadside motel.) As his waitress is about to be raped, Tom reacts in a way that would make Dirty Harry proud. The killers are rendered dead in pools of blood, coffee, and broken glass, and Tom, with his foot impaled by a knife, becomes a local hero that makes the national TV news. However, this notoriety draws out of the woodwork a scarred, Mafia hit man from Philadelphia, Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris), and a pair of associate thugs. Carl insists to Tom and Edie that the former is really Joey Cusack, a big city killer that tried to take out Carl's left eye with barbed wire. Tom, of course, denies that he's ever been to Philly. Edie believes her husband. At least she does until witnessing his reaction when Fogarty et al confront Tom on their front lawn after they kidnap Jack. Maybe Hubby has secrets, you think?At first, the audience believes that son Jack is a spineless wimp - until he's pushed too far in the hallway of his high school by a bully that's been tormenting him. (Is there an inheritable gene for mayhem, you might ask.) From all of us who've had sand kicked in our faces, way to go, kid! Even Edie isn't as turned off by violence as much as the thought that Tom has been lying to her all their married life. Indeed, an angry confrontation between the two escalates to a bout of consensual, frenzied sex that, while perhaps not "rough", was certainly uncomfortable and left bruises. (Is sex but low-level violence much as James Coburn's character in the 1967 comedy western WATERHOLE #3 called sex "assault with a friendly weapon"?)Despite Tom's evident past, he's now a loving, committed father and husband and a solid, law abiding member of the community. OK, so he has a few lapses into old habits; they're all for good causes. As the very last scene infers, perhaps Edie can live with it. After all, she and her Hearth and Home are more stoutly defended by Tom's darker side than by some pacifist that wouldn't act until it's too late; other tribes should be so lucky.A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE is a gritty, well-acted, visual essay that neither condones nor condemns the potential for violence that exists in all of us. It's just there waiting in the tall grass to be called forth as needed, and there's no anguished, PC-inspired, hand-wringing about that fact. It's not the greatest film of 2005, but I liked it very much.
summary: Bloodlust as part of the human condition

reviewText: I loved this movie when I first viewed it at a movie theater and I decided to purchase this DVD for my own private collection.  The appeal of this movie works for me on several levels.  The story is about a young couple with a teenage boy and they own a diner in a small town.  One evening while they were closing two thugs walk in and begin threatening everyone in the diner with their guns.  When they attempt to molest a woman the mild mannered owner of the diner, Viggo Mortensen, immediately goes into action throwing hot coffee in the face of one thug and takes the thug's gun killing him and the other armed thug.  These are two very bad career criminals and the news media jumps on the story in this quiet small town.This is really where the story begins to become a mystery and an action packed movie with various surprises. This is also a movie which shows how violence is committed and what it takes  to defeat a person who is determined to hurt you.  Watch closely the simple but highly effective techniques used in all these action scenes in order to appreciate the story.  I do not know if the writers and producers of this movie have ever heard of  a combative system called Target Focus Training, but the hero in this movie understands violence when dealing with these thugs and killers.If you are interested in a simple but also complex movie that has a little bit of everything in it, you may want to check this DVD out.Rating:  5 Stars.  Joseph J. Truncale  (Author:  The Samurai Soul: An old warrior's poetic tribute).
summary: An unusual and entertaining story about a small town family whose lives are changed after an attempted armed robbery.

reviewText: I have mixed feelings about this film; I am a HUGE David Cronenberg fan and - while it does have echoes of his earlier work - it doesn't quite measure up to his past glory.  It bears several of the Cronenberg trademarks: a graphic and unromantic depiction of violence and in-your-face gore (literally, sometimes).  Also, even though there is only one scene of full-frontal nudity, there are a couple of graphic sex scenes.Viggo Mortensen plays Tom Stall - a family man who owns a diner somewhere in Middle America.  I understand that the movie is based on a graphic novel (unread by me) and that perhaps points to the weakness of the film.  In the beginning scenes, Stall and his family come across as caricatures of the All-American family - they are almost too good to be true.  His son, Jack, is a good boy who gets picked on at school because he won't fight back.  "We don't solve our problems in this family by hitting," his father admonishes him.Everything changes when Stall's diner gets invaded by bad men who are obviously going to rob the place and kill everybody - or worse!  All of a sudden, pacifist Tom turns into a commando and neatly does away with them.  He becomes an instant hero/celebrity, but you can tell he doesn't like it.  The next day, a mysterious stranger played by Ed Harris shows up.  He claims that Tom is really a bad man named Joey Cusack.  Is he really? It isn't obvious.  If he is, will his family and town protect him?Some of the negative criticism of this movie that I have read asks, "Is that all there is?"  There is a feeling of thinness to the movie once you reach the end.  We tend to expect more from Cronenberg.  It ends up being a re-tread of the themes of Clint Eastwood's Unforgiven.  Yet, it is violent enough and compelling enough to hold your attention and it is better than much of the studio fare currently available.

reviewText: This movie had some, but not many, redeeming qualities: the graphic scenes (either sexual or violent) were pretty blunt and stark, and some scenes about how his son deals with high school bullies were good.  For that I give it more than one star.Aside from that, though, the story as a whole wasn't nearly as thrilling as we were led to believe; the whole "internal struggle" that Tom Stall endured wasn't captured well: the main character is just some dumb ex mobster who doesn't know what to do, and actually, Viggo Mortenson captured that rather well: he never looks too sorry or self-conflicted: he just looks like a rat who wants out of a trap.  The way out is to go back to Philly and wipe out his brother and a few henchmen, which he does in rather unimaginative fashion.Overall, that's my main gripe: the story is just boring: nothing brilliant or original about it.  Toss in the bad acting (particularly during intimate family moments, which the cast simply wasn't capable of pulling off), and the lack of much action, I just can't give this more than two stars.  You might consider renting it, but be prepared for a slow moving, largely contrived movie, that has some bad acting during the slower, more intimate scenes.
summary: Not nearly as good as I had hoped.

reviewText: It's not a bad movie per se, but it does boarder on being pretentious, a trend which starts at the title. With a name like "A History of Violence" you expect some profound exposition on the nature of violence in society, and this movie doesn't deliver. The notion of a former fighter forced into a situation where he has to resume his violent ways is far from a novel one. I could list several Westerns, spy movies, and comic books that have a similar plot, and I'm sure you could too.The fact that the bad guys in this movie, from the over the top high school bully stereotype to the psychotic restaurant killers, are almost too bad to be believed helps to push this movie more into the category of escapist entertainment. (Then again, reading the news recently, I guess you should never underestimate the capacity for human evil.)But still, the questions this film raises are almost cliché. "What would you do if someone threatened your family at gun point? Could you justify violence then?" I think most of us have been in several discussions about this hypothetical situation ever since middle school or before. I recall several religion classes and youth group discussions devoted to this hypothetical growing up. I suppose it's a question that deserves consideration, even if it is a tired cliché, but this movie adds nothing to the debate.

reviewText: After watching this movie, I immediately ordered the book, wanting to see how the two differed. I haven't gotten the book yet so I can't make a comparison but the movie fell a bit short of my expectations...but is still worth seeing, if only because of the huanting performance of Viggo Mortensen and the questions the film raises about identity and the possibility of redemption after leading a violent life.I can't say too much about the film without spoiling the surprises in it but will say that the main character in this film seems to be an "average Joe" type of guy, living in a small town, running a cafe/diner, married, two kids, nothing unusual. He loves his wife, is kind to his neighbors and is liked by most people who know him.Then a tragic incident puts him in the limelight and his past and present collide, forcing him to reveal his past to his family and to make some terrible choices. This is when the film starts to go "over the top" and viewers may find their credibility stretched to the breaking point. However, Mortensen's acting was so superb that he carried me along with him and I was able to suspend my belief far longer than I might if a less capable actor was pulling off the role. Also, William Hurt has a small but crucial role in this film and, as he so often does, makes the most of it, portraying a wealth of emotions in a short amount of time. He, too, was a pleasure to watch.
summary: Falls short but is still a fascinating movie

reviewText: Too many times I've watched a movie expecting greatness and not getting that. I just knew A History Of Violence would be good but it only met some of my expectations. Although it will keep you entertained you might get mad at it lacking some realness. It may look real but trust me it doesn't look real enough and it goes on for the entire movie. For example when Tom saves his diner and the people in it he hits one of the robbers in the face with a pot of coffee and it's so obvious it's digitalized. Besides that and some other unneeded scenes this film is very good and it ends very well with a nice shootout. Viggo does very well with the fight scenes and gives you a lot of action without gun play. He plays this role really good because he makes you believe he's Tom that other guy.

reviewText: If you like a film with a screenplay that is tight,taught,seamless,action-packed,with lots of plot twist-and-turns,then the Josh Olson written-David Cronenberg directed HISTORY OF VIOLENCE is just for you.THIS IS A GOOD ONE!!!The town of Millbrook,a peaceful and bucolic All-American town has it's soot dredged up when Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) takes out two "goons" who try to rob and kill at his town Diner.At first,Tom is regarded as a town hero,but as the plot thickens,Tom may just be a former criminal on the run from the Philadelphia Mafia.See how Tom and his wife (Maria Bello)and their children play out this scenario.The central theme of this film is DOES VIOLENCE BEGET VIOLENCE.IS VIOLENCE GENETIC? WHEN STIRRED UP SUFFICIENTLY WILL A NATURALLY CALM MILLBROOK BECOME A RAGING TORRENT?Much like earlier films THE RETURN OF MARTIN GUERRE and SOMMERSBY,can a leopard change it's spots? Does "skim milk masquerade as cream"? Do you REALLY know the people closest to you? GOOD STUFF!WATCH IT!
summary: There's a killer in Millbrook-or is there?90 minutes of tension!

reviewText: A History of Violence began as a movie ripe with possibilities.How do you come to terms when the person you love isn't who they pretended to be. This theme is also a parable of marriage as married couples eventually discover the truth about one another after the infatuation wears off.This theme alone was enough to carry the movie into an excellent character study but instead it veered back into a retaliation movie with one dimensional cutout villians.The best scene in the movie was the violent sexual scene just after the wife discovered her husband had been lying. At that point the movie took a wrong turn never to recover. Director Cronenburg missed the boat and took the easy way out.Ed Harris and William hurt played too fierce (laughable) roguesthat took away from instead of adding to the power of the move.Death Wish type movies by the like of Charles Bronson have already been made and done much better.
summary: Do we really know the person we love?

reviewText: I did agree with the reviewers who commented on Maria Bello's hair and how it looks as though she had once had a perm and had given it up about two months before the onset of the movie, in order to experiment, FLY-like, with new ways of developing split ends.  She always looks as though she were too frazzled even to look in the mirror--puzzling in one who is treated throughout the movie as though she were made up and coiffed gorgeously as Grace Kelly in TO CATCH A THIEF.  It's an example of the subtle kind of disconnect that Cronenberg, and his wife the designer Denise Cronenberg, have made to throw uf off balance.  Later on in the movie there's a sequence where William Hurt is filmed with a green screen behind him so that it appears he is larger and taller than Viggo, and even embracing him he seems to lean down and tilt his forehead into Viggo's.  He's wearing the sort of lifts inside his shoes that Hollywood ordinarily reserves for Tom Cruise, all in the name of making him seem larger than life, like a cartoon character.Otherwise I enjoyed this story of two boys, one a gifted athlete, the other a timid, nervous nerd, at odds with each other over the attentions of a baseball coach.  The coach tries to develop the morale of the shy kid, congratulating him when he makes a perfectly ordinary catch in centerfield, and this simple gesture of approval earns the shy boy the lasting enmity of the good-looking popular boy, Bobby (played by Canadian boy idol Kyle Schmid, with big white teeth bigger than license plates).  Bobby is shown driving, nay brooding, around the streets of the little town after dark with a chummy sidekick, a Kenickie type jealous of the shy boy, for it is apparent that Bobby's hatred of Jack is based on either a sublimated locker room lust, or, more likely, a boyish affair between the two during pre-baseball season that Jack suddenly aborted without a word of explanation to jilted Bobby.  Jack, as it turns out, is capable of great acts of violence, though as played by Ashton Holmes (a 30ish teen played with insipid charm and a very loud voice), he is mousy, whiny and a loser by nature.  Does he have a history of violence?  Bobby can't take his eyes off of him.  A friend suggested to me that A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE is Cronenberg's systematic re-enactment of the Kennedy family curse, with the bootlegger grandfather, the warring brothers, the dramatic assassinations, the conflicts between Jack and Bobby.  Instead of the White House, we get a diner set, another of the Cronenbergs' tricks to confuse you, to throw you off the scent of the allegory.If you enjoyed JFK or PT-109, A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE will be right up your alley.Another discordant note comes with the weird overdubbing of Viggo's little daughter, Sarah Stall.  Every time she talks an adult actress seems to be saying her words from a distance behind her, it's creepy as anything you might see in INLAND EMPIRE or MULHOLLAND DRIVE.  They found a little girl who resembles the little POLTERGEIST girl and they use this disturbing reflection to make us reflect on our own addiction to TV.  It's touching the way she sticks up for her big brother, Jack, thick and thin throughout all his ups and downs with Bobby.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Viggo Mortensen takes off his cowboy hat from "Hidalgo," his sword from "LOTR," and trades them in for a shotgun, a number of handguns, and a few swift punches to the throat to flesh out his role of Tom Stall in "A History Of Violence."  The flick starts off with a bit of a surprise, then uses the next twenty or so minutes to build up the monotony, simplicity, and happiness of Stall's life.  He has a perfect wife, Edie (Maria Bello), a good son (Ashton Holmes), and an innocent daughter (Heidi Hayes).  His quiet little diner doesn't draw a lot of business outside of the little town's citizens, but that doesn't bother Tom.One day two murderous thieves stroll into town and try to take the money from Tom's diner and the lives of everyone inside.  With swift and lethal accuracy, Tom takes out both men.  His actions garner the attention of the major news networks and his face is soon plastered all over the country.  This draws out some very seedy characters headed up by a grizzled and gamey Ed Harris, who thinks that Tom is actually Joey Cusack, a Mob hitman from Philadelphia.Threats and plenty of violence follow as the viewer has to decide whether or not Tom really is Joey Cusack.  Once the truth is revealed, another character (William Hurt) enters the fray.This is a very interesting flick to watch.  It is definitely a violent film and the "R"-rating needs to be taken seriously.  There's a little nudity, some sexuality that includes violent sex, and some very crude language.  Blood splatters, globs, goos, and gushes from just about everyone in this flick, so be warned of that.The acting is stellar.  Mortensen does a wonderful job as Stall, and everyone in his family and in the small town are perfectly cast.  William Hurt has a brief but key role and does everything he can with it.  Ed Harris is perfect in his role of Fogarty, a tough, aging mobster who has a score to settle with Joey Cusack.  He's my personal favorite in this film.Overall, this is a definite purchase for fans of the director, David Cronenberg.  It's unlike any other flick he's put out, and his fans know what I mean.  People who like flicks about the mob, action yarns, and even a little mystery will also enjoy this flick.  Most folks may want to rent this before purchasing it, since it does have quite a few intense moments in it that many may not wish to see more than once.  I personally recommend it, but please be warned that it isn't your average action flick.

reviewText: "A History Of Violence" is brilliant! Viggo Mortensen's performance is brilliant! William Hurt's (Oscar nominated for Best Supporting Actor) and Ed Harris' performance is brilliant! David Cronenberg's directing is brilliant! One of last year's best! The screenplay by Josh Olson (Oscar nominated for Best Adapted Screenplay) (based on the graphic novel by John Wagner & Vince Locke) is brilliant! The music by Howard Shore (who has been doing the music to Cronenberg's movies for 27 years & his upcoming "I Kill" (2006) & three-time Oscar Winner for his work on the first & third installments of "The Lord Of The Rings" trilogy) is brilliant! The cinematography by Peter Suschitzky (who has been doing the cinematography to Cronenberg's movies for 18 years & the upcoming "I Kill" (2006) is brillant! The film editing by Ronald Sanders (who has been doing the film editing to Cronenberg's movies for 25 years & the upcoming "I Kill" (2006) is brilliant! The casting by Mark Bennett & Deirdre Bowen (Bowen, who has been doing the casting to Cronenberg's movies for 23 years) is brilliant! The production design by Carol Spier (who has been doing the production design to Cronenberg's movies for 27 years & the upcoming "I Kill" (2006) is brilliant! The art direction by James McAteer (who has been doing the art direction to Cronenberg's movies for 20 years) is brilliant! The set decoration by Peter P. Nicolakakos (who has been doing the set decoration for Cronenberg's movies for 15 years) is brilliant! The costume design by Denise Cronenberg (Cronenberg's sister, who has been doing the costume design to her brother's movies for 20 years) is brilliant! This is brilliant, masterful, and intense!

reviewText: Of course you know the plot by now, it's kind of Hitchcockian. In the great director's films, he would take the 'normal' man, James Stewart, Cary Grant, and immerse him into abnormal events. Here Mr. Cronenberg, in an excellent film with great supporting actors, does quite the opposite taking the anomolous man, certainly abnormal, and immersing him into normal circumstances. At least until two killers stop for coffee in this quiet midwestern town.You know, Roy Hobbs in "The Natural" says about his past life, 'some mistakes you never stop paying for.' And that's how late night eatery owner Tom Stall must feel when the scarred Tom Fogarty (Ed Harris; brilliant; what would you expect?) shows up wanting to bring Tom back to talk to his brother Richie, mobster William Hurt. Maria Bello is lovely and is confused, angry and then supportive of her husband Tom . . . . .errrr . . . . Joey, and the film continues with granted some predictable 'a tiger CAN change his stripes' scenes. But the ending is kind of haunting with that 'what do we do now' scene so similar to the red light scene in "Unfaithful." 5 stars. Recommended, but probably not for kids, if we can still offer that caveat. Larry Scantlebury
summary: We all sit on a footlocker containing a couple of secrets we want to remain locked up

reviewText: David Cronenberg is a master at involving viewers in aggressive and explicit behavior in films ranging from "Scanners" to "Rabid" to "Videodrome". He seemingly has a better script at his disposition in "A History of Violence" but the film falls prey to the typical Cronenberg shortcomings: superfluous plotline and inadequate ending.Make no mistake, this movie is full of good actors and has a great many compelling scenes. Its story can also be arresting, at least until the time the main character's identity is exposed. From that point forward, this movie is echt-Cronenberg with a lot of needless and explicit bloodletting, no seeming logic in the transposition of certain events, and a completely inadequate ending.Viggo Mortensen, one of the best actors appearing before the public today, combines with Maria Bello as a formidable married couple in this drama which critics mislabeled multilayered. The only thing multilayered in this flick is Bello's character, a loving wife and mother whose lfie changes and, with it, arrives her tangible sense of betrayal. This is acted out realistically and with conviction. Her later frontal nude scene is more of Cronenberg's needless leering into perversion.Mortensen, who is poorly directed by Cronenberg, is a cafe owner whose life turns around after he kills a couple guys that try to rob the place. He is, first, heroic, but this is thae point that his personal history of violence begins to come into focus. That focus is visually sharpened when some mobsters -- including Ed Harris in ludicrous makeup and using a paltry accent -- show up and tell the hero to come clean about his past life, over which they say he owes them much.The story begins to gain interest as the viewer is enveloped in doubt about his identity. However, the real Viggo is soon enough exposed in a group of scenes that are arbitrarily violent without meaning. He closes affairs with mob brother William Hurt -- playing a role even more cartoon characterish than Harris's -- after which he returns to the family he emotionally cheated on and the film ends silently, yet with a resounding thud.If this sounds like a curt and foolish way to end a movie, that's because it is. Cronenberg has never been able to close the deal in his movies and it's no different this time. Without disclosing the action for you, imagine the ending being this: he returns home, kills the family he loves, and the morality tale is resolute. Isn't that more satisfying than what happens here?I was very disappointed that Viggo wasn't better used in this film. To see what he had done before with a role like this, buy, rent or borrow "The Indian Runner", a 1991 movie where he plays a character very similar to this one. This may be the best work Bello has done on the screen but it isn't enough to lift this movie beyond the realm of average.For, even though it is full of explicit and graphic scenes of sex, violence and brutality, the visual exploitation is not enough to carry this story that loses momentum about two-thirds of the way through and becomes a cliche of gangster movies at the end.
summary: Closer to average than exceptional Cronenberg

reviewText: This was one of those movies my husband wanted to watch on DVD rental, as he'd heard it was good from another male co-worker. I wasn't excited about watching this film as I had suspected that it was going to be another one of those mindless/predictable films filled with too much violence and no story line. Needless to say I was wrong about this movie.Yes, this movie has violence. More violence than I would normally enjoy watching, but it does have a good story line and the acting (especially by Viggo Mortensen) was good.In this movie we meet mild mannered family man, Tom Stall, played by Viggo Mortensen, who owns and runs his own diner in a small town where everyone knows everyone else. Life is good for Tom Stall and his family. Stall becomes a local hero who makes big media news when he defends/protects his small diner and its employees by killing two ruthless killers whom have come to rob the diner. Stall doesn't want the attention or even like the attention he receives from the media. The way he sees it is that he was only doing what any other normal citizen would do under those circumstances and wants nothing more than to return to the quiet lifestyle he once knew.Due to all of the media attention Stall receives, two men, whom are outsiders have come to town seeking out Stall and accusing him of being a ruthless killer named, Joey Cusack, from a mob/crime family in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to which Stall denies. These two men keep harassing Stall and his family. Along the way the violent behavior and fight moves on Stalls part escalate which alludes to him being Joey Cusack, from a mob/crime family in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Stall finally admits that he is Joey Cusack and that he returns to Philadelphia to confront his past.Don't want to spoil the ending, so watch the movie!

reviewText: I did not know that "A History of Violence" was based on a graphic novel, but it makes perfect sense that this is the case because an ordinary novel would not really work to tell this story.  Whether we are talking the 2005 movie or the original graphic novel, both the audience and the family of Tom Stall need to see the murder and mayhem.  Describing a head turned into a bloody pulp is not a real substitute for seeing it and it is the visceral reaction of Stall's family that matters most in this story, regardless of what response it engenders in the viewers.The story takes place in the small Indiana town of Mlllbrook that is on the way to other places where Tom (Viggo Mortensen) runs the local dinner.  He is married to Edie (Maria Bello), who is a lawyer, and they have two kids, Jack (Ashton Holmes), a teenager who uses his brains to defuse situations with the school bully, and young Sarah (Heidi Hayes), who symbolizes the innocence of the Stall family.  Then comes the day when a pair of brutal men walk into Tom's diner.  We have already been privy to exactly what these two are capable of, and as soon as they give and indication of their intentions in the diner, Tom kills them.  The fact that they are armed and he is not does not matter, and there is an incongruity between the elegance of his ballet of death and the bloody ruins that result.Tom becomes a hero and a television news crew is there to greet (read: "hound") him as soon as he comes home from the hospital.  Tom spurns the limelight, not because he is particularly shy or humble, but because seeing his face on television sets and the front page of newspapers is going to get him recognized.  That is because Tom has a secret, one which explains why he could kill those two men so effortlessly and why the scarred Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris) shows up in town calling Tom "Joey" and threatening his family.What makes "A History of Violence" different as a revenge drama is how what happens between the explosions of violence is way more important than the murder and mayhem.  We have seen this sort of story before, where somebody turns out to be someone else and their family has to deal with the revelation.  But Stall's family is confronted with an extreme level of violence from the man who is their husband and father.  It is clear that they are repulsed.  However, the key scenes in the film become those in which Jack and then Edie discover that violence is something with which they appear to be more comfortable than they would like to think.Killing everybody who comes from Philadelphia looking for him does not become a viable way of living the rest of his life, so the man whose name is not really Tom has to return to the City of Brotherly love for an ironic confrontation with Richie Cusack (William Hurt in his Oscar nominated supporting role).  Ultimately, "A History of Violence" is a film where actions speak louder than words and in the end words become an inadequate refutation of what has happened.Does the ending of director David Cronenberg's speak to some sort of acceptance of what has happened?  Sir Thomas More reminds us that silence assumes assent.  But when neither party is speaking silence becomes a cipher of indecision.  The most important thing about "A History of Violence" is that when the film is over, the story is not, and you are free to impose your own view of the future for the characters who are left alive in the wake of this violence.
summary: David Cronenberg's take on living with violence

reviewText: Good idea for a movie and that's everything good about it. I was tempted to give up and not finish the movie, but decided to tough it out. I am glad that I stuck with it or I would have only partially understood how terrible this movie is. There are glaring holes in the story line...How did "Joey" get out of the desert after 3 years, find a wife and open a diner in Indiana? Never explained. Terrible acting; everyone seemed to be sleep walking through their parts, even Ed Harris which is a shame because he is a GREAT actor. Let me save you some time to spend your life on something more entertaining...the ending just...ends. Nothing is resolved for the family. We are just left hanging. What will happen to the family now? Are there more gangsters out there yet? Will they stay in Indiana? Are they gonna have more sex on the stairs?? Has her back healed from the last time???These questions need answers and they are not in the movie. In fact, after writing all of this I changed my rating from 2 stars, to 1 star. It is that bad.

reviewText: Not knowing what to expect from this film, I have to say I was pleasantly surprised.  The movie sheds light on the life of a family living out in the country.  Things become a bit more complicated when visitors arrive and show that all is not what it seems in this quiet Indiana town...On the positive side: a) Great casting i.e. Viggo Mortensen is AMAZING, b) There is some really GOOD eroticism between husband and wife the likes of which I have not seen in a long time, and c) The plot and the setting are overall quite good keeping the interest alive.On the negative side: a) At times the movie is slow for no apparent reason, b) The side story with the son and his problems at school with the "tough guy" was rather uninteresting if not annoying, and most importantly, c) the actors portraying the daughter and the brother were not convincing in their respective roles.  The young actress was a very poor choice indeed as this movie does not seem to be her thing, while the brother overdoes it with his character's weird "attitude."In short, A History of Violence is a movie definitely worth watching, as it will provide for an evening's entertainment.  3  Stars

reviewText: This film has a complex theme at its core.  But it moves so fast and is so engaging that I didn't get it until long after I had left the theater.  It opens with a scene of two bad guys who have just commited an act of violence.  It is clear that they will show no mercy as they approach a small town in Indiana with the intent of more mayhem.It's at this point that we are introduced to Viggo Mortensen, cast as a Tom Stall, who runs a small diner in town.  He and his wife, Maria Bello, have been married for twenty years, have a young daughter and a teenage son and are a happy couple.  We know that's about to change.  But at this point we have no idea how much. Soon, the bad guys come calling.  Tom Stall acts fast and saves innocent people.  Immediately, he's proclaimed a hero.But that's just the beginning of the story.  Soon Ed Harris visits the diner.  He's mob connected and bad.  He keeps calling the soft-spoken Tom Stall by another name.  All of a sudden, the whole family is in danger.  It seems that Tom has a secret, a big secret.  How this all plays out kept me on the edge of my seat.  The acting and directing were so good that it all became real.  There are changes in the relationship between Tom and his wife.  There is also a big change in the son.  The pace of the film gets faster and more complex until it finally reaches a very satisfying climax.It wasn't till later that I realized that his film was more than just an exciting suspense drama.  It brought up the concept of "survival of the fittest" and whether this characteristic is something that is inherited and can be controlled.This was a good film.  There's violence in it of course.  But it does make you think.
summary: Great suspense story with  a complex theme at its core

reviewText: The situation here is very intriguing, if not new. Tom Stall is a typical small town man. He runs a diner, he has a loving wife and a typically Hollywood-style troubled teen. All seems well, until a pair of psychos roll into town. The psychos try to make trouble at the diner, and Tom easily takes them down. He's an instant hero, which draws in the mob, who believes he's in witness protection. Normally I am very careful to hide details of the "ending" of a movie in a review, but in this case it's revealed about halfway through and I need to discuss the situation in the review. So if you haven't seen this movie yet and want to watch it completely "blind", please stop reading here.Tom is, indeed, an assassin who is in fact the brother of the current crime boss. Repeated trips by mobsters to his quiet rural home make it clear that he can't just stay in hiding. He decides the only solution is to head home to "talk" to his brother - which ends up meaning he slays everyone in sight. Then he returns home, sits down with his wife and kid, and the movie ends.I really appreciate what was attempted here. Viggo is a great actor, and there are many interesting aspects of the transformation. For example, let's take his marriage. They start with the wife, to be "racy", dressing up as a sweet cheerleader from high school. Only a short while later, when she realizes he's an assassin, they have a brutally passionate sex scene on the stairs. Tom in fact tries to pull back, and she pulls him down to her again. She's discovering her own darker side.Tom tried to "reform" from his previous life. He says that he spent a few years in the desert, changing. His new name, "Tom Stall", was "available". Did he know someone who died? Was it someone he killed? I love the ambiguity. He even tries to tell his son to be peaceful with the school bullies. He's not grumpy with his small diner restaurant. He's honestly proud of it. He's happy with his life. He isn't "making do" - he is content. There are many small touches shown throughout the movie that reflects this.So now, the issues that I have. First, David Cronenberg is a horror movie director and it really shows. It turns the movie from a dark, psychological thriller to something that is more over-the-top. Some of the deleted things border on silly. I am all for violence in context. The violence was heavy handed here, so that it crossed from being realistic and into the realm of fantastic. It meant the movie became less "real". That's fine in a movie that is meant to be violent for violence sake, like say Predator. I love movies like that. However, this movie had amazing potential for being a *psychological* gripper. That means you really have to believe 100% in the characters and their personalities and motives, to be caught up in that. The movie was missing in that. There were also several plot holes which were too big for suspension of disbelief, which also made the connection to the characters falter.Here's one situation. Tom grew up with the mob. He was in fact an assassin for them. Yet when some mob guys show up, he thinks somehow they'll "go away". It's not like Tom is without people who can easily identify him. Surely his brother saw the news footage! Yet he leaves his entire family at risk by hanging around, waiting. The bad guys show up. He could go with them, to save his family. Nope, he doesn't do that either. Eventually he decides to go talk with his brother, and shoots up the entire place, leaving fingerprints all over. Then he walks out and tosses the gun in the pond. Nope, I bet the police will never spot it there. And then ... he drives home again?There was so much depth that could have been developed here. The relationship between Tom and his son, how both reacted to situations, how Tom dealt with the situations he faced. Besides the aforementioned sex duality, however, most of the rest was whitewashed. I would have loved to see more meaningful time between Tom and his son. I'd have loved to see Tom in more "grey" situations. Instead, it was all black and white.The "meaning" that did survive was pretty light. Sure, everyone can change. We see that every day, with people who are corrupted by wealth, and other people who turn their back on a life of crime to be peaceful. It's normal, it's not "strange". The mob wasn't "evil" any more than Tom was "good". They were all just men who had their personal drives. Many mobsters will tell you they were born into a family and raised to be loyal to that family. They don't kill innocent civilians, they kill "soldiers" who actively threaten them. That was Tom's life. Life is about shades of grey, about people sliding along the scale, making decisions, interacting with others. The movie went right past all of that into the blood and gore.As a final note, I pegged the landscape as Canadian as soon as it opened - that fall foliage was a pretty clear giveaway. While it was pretty, it also took away from the realism. Surely Canadian film costs can't be *so* low that they are incapable of filming a film about the midwest IN the midwest? It seemed like a shallow cheat to me. The midwest has such a rich history, a gorgeous landscape, and that "safe quiet" was such a critical component of the storyline that it was disappointing to me to be reminded constantly that they were lying about it.
summary: Great Potential - But Lacking in Realism

reviewText: A History of Violence is a film about Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen)l a loving husband and father to a family with two children in a small town in Indiana.  Corn fields surround his rural area home and he drives a pick-up truck.  Tom also owns a small diner in town and has been in this town and married,living a quiet idyllic existence for about twenty years.The movie slowly builds and develops complexity when Tom stops a vicious robbery in his diner.  He protects his innocent employees and customers in amazing defensive and offensive reflexes beyond what normal men can do.  Tom reminded me of a Clark Kent that can turn into his alter-ego Superman when needed.  (His son also shows Tom's quick reflexes and thinking when he is unfairly attacked by high school bullies.  By standing up to the bully and his friends he gains respect and the right to be left alone.)Unfortunately for Tom, he is featured as a hero on several news stations as well as the newspaper.  His life and face are in the spotlight, which immediately signals a threatening mobster from out of town (Ed Harris).  He arrives into town with two thugs with a story that Tom attacked him and ruined his face and eye with barbed wire.  Tom's past is unpeeled layer by layer as he struggles to protect his family from his violent past.After the two confrontations and killing out of town mobsters, Tom is ruinited with his "good guy" brother, Ritchie (William Hurt).  Ritchie is mixed up with the mob and wants vengence with Tom for leaving him "holding the bag" from the past.  The acting does not skip a beat - the casting is excellent and the movie is mesmerizing.  This is a top-notch psychological thriller, putting light on beliefs, relationships and the audacity of using violence to protect and save relationships.

reviewText: This year was a particularly good year for films with the debuts of amazing films such as Brokeback Mountain, Capote, and Crash (to name a few), but no film is better than David Cronenberg's A History of Violence.  First of all, how does one comprehend the fact that David Cronenberg has directed such a mainstream movie?  This was a complete shocker to me.  I expected a movie like his previous ones (Spider, Crash [the 1997 version], or eXistenZ).  The main acting is very strong, not as strong as other films, but William Hurt should be able to contend with all of the other Oscar contenders for Supporting Actor, although I think Clooney or the surprise Giamatti have the best shot.  What is interesting is that, on the whole, this movie is better than any other film this year.  Brokeback Mountain relies on its acting to have the plot succeed, much like the acting in Capote.  Those two films could have easily failed, but because of the amazing acting they succeeded.  This film does not really need amazing acting because it is well written.  It does need above average acting, but the story was so well adapted from the graphic novel.  I think it will be between Brokeback Mountain and A History of Violence for Best Adapted Screenplay this year.  This is the absolute best movie of the year.

reviewText: I'll state it right away - Cronenberg is one of my favorite directors, living or dead, so it's more than likely that I'll at the very least ENJOY his work, let alone absolutely adore it.  A History of Violence is one of my favorite films of the last 10 years, and was the best film of 2005.  It's a film that, as stated before by other reviewers, raises far more questions than it answers but that's Cronenberg, a film maker who loves to make his audience think - and if they cringe in the process, all the better.Cronenberg began his carrer with more horror orientated films, They Came From Within (aka Shivers) and Rabid.  But even with these films the enemy, the monster, wasn't some other being, but the evil force bent on destruction was within the self, which is far more frightening than being chased by Frankenstein's monster of a werewolf, because no matter how far, how fast you run, you cannot escape yourself.  (I think the best example of this is either The Fly or Videodrome.)Back to the film at hand.  A History of Violence, based on the graphic novel by Locke and Wagner, shares very little with said GN, Cronenberg even states it himself.  They start off the same, somewhat, but the film eventually veers off into more philosophical territory than the comic.Violence is a horrible thing, no matter how seemingly tiny of an event, be it a school fight or the murder of a family member, it destroys lives, leaves scars, it is the ultimate horror.  The violence in the film isn't styilized (like Tarantino, who Cronenberg has spoken out against.), it's realistic and disturbing.  If you engage in an act of violence it will come back to you, perhaps ten-fold, and will destroy some aspect of your life.This is what I got out of the film.  I listened to bits and pieces of Cronenberg's commentary, and he said it's not an ironic film, and I agree, it's a cathartic study of what violence can do to a seemingly loving and intimate (this is the justification behind the accusedly "graphic" sex scenes.) couple, and their family.Maybe when I watch the film again I'll delve even deeper into the whole thing, but I'm tired.
summary: A past you cannot escape - a future you cannot foresee, best film of 2005

reviewText: Viggo Mortensen plays Tom Stall, proprieter of a diner in a small town in the mid-west.  Tom has a beautiful wife, played by Maria Bella, and a son and daughter.One day a couple of bad - and I mean really, really bad - men come into Tom's diner.  The menacing scene is resolved when Tom is provoked and dispatches the bullying baddies as easily as Bruce Lee kicking a collective roomful of bad backsides.  Everyone is surprised - how could Tom have dispatched those ruthless toughs so easily?Soon Ed Harris, sporting a wicked scar, shows up at Tom's diner, claiming that Tom is not an innocent small-town guy at all.  No, Harris claims that "Tom" gave that scar in his previous life working for the mob.Hitchcock loved the tale of the innocent man suddenly thrown into a cyclone of turmoil and intrigue.  Cronenberg reverses roles with the story of a man who is not innocent, but leaves a life with the mob to try a life behind white picket fences.  I don't know about the real mob, but in films they never take kindly to such independence.

reviewText: A history of violence is a film that stars Viggo Mortenson and Ed Harris.  Viggo plays Tom Stall, a man who runs a Norman Rockwell type diner in a Midwestern town in Indiana.  He lives a simple life.  On a road to this town are some bad guys who decide one night to go to this diner.  What happens next sets into place not so much a chain reaction, but an opening of a door into Tom's past.  A History of Violence is thankfully not a "thoughtful" film about "violence" even though many may claim it to be.  It has that in it somewhat, but I don't know if that was so much the point.  The story is more centered on the character of Tom Stall and the life he has led.  Violence is not a trait as much as an action or tool that is applied in the film.  It is an old devil resurrected again to keep some kind of balance with things.  The balance soon shifts though, as Tom's son decides to start using this action of defense against the school bully.  The film does have its shooting scenes that will show you carnage with torn flesh and broken teeth.  Ed Harris is really, really good as an organized crime boss who thinks that Tom Stall is someone he used to know.  The ending was actually quite good, at least not the very end but the scene that showed a road trip that went back through the door into the past, which has a trail that shows us a history of violence.  I think that this film has a lot of qualities to it and it is not light in action nor is extreme in constant shooting scenes like some movies that are like this.

reviewText: I didn't know what to expect when I sat down to watch the movie.  I didn't even know the movie was going to revolve around a single family.  Even upon seeing the first scene, I was under impression that this was going to be a movie in the vein of Natural Born Killers.  The scope of the movie I ended up seeing was far smaller than I was expecting, but that took nothing from its impact.This is a very different, very good movie.  It makes you remember that you can never truly KNOW someone.  You can know their personality, their quirks, etc... yet you can never get inside of that person's head and listen in on their thoughts and admissions made only to themselves about their past.  Vigo Mortensen plays that out wonderfully in this film.  He appears to be a good man - and virtuous man, who lives and earns for those he loves.  His family is cared for, it would seem, by the hand of a gentle and caring man.  You truly believe this until his past begins to stalk him down and truth begins to reveal itself.The supporting cast couldn't have been much stronger.  Maria Bello, Ed Harris and William Hurt all give stirring performances.  William Hurt's character is one that you will remember.  Those who lack the most basic human characteristics and sensitivities always tend to stick with us.  Ed Harris is always outstanding - and he gets to show a particularly menacing (although still somewhat passive) side in this film.Highly recommended.
summary: He wouldn't know you, somebody like you.

Does his son go back to school? Does the wife forgive him as we might be inclined to believe at the end? Will the husband change his ways or will there be more problems will the mob?  Does the husband get in trouble with the law? Also it got annoying when everytime he was in a serious life or death situation he manages to pull a superman out of his bag of tricks and kills everyone around him. To me that was just plain absurd. reviewText: Beyond the controversy, beyond the hype, beyond all of the critical praise, "A History of Violence" is a slow-burn of a movie, demanding of repeated viewings. Much of the reviews on Amazon seem to have been in answer to all of the critical hype moreso than the film itself.David Cronenberg's films have always been challenging, to say the least, and that is precisely why he is one of my fave directors.The opening shot of the film is remarkable. I'm talking about the way Cronenburg frames the visual elements - doors, windows, wall panels... not too unlike comic book panels! He straight off the bat acknowledges the very inspiration for this film (being as it is based on the graphic novel by John Wagner & Vince Locke). But the violence of this film has no resemblance to the violence of the usual comic book. The opening scene also seems to play around with normal perceptions of time, where the younger man drives the car down to the office, which is only a few paces away(!) and then when his partner walks out of the office almost immediately, he is asked what took him so long(!). Just like in a comic, where panel-to-panel movement is meant to convey a sense of flow, which entails a sense of time. But, in a comic, how do you measure time? Maybe I'm reading too much into this; but this is the way that I interpreted this scene.Viggo Mortensen was great in the part of Tom Stall, as he always is! Most people only recognise him as "that guy from Lord of the Rings" which, while I don't deny that those films certainly made him a household name, to me, Viggo will always be Frank from "The Indian Runner". For those who haven't seen it, do yourselves a favour and check it out. If you like "A History of Violence" you'll love "Indian Runner". In it he plays another troubled soul locked in a cycle of violence against a brother who doesn't like the life he leads! Ah, I just love synchronicities... Oh, well, I'm done with this review, I'm going to watch "Indian Runner"!
summary: If you like "A History of Violence" you'll love...

reviewerName: Meesha "I'm A Lonely Angel Stuck On The Slow ...
reviewText: I came to watch A History Of Violence without knowing anything about it previously. I don't remember reading a single review about it when it originally came out, maybe one, but that was about it. I knew nothing before my boyfriend suggested it to watch.Unlike many "violent" movies out there, this film gives so much more meaning to a violent film. It looks bloody realistic, with bits of brain being blown over someone else, and it's so realistic that you almost forget it's a film.The main character, Tom Stall, a seemingly ordinary family man, gets involved with a couple of would-be robbers. He shoots them dead, when they attack his staff, and later becomes a hero in his little town, where everyone knows everything.But is Tom hiding something? Because someone, played by a very scarred Ed Harris, sees Tom on the news, but only, he doesn't know him as Tom - he knows him as Joey. And he owes Joey a beating.After this, I lost track a bit. For me, I was never quite sure whether Tom was actually Joey or was Joey actually Tom. Viggo Mortensen played it so convincingly, that I actually believed he was Tom, and not Joey, but is there a hint of schizophrenia in there too?There's a great relationship between Tom & his wife, played by Maria Bello (Coyote Ugly). They have some extremely powerful scenes together, and two scenes show two very different sides to their physical relationship. The first scenes shows a happy loving couple, revisiting their love from a long time ago, by playing at teenagers again. Maria Bello in a cheerleader outfit? Yeah I think that'll do it for most guys. A later scene, where Tom is Joey, shows some very conflicting emotions while on the stairs, as it seems to be revealed that Edie knew all along that Tom was Joey, but is still happy to show a rougher side to their physical relationship. Looks painful!The "monsters" that Tom's daughter dreams about and is scared of at the start, gives a little preview to what is going to happen. The monsters are real.It's a very difficult movie to forget, but after reading that Thomas Jane turned down the role of Tom, I think I would have preferred to see him rather than Viggo Mortensen. I just don't like him personally as an actor. But altogether A History Of Violence is a lot better than many so called violent films out there, and is well worth seeing.

reviewText: Viggo Mortensen is a good actor.Cronenberg is a good director.Both have made hits, both have made misses. This movie I have to file under the latter. What starts out as an intersting story (a silent type gets forced to show what's brooding under his skin), takes a turn for the worst when his actions wake the interest of - how original - the mob. There's a cat and mouse game that simply ends with three dead mobsters, a father/son conflict, a signature sex scene, and... well, Cronenberg is well known for his in-your-face bloodshed, so it isn't unexpected, but the last third of the movie turns it into a turd of a movie, that ends with not even a sizzle. The whole roadtrip ending in carnage and the anticlimactic finale left me with a bad taste.
summary: Not a good followup for Viggo or Cronenberg

reviewText: Director David Cronenberg's movies glisten with a surface sheen that is always perfect. His mise en scene is often pathologically devoid of human connection or touch, though his films are always thought provoking and often scandalous in their grasp of the detritus of our lives. Is there any more beautiful movie than "Dead Ringers?" Any movie as scandalous, off-putting yet compelling as "Crash?" (the version with Rosanna Arquette and Holly Hunter).In his terrific new film, "A History of Violence" Cronenberg has it both ways: his film features a straight forward plot that he handles with just a slight out-of-kilter quality that adds crunch and bite to the story of a man, Tom Stall (the quintessential strong silent, Gary Cooper-type, Viggo Mortensen) who, when placed in a situation that requires swift and brutal force...vomits out the internal fortitude necessary from deep inside his psyche and bowels to come up with the goods to deal with the situation. "AHOV" then, is about violence, brutality and the far reaching and ever telescoping tentacles that both exhibit as they wreak havoc on Tom, his wife Edie (the luminous Maria Bello) and his family and friends.Cronenberg is dealing with some lofty and controversial ideas here: Kill someone and forever pay the price for that murder, whether or not the crime is justified or not. Commit violence and that violence colors everything that you are, everything that you do for the rest of your life. Once you take someone's life how much of you, the essence, the soul, the heart of you is gone also?Viggo Mortensen's Tom Stall is strong of mind and morals, tender, vulnerable, upstanding but ultimately conflicted. Mortensen turns in a shaded performance that not only shows up Tom's soft side but also his malevolent one as well. Maria Bello, usually miss-used in her previous films is a revelation here as Edie: intelligent, accomplished, dedicated and hopelessly in love with Tom but aware that many times being in love doesn't mean you know everything about the object of that love."A History of Violence" is Cronenberg's "Vertigo": his version of obsession, violence and retribution told the Cronenbergian way: slanted toward the perverse...bordering on the maniacal. Don't blame Cronenberg because he is not Hitchcock, for he has learned his lessons from the master well. Blame him because he has come up with a film that is provocative and multi-layered though: one as transparent as a silk screen, just slightly out of reach...beckoning us in for a closer, scalpel-like investigation of what makes us tick, the buttons to punch to make us react and the mechanics necessary to allow us to exist.

reviewText: This is one of those movies that seems to start off as a powerhouse and then peters off where the director was not sure where to take it and the movie seems to feel more like a long Sopranos episode than a feature length film.Tom Stall runs a diner in a small Indiana town with his wife.  Tom is the "nice" guy with the adoring wife that works with him and two children that everyone in the town "knows."  One day there is trouble in the diner which causes Tom to get into a fight with two bad guys and kills them both to protect the waitress.  Tom is wounded in the foot and ends up in the hospital and "all over the tv."After Tom gets out of the hospital he goes back to work in the diner.  One day 3 guys in a black car come into the diner, calling Tom Joey Cusack and tell him to remember Philadelphia.  The three men start to stalk Tom and his family and the sherrif tells Tom that the three men are very bad mob guys from Philadelphia and why are they so sure that Tom is this Joey?  Is Tom in a witness protection program?  This leads to a showdown between Tom and the three men.  Meanwhile Tom's son seems to believe all the accuasations and starts getting into a lot of trouble in school.This is the type of movie that too many things are obvious and there is very little suspense.  The big showdown happens about two-thirds into the movie so there is still more unresolved things going on including a showdown with a very mis-cast William Hurt as mob-boss Richie Cusack.Even after the final scene, this movie leaves you shaking your head as not everything is resolved especially Tom's (Richie's?)relationship with his wife.
summary: Could have been a lot better

reviewText: It's ironic that director David Cronenberg (the man who gave us exploding heads in SCANNERS) has been quote to say he doesn't like violence.  In A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE, there's a lot of sudden and quite graphic violence.  But it is a powerful movie focusing on a seemingly normal man's unexpected exposure to violence and how it affects him and his all American family.  In the beginning it's hard to see Tom Stall as a violent man; he seems so gentle, so kind, so "normal."  But does Tom have a violent past that has come back to haunt him?  Is he really Joey?  With a well developed script and a cast of impeccable performers, this movie is a disturbing look at our violent and our normal worlds.  Viggo Mortensen proves there's more than LORD OF THE RINGS in the world; his performance is well fleshed and his transference from good old Tom to not so nice Joey is superb.  Maria Bello is quite effective as his wife who watches their world crumble around them; Ashton Holmes plays the son who shirks away from violence, only to have it erupt within his own world; Ed Harris is brilliant as the man from Tom's past who crashes into his life; and Oscar nominee William Hurt in a small but focal role is simply stunning in his acceptance of violence in his life, at the expense of even killing his brother.The violence in this movie is ugly, and that's what I think the movie wants to say...can one change?  That's up to the viewer to decide.

reviewText: David Cronenberg is not the first person I think of for an action film.  But then, despite the movie's name, this isn't an action film.  It's parable about all kinds of violence: violence between parent and child, between children, between husband and wife, between brothers, and of course, good old-fashioned violence against people who disagree with you.The Stalls are a perfect family.  There's hot lawyer wife Edie (Maria Bello), soft-spoken Tom (Viggo Mortensen), and their children: wisecracking teenage Jack (Ashton Holmes) and cute-as-a-button Sarah (Heidi Hayes). Into this perfect family portrait enters violence in the form of bullies at school and thugs who attempt to rob Tom's diner.It turns out that Tom has an ugly past he's been trying to keep secret.  But when Tom violently repels the robbers and becomes a minor celebrity, his past comes back in force.Carl Fogarty (a snarling Ed Harris), a mobster who wants Tom to "go for a drive," shows up at Tom's doorstep, threatening his friends and family.  Things spiral downward from there.Tom's struggle isn't just about his criminal past. Cronenberg unspools on screen a litmus test of violent scenarios, and then asks the audience each time: Is this okay?  The questions start out easy to answer and become increasingly complex.  By the time Tom grabs his wife in a violent embrace that turns passionate, we suddenly understand that each person defines their own boundary of when violence is and isn't acceptable.  And the morality attached to each act of violence is a fluid thing indeed.All the actors pull their weight in History of Violence, except perhaps Hayes--she's no Dakota Fanning, but she acts suitably cute (a little too cute).  Everyone else is excellent, from Bello's desperate, hurt looks to Holmes terrified/thrilled rage, to the inimitable Harris as a very scary man.  And of course there's Mortensen, who infuses every character with a level of depth with a sad glance.By the time Richie Cusack (William Hurt) appears, the violence at home has come full circle.  I'm not particular fond of Hurt, but he does an excellent, frightening job here, as a mobster completely bereft of any moral compass.This movie poses important questions that challenge American assumptions about violence, similar to how American History X challenged our assumptions about racism.  It's in answering those questions that the movie becomes more than action film and transforms into a morality tale worth seeing.

reviewText: A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE is, guess what, violent. But not as much as one would think from the title. Actually, AHV is a standard thriller and the somewhat misleading title refers to the character Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen), who may or may not have a "history of violence". As a standard thriller, AHV is pretty good. It can boast a good script and it is well directed by David Cronenberg. Thrillers must have one necessary element to succeed: good villains. Think of DIE HARD. What would DIE HARD have been without the spectacular acting of Alan Rickman as the lead villain? And AHV has some dandy villans: two of them played by Ed Harris and William Hurt, who give excellent performances as stone cold killers. Like many thrillers, AHV is the story of how one man deals with violence, alone and without help from the cops. Men will love to project themselves as resourceful Tom Stall and women will love to see their hero. But psycho-babble analysis aside, chances are you will enjoy A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE. But don't be afraid of the film's title; instead be afraid of the film's bad guys.

reviewText: Tom Stall (Mortensen) is a mild mannered man in a small town.  He is a family man, and runs a diner.  One day two criminals enter his diner with robbery and rape on their minds.  Tom manages to get one of their guns, and kill both of them.  Hailed as a hero, the media descends and Tom finds his face on the television.  Enter Earl Fogaty (Harris), a thug who thinks he recognizes Tom, only he knows him as Joey Cusack, an ex-killer from Philadelphia.  Fogaty comes to see Tom and "out" him for the killer that he believes Tom to be.  Tom firmly denied knowing anything about this Joey Cusack and claims to never have seen Fogaty before.  Fogaty is unwilling to accept Tom's casual dismissal, and begins to stalk Tom and his family."Violence" is an excellent movie.  From a solid story to solid acting, "Violence" is top notch on all levels.  The story is compelling.  The uncertainty of Tom's past keeps the viewer engaged in his plight.  The four main actors all give top notch performances.  Mortensen gives no clue as to his characters past, portraying Tom as a man living a quiet peaceful life until confronted with violence.  Maria Bello is excellent as Tom's wife, who loves and supports her husband.  Harris is pure evil and menace as Fogaty.  His character is not likeable in the least, and you know that he is not going to leave Tom to live his life peacefully.  Finally, William Hurt gives a memorable, and at times, funny performance.  You have to wait until the final third of the film to see him, but he steals the scenes he is in."Violence" is a must see movie.  It will make you think about what makes a person who they are, and how their identity is defined.  And, can that change?  I highly recommend "A History of Violence".

reviewText: Viggo Mortensen (Lord Of The Rings Trilogy, The Indian Runner) stars as Tom Stall, just a hard working family man with a beautiful wife named Edie, played by Maria Bello (Assualt On Precinct 13, Coyote Ugly) and he has a daughter and a son, played by Ashton Holmes. When 2 men come in, they dont seem to want to leave and they want to do some damage to the customers, so Viggo takes matters in his own hands and kills the 2 men and winds up with a knife wound in his foot. This pins him as a Local Hero to the town and  attracts a few men, one with a wicked looking dead eye named  Carl Fogarty, played with sinister support by Ed Harris (The Human Stain, The Rock). Harris tells Mortensen that Tom isnt his real name and Joey Cusack is his real name, he lived in Philadelphia and he has a brother named Ritchie Cusack but Mortensen denies this, he denies that he's this Joey character that their talking about. So, Mortensen's Wife finds out the truth, and I am not going to tell you all what happens next. The result is a shocking and jaw dropping thriller with Mortensen in top form digging into one of the best performances of his career and we all know Mortensen was Aragorn, in which he was superb dont get he wrong, but this shows that he can go the distance. William Hurt (Changing Lanes, Broadcast News) plays Mortensen's Brother Ritchie and Hurt has a hoot of a time in the small but memorable role. One Of Cronenberg's Best...maybe my favorite Cronenberg movie, because I didnt like Crash in 1966 or The Fly with Jeff Goldblum. Also One of The best movies of the year on my list.
summary: One of Cronenberg's Best.........One Of Mortensen's finest performances..maybe his best

reviewText: David Cronenberg has made some of the best films of the last 30 years, like "Dead Ringers", "Spider", and a forgotten film that I highly recommend, "Rabid". Needless to say, I was excited for a new Cronenberg release and quickly made my way to this film. I was HUGELY dissapointed in this movie, somehow believing it would be his best.The first half of the movie was entertaining, driven almost exclusively by Ed Harris absolutely chewing the scenery he's so over-the-top good. Sadly, his part is small. His absence in the second half is felt until William Hurt starts chewing some scenery of his own- he earned his Oscar nomination and probably should have won for his performance.Notice I've only mentioned the supporting actors? Vigo Mortensen is a good supporting actor, but I don't believe he's got the chops to carry a film on his own. Talented? Yes. Leading man? Not quite.Back to the issue of Cronenberg- this is NOT a Cronenberg movie. It has none of his trademark distance and coldness. At no point did I feel challenged by the film. This may sound strange, but I want the confusion that's inherent in one of Cronenberg's films. I want the questions and the debate. Have you ever seen "Videodrome"? Explain that one to me- go ahead, I dare you! "History of Violence" had none of that.Not a terrible movie, but certainly not befitting the status I've come to expect from Cronenberg.
summary: NOT Cronenberg's best by a long shot
