reviewText: The setup of "A History of Violence," David Cronenberg's provocative and profoundly disturbing new film, is simple: Tom Stall, a quiet, inarticulate diner owner in small-town Indiana, becomes a national hero when he blows away two psycho killers who threaten him and his patrons. Then three sinister mob goons show up in town, insisting that Tom is really Joey Cusack, a long-vanished Philadelphia mob hitman who once, shall we say, did them a disservice. The genius of "A History of Violence" is that the question of Tom's identity is what Hitchcock would have called the McGuffin; the real point of the film is a delirious meditation on the nature of violence, love, atonement and forgiveness. Because this is David Cronenberg, the moral lesson is illustrated with vats of blood; Cronenberg pulls no punches about the effects of a bullet from a .38 Magnum on a human face. But far more disturbing than the physical violence, as Cronenberg demonstrates, is the emotional violence that distrust and fear can wreak on even the most loving family relationships. Viggo Mortensen, in a role that affords him little dialogue, must tell his character's story with his face and body; the results are revelatory. Maria Bello is equally impressive as Edie, Tom's wife, who goes from loving support to fear, distrust and hatred as she learns increasingly unwelcome new secrets about the husband she thought she knew. As mobsters, Ed Harris is brilliantly menacing, William Hurt brilliantly wacked-out. There is also excellent work from Stephen McHattie as one of the diner psychos and young Ashton Holmes as Tom and Edie's teenage son. In his best work, Cronenberg is able to elicit abundant sympathy for his characters, even as he ties our minds and stomachs into knots. By the time we reach the final family tableau in "A History of Violence," we are both deeply horrified and deeply moved.

reviewText: "A History of Violence" is a allegory in the guise of a small-town drama, based on the graphic novel by John Wagner and Vince Locke and adapted for the screen by John Olson. The film poses questions of violence in a personal and social context, such as: When is violence justified? What implication might it have for the perpetrator? Does violence simply beget more violence?  Or not? The best thing about the film is that it presents its questions without being dogmatic and within the context of a mystery surrounding the film's genial protagonist. Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) is a family man with a wife (Maria Bello) he adores, a young daughter, and a teenaged son, who lives a quiet life in a small town, where he owns a diner. When a couple of sadistic thugs try to rob his restaurant, Tom saves the day and becomes a local hero. Then an East Coast gangster with a grudge to settle, Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris), arrives in town claiming that Tom is his old enemy, ruthless enforcer Joey Cusack, who disappeared decades ago after robbing Fogarty of the use of one eye.Director David Cronenberg begins "A History of Violence" on just the right notes: ambiguity and curiosity. When I was watching it, I thought the beginning of the film might be too slow, but once the pace picked up, I appreciated the measured, almost studious start. Tom Stall seems like a great guy.  Just a glance from him elicits sympathy. But the fact that we don't know if Tom might be Joey builds real suspense. This film has an idyllic calm that is sporadically punctuated by extreme violence. But it's the mystery behind Tom, and Joey, and Fogarty that keeps the audience engrossed while a surprising allegory plays out. That is David Cronenberg at his best. I think the film falls down a little in how it handles Jack (Ashton Holmes), Tom's son, because I don't think that teenagers care who wins a baseball game in gym class, and I don't think they speak like that. Actually, no one does. But that is really a quibble. Viggo Mortensen is terrific here. I don't think that Tom was intended to be a realistic character, but rather a mythical one. "A History of Violence" ranks among the few films that have successfully explored extremes of duality in the human character.The DVD (New Line 2006): "Acts of Violence" (1 hour, 5 min) is a making-of documentary that divides the film into 8 acts, exploring each separately. It includes behind-the-scenes footage and interviews with the cast, with David Cronenberg, and with various crew who show us how scenes were created. "Scene 44: Deleted Scenes" (3 min), with optional director's commentary, is a dream sequence shown in its context that didn't make the final cut. "The Unmaking of Scene 44" (6 min) shows us how the scene was created and comments on why it was cut. "Violence's History" (1  min) compares the European version of the film to the US version, in which 2 scenes of violence were softened slightly. "Too Commercial for Cannes" (9 min) takes us tot the 2005 Cannes Film Festival, where we see preparation for the screening, a press conference, hectic interviews, and Cronenberg snapping away with his Nikon for a French film magazine. There is an audio commentary for the film by director David Cronenberg in which he provides scene-by-scene discussion of themes as well as technical and editing details. There is also a theatrical trailer and a DVD-ROM (Windows only). Subtitles for the film are available in English and Spanish.
summary: An Unusual, Surprisingly Absorbing Fable of Human Violence.

reviewText: "A History of Violence" is definitely not a movie for everyone.  The violence is brutally graphic, the sex kinky and the film thematically awards only those who observe the plight of Tom Stall (an excellent Viggo Mortensen) with a keen and searching eye.  But if you're willing to peer closely, "A History of Violence" proves itself to be one of the best films in recent memory, working on multiple levels as possible essays on the nature of violence, the innateness of brutally to the individual, the violent and sexual menace that lurks beneath small-town America or the danger of passing violent tendencies from generation to generation.  But, thankfully, it also works as a good old-fashioned wrong-man thriller, and it finds gifted director David Cronenberg (The Fly) firing on all cylinders.Tom Stall (Mortensen) is enjoying the quiet life in Millbrook, Indiana with his wife (a dynamite Maria Bello), with whom he still enjoys a pumped-up sex life, and his two children.  But his tranquility is shattered when two men who have been rampaging around rural towns come to his diner for a bit of robbery and rape.  Stall springs into action, dispelling the would-be robbers with ruthless efficiency, shocking everyone he knows, none moreso than his son (name) who has always been taught to avoid violence, even in the face of a local harasser.  For Stall, things reallys take a turn for the worse when a group of mobsters, led by the gleefully wicked Carl Fogerty (the reliably superb Ed Harris) and under the orders of mob kingpin Ritchie Cusack (a mesmerizing William Hurt), arrive and accuse Stall of really being named Joey Cusack, Ritchie's brother, a man they have been trying to track down for years.From there, Cronenberg and screenwriter Josh Olson keep the surprises coming at a furious pace, with Cronenberg indulging his usual penchant for gratuitous violence and sexuality.  But Cronenberg also brings out uniformly excellent performances from his gifted cast.  It's great to see "Lord of the Rings" alum Mortensen stretch himself and show how good of an actor he truly is.  Maria Bello makes a worthy sparing partner to Mortensen as both actors subtly show the ugly mutations their characters undergo.  And it's a kick to see great character actors like Ed Harris and William Hurt cut loose and become one-man-wrecking balls as whacked-out mobsters bent on revenge.  A film that both thrills and intellectually entices, "A History of Violence" is one of the best films in recent memory, and it demands to be seen and examined.
summary: One of the Best in Recent Memory

reviewText: This film had great promise, but somehow missed the mark.  The director assembled a very good cast, so you can't blame the casting.  The movie also has some extremely good action scenes that remind me of the old "Deathwish" films, where the hero dramaticly evens the score with some disgusting criminals. The concept and general story line are interesting and relatively complex.  Still, this film ends up being closer to 2 stars than to 4 stars.What went wrong?  Well, for starters the relationships between family members seems contrived.  Stall's (Mortenson) relationship with his wife (Maria Bello) doesn't really have any chemistry.  Don't get me wrong, the director tries to gin something up with a couple of sex scenes that are over the top for this type of film.  While some won't mind the scenes, those clips would fit better in a "9 1/2 weeks part IV".  At any rate, the scenes fail to accomplish their mission, which should have been to show some sort of relationship between the characters.  The daughter is cute and that's about it.  The son isn't really likeable at all and his relationship to his father is just odd.Also, there isn't enough action or suspense in the film to compensate for a lack of chemistry between the people we're supposed to be cheering for.  The details of the story fall flat.In the end, you're left with a movie that has some good actors, 3 good action scenes, and a decent plot concept.  That works well enough to make the 3 star cut, but that's about it.
summary: Not bad, but not good either.  Could've been MUCH better.

reviewText: I didn't expect to like this movie, the title in itself might make some people shy away from it, especially those who dislike violence in general.  It seemed like a average "guy movie", the type my husband loves to bring home from the video store.  I must say that the director delivered the goods, as did the actors in this entertaining film.  The relationships and family dynamics were portrayed in a realistic manner.  I came to care about the family quickly and couldn't walk away.  I am ashamed to say that I was too quick to judge this film just by it's title.  It is not just a movie with violence in it, there is a purpose here, and I am sure if you give it a try, you won't be disappointed.

Believe it or not, all the great reviews by critics are justified because this film is very well made. The violence is extreme at times, but realistic, and the sex scenes are a bit graphic. reviewText: To begin with... these pretentious relations to the darwinian theory, survival of the fittest, could be drawn from any violent movie... I'll pick 'rambo'. It's an overanalysis. All these philosophical issues raised are interpretations fathomed by observation. Such is philosophy. Does that make the movie great. The movie is about a person who changes his way but is forced to face his old self again. That sentence alone could summon infinite philosophical chit chat. Such is philosophy.Really this movie had the scope to be truly breathtaking. But instead, we are fed a simple story imploding under the guise of its own shadow. It is up to us to do all the thinking because the truth is, the writers themselves dont know how. I prefer 'Clockwork Orange'... truly exploring issues it presented.To describe this movie in the form of a violent confrontation... I'd call it a messy brawl that begins with a few shoves in an alley , and ends on top of a high rise building. Its all over the place.I mean it tries to do everything and turns out to be nothing. Other than what is proposed in commercials and previews, I dont think I got much more out of it. Its part action movie... part family drama... part romance... part thriller.. oh yeah and part darwin's theory. It swings every way... but never hits.It doesnt bother delving deep into the true consequenses of Tom's history. The family's ability to deal with the bombshell is brushed off. The emotional connections are severed, the drama ignored. The story merely transcends into a classic b-grade movie where the character is faced with a clear one dimensional objective (in this case, Tom to finish what he had started... Kill the baddies and be home in time for supper).I cant believe the ordeal ends with a family dinner. Iconic, but far from satisfying. This should have been the story. The movie downright fails to progress in worthy direction. What's with the animal sex?
summary: If this was a fight... it would have been a very messy brawl.

reviewText: How well do you know your spouse? Edie Stall (Maria Bella) thought she knew her husband pretty well. Together, they've brought two kids into the world. Tom owns a small diner and Edie has a professional career going. The next question to ask, can you ever really change who you really are? Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) thought maybe he could.An unfortunate event occurs which raises both of these questions and reveals their obvious answers. The lives of this small mid-western couple come unraveled when a couple of small time scumbags try to rob Tom's little diner of whatever tiny bit of cash might be on-hand, but, being the scumbags that they are, figure raping the waitress would be in order as well. Their plans disintegrate when Tom commandeers a weapon and kills them both, but this casts Tom simple life into the world of instant media darling. Having his unwanted fifteen minutes of fame also draws the attention of Philadelphia connections Tom buried a lifetime ago.The movie has a good action theme behind it and some good casting. The usual suspects, Mortensen, Ed Harris and William Hurt, play their parts very well, but the casting goes downhill from there. Particularly poor is the casting of the Stall children, who fail to convincingly portray their roles. The ending of the movie is also rather abrupt, but beyond that, the movie does have a good flow of action and even of relatively steamy scenes between Mortensen and Bella.This is no Academy Award winner, but it is a good action film with a fine plot behind it. Parents should heed the "R" warning for graphic violence.

reviewText: I had never seen A History Of Violence when it was in the theaters and because of that did not really jump at it when it came out on DVD.  I finally bought it off Amazon.com for like six bucks and just the other day got around to watching it.What had i been waiting for?  I don't know.  I hadn't ready the graphic novel and I hear very little about it from friends and coworkers so the buzz wasn't really there.  Well...I was pleasantly surprised, even though Cornenberg strains on a coulple of things.  Ed Harris and William Hurt's characters are so cliche and overplayed.  The sex scenes (the cheerleader outfit and the near-rape on the stairs) were so gratuitous it wasn't even funny.  It was like, hey, lets throw some porn in here.  I'm all for sex scenes, bot those didn't make much sense.  Overall, Viggo Mortensen was great as Tom Stall, the coffeeshop guy turned hero when a couple of freaky bad dudes show up to rob the joint and hurt people.  Scuffle.  Gun loose.  Tom Stall winds up blowing them both away.  (Here you get the first real glimpse that Cornenberg directed when the dying thug is laying on the floor shuddering with half his face blown off.)  Publicity brings in some new customers, of the hoodlum variety.  Carl Fogarty (ed Harris) a Philly wiseguy shows up and starts calling Tom "Joey Cuzak " in a sneering, irritating way.  Who is this Joey Cuzak?  A Philly mobster and brother of mob kingpin Ritchie Cuzak.  A really bad dude that killed a lot of people.  Well, Tom doesn't know what Fogarty is talking about.  Or does he?  Does he have A History Of Violence.Overall this was an entertaining flick.  Try not to dig too deep or you'll wind up picking it apart.  Just enjoy it for what it is.  Viggo Mortensen is kewel and Maria Bello is gorgeous and fieisty and very sexy.  Cronenberg applies himself, but just not all the way.Dig it!
summary: Cronenberg Brings Us An Interesting Piece
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a gem of a movie.  It is one of those rare treats that you can enjoy on multiple levels - as a straight forward thriller, or as it is really intended, as something much more thought provoking.We start the movie with Tom Stall (Viggo Mortnesen) and his wife played by Mario Bello exhibit all the characteristics of a happy, safe, marriage.  Passionate, intimate, good kids etc... Then their world is disrupted, when two bad guys come into the diner where he works.  They set out to do nasty things, and Stall is propelled into a brief but highly effective eruption of violence.  He is feted as a hero, but we begin to see the changes in his relationship with his son in particular as a result.  As the town comes back to normal however, the ever brilliant Ed Harris comes into town.  He is convinced Tom Stall is actually someone else altogether, an explanation that fits with the violence we have seen.  To say more about the plot would be to deprive you of seeing how things unfold, so I will leave it at that.It is in the subtexts that the movie excels - not telling us what we should think, but questioning our own reactions.  Is his son right for using more violent means with bullies?  Was a little violence necessary to balance his pacifist ways?  Is the couples `violent' sex more real than the passion we see near the beginning of the movie?As stated by others, it is after the movie ends and you start talking about the movie.. and you WILL start talking about the movie, that you will realise how effective it actually was.  The performances are uniformly excellent - Mario Bello brings real credibility to a wife dealing with the changes in her husband, and Ashton Holmes as Tom Stall's son is brilliant.  William Hurt is almost unrecognisable in the role of a mob boss teetering on the edge of sanity.  And last but not least, Howard Shore gives a muted and perfectly sorrowful score, completely at odds with the violence in a way that helps the movie immensely.There is violence, and there is sex, but all tightly controlled and more tense than graphic, and all carefully crafted to service the story.  The ending will disappoint you if you tackle this as a mere action movie.. but if you want a real kick off into the whole subject of the influence and effects of violence, then this is a perfect place to start.

reviewText: Wow!  I'm surprised at the average rating of reviewers here on Amazon being 3 stars.  I thought it would be higher.  This film, "A History of Violence," is a powerful little tale directed by David Cronenberg.  A powerful tale not because the film has a surprisingly overwhelming amount of violence (I was shocked that it didn't relatively have all that much violence).  It is a powerful tale because Cronenberg and scriptwriter Josh Olson take the time to build up strong individual characters and have a plot powerfully told.  This film works.As to the overall feel of the film, for some reason I was reminded of older Alfred Hitchcock movies where it seems like a normal tale on the surface but you get this sense that underneath it all something dark this way lies.  It will be difficult to write too much about the plot line without giving away any spoilers.  Besides the great directing and screen writing (and oh did I mention some pretty fine acting chops) the story twists is definitely a strong suite of "A History of Violence."  Concisely and vaguely, Viggo Mortensen plays Tom Stall.  One of those good stable guys everybody loves around a small town.  Maria Bello, who deserves a lot of attention for her strong performance in this film, plays his wife.  He has a son and daughter too.  The perfect American Dream little nuclear family.  Or is it?  There are also some chillingly wicked performances clocked in by Ed Harris, he of the milky eyed scar-faced demeanor.  The more suprising role is that played by William Hurt, whom I've never seen as a villain before.  He pulls it off deliciously.So yes there is some violence along the way.  If that turns you off, this probably isn't the best film for you.  But it does make one think about the role of violence in society and how that may be connected to something primal in us all.  The American culture has been accused of having a morbid unhealthy fascination towards violence as reflected by the fare put out by Hollywood and the media.  So there are some grains of truth in that, but in "A History of Violence," the violence unexpectedly enough isn't front and center.  It is presented more as a by-product of human nature.  What is front and center are the strong characters played by Mortenson and Bello.  Oh...before I wrap up the staircase scene with those two actors is one for all times.  You will not want to miss one of the more unique sex scenes laid down on celluloid (and carpet).  This flick isn't a must see, I'd say...but you'll probably want the DVD if you are interested in what a person can do with filmmaking.  The extras are great in that department.  Happy viewing out there...mmw.
summary: How Far Back Does Darwinian Violence go?

reviewText: Some scenes in this movie are hard to view, but you get a chance to evaluate your own feelings about violence.  You may conclude that violence within a soul can be tamed, or you may decide that once violence erupts within a person that it is always there, ready to come to the surface.  Tom Stall in this movie is a hero, and yet also a violent murderer.  William Hurt adds some comic relief, as his brother Joey runs around killing people.  And Tom Stall is the role that Viggo Mortensen was born to play.  He goes from gentle to brutal in the flash of a eye.

reviewText: Based on the Vertigo graphic novel, A History of Violence is transformed (in this case, for the better) by screen writer Josh Olson and master director David Cronenberg.  Viggo Mortensen stars as Tom Stall, a diner owner in rural Indiana who lives a happy life with his wife (Maria Bello), young daughter, and teenage son.  When two desperate crooks attempt to rob the diner and lay waste to the patrons, Tom springs into action and kills them both, rather easily.  From this point on Tom garners unwanted attention as he has become a local celebrity, and has also gained the attention of a disfigured mobster (Ed Harris, happily chewing his scenery) who claims to know him from years back and keeps calling him Joey.  Without giving too much away, as the film goes on Cronenberg briskly delves into the human psyche and examines the most basic instinct: survival.  The performances from Mortensen, Bello, Harris, and William Hurt in a brief, but unforgettable (and Oscar nominated) role are some of the best that Cronenberg has ever gotten from any actor in any film he's ever done.  The only downside to A History of Violence is that it's over too soon, and fans of Cronenberg may not appreciate it as much as his previous films.  That aside, A History of Violence is one of the better comic to film adaptations of late (and it doesn't feature spandex), and in the footsteps of Crash and Spider, it's another fine examination of human nature by David Cronenberg.

reviewText: "A History of Violence" is a great film. The cast is excellent as well. Viggo Mortenson excels as lead actor playing Tom Stall and Mario Bello is excellent as his wife who comes to a stunning revelation about her husband and the family. Ed Harris and William Hurt are excellent as well. William Hurt rightfully deserved his Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actor... He is one of the few actors that can pull that off, playing the head mobster, with only ten minutes of screen time. The only regret I have is the deleted scene not being in the film... However, if it was it might have gave a lot of information away. Oh well. Overall, definitely worth watching.
summary: "A History of Violence" is a GREAT film.

reviewText: I think when they took this graphic novel to silverscreen, they may have used maybe 15 full pages of the book..there is so much more of a back story and more VIOLENCE in the book than what was given in this film...and the book didn't have these not-needed sex scenes that were ADDED to the film...they didn't belong and I think this movie would have been better without them--plus the movie  should have been at least an hour longer than it was to give a better reflection of the story found in the graphic novel...the cast worked very well in the film and the special effects for the few VIOLENT scenes were excellent...If you didn't read the book prior to seeing this film, you will probably think it's a great movie, but for me, it was a diluted and sanitized version of the story I enjoyed reading very much as a graphic novel.(This film is no SIN CITY-Which was a remarkable comics to film release)..I'm suprised the writer of the book let this film be released in this content.  Like the film HOSTEL, this is yet another disappointing film by an overrated director...
summary: More like A HISTORY OF SEX....and some VIOLENCE

reviewText: I like this movie despite my best friend telling me how much she hated it.  I also share the same complaints as other reviewers even down to Ms. Bello's hair.  Very rarely has someone's hair has driven me to distraction.  I loved the movie all the way up until the family turns on their patriarch.  A man who went through a lot to protect them.  They acted like he was this horrorable person before the trouble came to town and then when they were handed an opportunity to kick him out of the nest they were seriously considering it.  It didn't seem real or true to life.  The whole drive to Philly to confront Rickie suddenly felt like I was watching a different movie.  William Hurt gets an A for effort BUT his portrayal of an organized gangster was nearly too painful to watch.  And then the big return home to his ungrateful family just left a bitter pill in my mouth.  But for the first two-thirds of the movie, I thought it was a good thriller...it just took a left turn at Albuquerque or something.  Still it was good...but it could've been better.

reviewText: Truly one of the worst films I've ever seen. The people who have posted the same really make sense on this one.  Shockingly bad acting, dreadful dialogue, so cliche-ridden there isn't any point in watching it past the first 20 or 30 minutes - you know everything that is going to happen.  And those first 20 or 30 minutes set the pace:  they crawl by, as we are introduced to the family and their fellow smalltown Mayberry inhabitants, every one of them straight from Central Casting and the prop room. The same sheriff we've all seen a zillion times saying the same lines.  The same town, same stoic Reluctant Hero that is the head of America's Stupidest Family unwittingly pursued by the bad guys in black cars - standard fare, all the way down the line. Totally implausible dialogue spoken between family members in nearly every scene.  A soundtrack generic as they come, and sound editing that defies any sense of natural dynamics. BTW there is no "twist" in the plot. If you call it a plot. The lack thereof, however, does not dissuade this director from filling the "storyline" with as many non sequiturs as possible. There is no profound message here that hasn't been recycled in hundreds of made-for-TV movies, usually better. I'm quite surprised, as I enjoyed Eastern Promises pretty well.

reviewText: This movie starts off with such a chilling and foreboding episode that I was sure this would be a real cliff-hanger. It isn't. In fact, it is so predictable, and the ending is so stupid that I can't help but feel this movie has irrevocably cast Viggo Mortensen as the 21st Century Harrison Ford - that's not good. All od the acting is just a notch above high school drama class or bad regional theatre, but at least Viggo and Bello are attractive. Bello is trying desperately to be Kathleen Turner but lacks the wit and the chops. William Hurt must be desperate, as must Ed Harris - they turn in two of the worst performances of their careers, and if you have followed Hurt's recent oeuvre, you can imagine how bad that is. The kid actors stink, all of them. The sex is non-committal, the violence leers toward gratuitous, and that's quite something when you consider it's about violence.Harris, Hurt and a slew of stuffed actors take turns imitating Sylvester Stallone in order to give the film a "Philly" feel. Maybe someone forgot to tell them that Stallone is only marginally connected to Philly, having spent all of his formative years in north Jersey or Brooklyn, which is the actual accent Rocky has, not some meat packer's patter from Kensington. I don't what town substituted for Philadelphia - it is way too clean, tidy, and the streets are too wide. The "mob bar" where Viggo meets his brother's driver is way too upscale and clean for the neighborhood it's meant to inhabit, and Viggo orders a Genessee Cream Ale - now I don't know where in Pennsylvania, let alone Philadelphia, you can have an option of that brew on tap or bottle.The icing on the cake is Viggo's effort to mime everyone else's imitation of Stallone's accent when he switches over to his "Joey" (there's another name for a thug from Philly?) persona. In short, it is a contrived film that began with a sense of revulsion and horror and just caves in to the type of melodrama you'd see in  B movies of the past. Pulp cinema.And that ending! If you haven't guessed it, it's because you've fallen asleep. Skip this and let's hope Viggo signs on for THE HOBBIT.

reviewText: I am not a huge fan of David Cronenburg. However, this movie is an excellent thriller/drama of sorts, with a dark message about today's average family. Simply put, it's about the violent tendencies men have in today's society and how it can be hidden under the guise of being the hardworking American bread winner. In this case, its Viggo Mortgensen, the quiet father and loving husband who runs his own little diner in middle America.He has a vague past which is eventually worked out in the movie. One thing is for sure, he is no stranger to violence and becomes the unlikely town hero for his "skills", saving some lives in the process. But the irony here is that violence begets more violence, no matter how noble the motives might be. Moreover, violence is ingrained in our society and we can't run away from it, even in small town America.Cronenberg exhibits these themes successfully, without trying to indoctrinate. He simply gives some powerful images and scenes to work with. The "action" scenes are few but they pack a serious punch. I haven't seen too many movies with scenes this compact yet graphic. I suppose brevity is the soul of wit, especially in this case.I had a bit of a problem with William Hurts' character. I thought that there could have been a better fit of actor there. But this is a mild complaint considering that the rest of the movie as a whole kicks some serious ass.

reviewText: I rented this DVD on the pure fact that others I've talked to thought it was good--in several forms of the word.I sat down to watch it and was incredibally bored within the ferst few scenes. So much seemed not to make sense and seemed detached from the rest of the movie.It all came down to the story-line being too intense or deep for the plot.The movie had not enough time to go into all the different aspects the filmmakers tried to show. Not too much time after this all starts, the main-character kid flips out on the bully after this one scene of harassment, and beats the spit out of the bully. Where the heck did that come from?! There seemed to be no real reason or "history" for this violence.I guess what I am trying to say is that the director or whomever, might have had a great idea but went about it in all the wrong ways.From a viewer of many violent/action films, this seemed to go nowhere! The characters could not/did not act very well; they seemed to change their personalities so much from one scene to the next, for no conceivable reason whatsoever; and then we have this background on Viggo's character that is never really explained or analyzed for the viewer to understand where it comes from.The movie has been touted as an excellent film, and many of the other reviewers below this one seemed to absolutely love it, but for me, it was an enormous waste of my time.

reviewText: This review may have a few spoilers.How one views a movie often deals with one's approach to the film. I made a mistake with this movie. I went in, having had difficulty securing a Cronenberg movie before, waiting to get an introduction to his style. I went in expecting, based on what I've heard about Cronenberg, a stylized film. I came in expecting a theme.I was mostly disappointed on all three marks. What I ended up with was a fairly straight-forward identity thriller, and that surprised me.Viggo Mortensen plays Tom Stall, a docile man in a docile world. Viggo Mortensen's style of acting, judging by Lord of the Rings, Hidalgo, and this film, is to whisper when he's getting dramatic. This works well with the film in that everyone in it is either just as docile as Tom, or trying to be smooth and stoic, which involves an outward appearance of docility. Tom Stall owns a café, has a good family, has no worries but that he can't get his truck started. Then some violent criminals decide to mess with his coworkers during closing, and he shows a side of himself nobody (in the film) expected: the ability to kill with relative ease. So thus the audience is in the search for his identity, who he is, and where he came from.This film started many things and decided to give them up. At first it seems a film to look into the undercurrent of violence in even the most domestic of communities. Then it seems to be a film of mistaken identity and bad fate. Then it just decides to be another story of a man escaping a past he didn't like, and finding out that he can't... as in, what we've seen many many times before.But it's a Cronenberg film. This means that it's stylized, interesting, and special, right? Honestly, I saw nothing in this film that struck me particularly as "something only Cronenberg could do." Sure, there's some pretty detailed gore effects, but they're sporadic, random, and worst of all, not needed for anything. Sure, there's some strange sexual encounters, but they don't really seem as anything except for sex, they don't develop the characters, they don't add anything to the story, they just exist in a sort of acceptable state of "Well, might as well find a way to show these characters having sex." They do reveal that Viggo Mortensen doesn't have that great of a body, if anybody cares about that.Speaking of the writing, indeed, it doesn't seem real care or interest was put into the script. Nothing particularly new is given us, the dialog could have been cut and pasted in any other movie of this genre, and the character development was, again, straight-forward and unappealing.As I mentioned before, I thought a large part of the lethargy in this film had something to do with the theme of violence as an undercurrent, but my mistake was thinking there was a theme. Even during moments when the action starts to pick up, it feels like the actors are really just sleep-walking through their roles. Only Ed Harris seemed to have any fun at all, everything else about this movie seems as though Cronenberg forced the cast and crew to stay awake for 24 hours before filming began to make everything seem lazy. Even the cinematography seems lazy after the wonderful long take at the beginning. However, stuff like the close-ups never really added to drama but more made me frustratingly want to take the director's chair and say, "All right, move back a couple of feet, give us some room!" It's not a bad film. It's just that the ending credits came up after an exhaustingly long ending sequence of no importance and I couldn't help asking, "Oh? So what?" This film is a good film to have some fun over the weekend with, but it's not really anything that can stick with you.--PolarisDiB

reviewText: "A History of Violence" is a thoroughly entertaining film.  It is filled with tension, pregnant pauses in the dialogue, and unease from start to finish.  The movie also has some great moments of dark humor that break the tension from time to time, allowing it build again.  All in all, I think this is a great movie.  But, it is probably not everyone's style: if you are looking for the usual Hollywood ending with complete resolution, this is not the film for you.The film begins with the small town family of Tom Stall living the American dream in a small town somewhere in Indiana.  Stall is forced to defend himself and his patrons when some villains attempt to rob and murder at his small diner.  The celebrity that comes along with his daring rescue leads to unwanted attention that brings a cast of entirely un-Stall like characters crawling out of his past- a past that he denies existed.  This tension rises to the memorable climax in a movie that I think can be considered a modern classic of suspense and psychological thrill.David Cronenberg uses some fairly graphic violence to tell his story, and he manages it without going over the top; however, if you are turned off by violence don't watch this movie.  The actors are all well casted, and Vigo Mortensen sheds his stereotype and shines in this new role.  Ed Harris is at the peak of his form and William Hurt also does a great job with his small but important role.  I am not used to seeing Maria Bello, but she is obviously a great actor, and does a very nice job.  Ashton Holmes also brings a unique perspective and dimension to the movie that would have been lacking had he not used his talents so well.
summary: Small town hero with a big city skeleton in the closet

reviewText: This film is blunt, concise, and extremely well directed and acted.  I was compelled to write this review because of the great job done with the extras on the dvd. There is a lenghty making of feature that really demonstrates the fine craftsmanship and intelligence that went into this effort.  If you just saw this in the theater and came out somewhat satisfied, you owe it to yourself to at least rent this dvd, if only to check out the documentaries.

reviewText: This is an interesting, if brutal, movie.In it, Viggo Mortensen plays a Dr. Jekyll who is gradually revealed to be harboring a Mr. Hyde inside.The revelation disrupts--although it saves--his family completely.  For physical survival, he trades emotional health.The movie is a flip of Cronenberg's "Eastern Promises."  There, Mortensen plays a Mr. Hyde, a Russian mobster, who is gradually revealed to have a Dr. Jekyll inside."Violence" integrates the emotional (the female) part of the movie with the violent (male) part of "Eastern Promises."But both movies do a very good job of contrasting, and interweaving the two incompatible sides.Offbeat and disturbing and memorable.

reviewText: The title pretty much says it all.  Based on a graphic novel, it's not nearly as violent as Sin City, but much more realistic; not nearly as original and stylish as Road To Perdition, but more contemporary.  It's about a small town family man  (Viggo Mortensen) who draws media attention with a heroic act of violence (ok, a violent act of heroism).  A mobster (Ed Harris) accuses him of being a former Mafia killer in hiding.  This leads to considerably more violence.  The story keeps you interested, nothing more.  Ed Harris (Milk Money) is effective but I think he would have been great in the lead role.  William Hurt (Lost In Space) does a near-perfect Keenan Wynn impression as a loud-mouthed gangster.

reviewText: This film is extremely promising.  In spite of the seeming pretension of the long take opening scene, up until about the 60% mark, the film has a number of nice setups and pay offs.  While the characters seem very simplistically written, the fact remains it's how most people like these actually behave.  In spite of what happens later, I think the same holds true for William Hurt's character: that's actually how Philly gangsters talk and act.  I know people from that region who've been connected to the crime scene there, and Hurt simply plays it from a slightly classier standpoint...but we're talking Philly and crime, so it's not that classy.  The guy still probably never misses a NASCAR race in town, though he'd be in the premium seats with bodyguards.The sex scenes also appear very obvious and simplistic, but they're again totally realistic representations of how people (who aren't duds in the sack, that is) have sex and express those kinds of feelings.  The depictions of violence are fairly well done, and don't shy away in the least from showing what's happening, or what has happened to the dead or dying.  My primary problem with the film, however, is that if the rest of it was done as well as the sex and killing scenes, this would have been amazing.  That simplistic, obvious, and general lack of subtext to the dialog, actions, or character development just falls flat in too many places where it's needed.  There's a lot about this film I liked, but the script time and again felt like it was a first-time unpolished, underdeveloped draft by a recent film student who happened to have a bunch of really great ideas but simply couldn't fill in enough of the meat and potatoes that make up true cinema.In its totality, A History of Violence feels like it's being done to tell a moral or exercise a point.  I don't think any viewer who hasn't read reviews of the film or interviews with Cronenberg will have any idea as to what that is.  For these average viewers, the simplistic, obvious, bland quality that presents repeatedly in the film will simply fail to move them enough, especially in the second half.  And when you get to the end's kitchen table scene, the contrived avoided looks, the tear...that all sounds like it was a script that wasn't fully developed where it should have been, yet over directed and scripted out every single glance and emoting on the page when it shouldn't have, right down to that tear.  Scripts by fully developed screen writers are not like that.  It's too bad Cronenberg isn't a better writer himself, because higher-end writer/directors are able to take a script like this and either rewrite it or throw out the obvious and/or confining aspects, and that didn't happen here.I can certainly see why so many quality actors would have come on board, since so much of what they were supposed to feel and do would have been, again, obvious and spelled out, almost like a short novel.  If the ideas and character arcs are there, those qualities that would later harm the shot film if not taken out can actually make the ideas more accessible and appealing to those actors being exposed to them.  It's really too bad, because this had the makings of something special and important.  With some polishing by a better screenwriter and perhaps a quote by Richard Dawkins in the beginning to put the whole "survival of the fittest" theme Ebert points out on our brains for the duration, this could have been a five star work.Let me also add that Mark nnn below is totally wrong in saying the film needed more resolution and explanation of what will happen to the characters later.  That's the sort of crap Spielberg gets fixated on now..."and this character bought a condo, and these ones lived happily ever after, and blah, blah, blah."  Part of the art form is knowing when to end it, even if that means losing a whole sequence that you've already shot, edited, and scored.  I feel bad not giving this film four stars, but there are four star films with less potential that are still executed in a better way that edge it out.  Certainly it does feel awkward giving a film like this the same grade as I gave Mission Impossible 2, but I don't see any other alternative.

reviewText: A History of Violence is a thoughtful, if violent movie. It serves as proof that Viggo Mortensen can act outside of Lord of the Rings, and features other great performances from a talented cast, including Maria Bello, Ed Harris, and William Hurt.Set in a small-town Midwest setting, the story starts with an attempted robbery in a diner (which most certainly would have ended with the death of the patrons and staff of the diner), and leads into the unraveling of main character Tom Stall's (VM) life, as big-city mobsters are drawn to the small town by the TV coverage, believing Stall to be a long-missing mobster. Tom's family structure is put under ever-increasing tension by the presence of the obsters, their allegations, and the growing suspicion within the family. Throughout, Stall fights for the family life he has built over the years.The movie is well-directed, with tension building and building, along with our sympathy for Stall. The violence shows up infrequently, but with a stacatto-like precision that does not relieve the tension, but rather adds to it. In the end, there may be hope for Stall, that his family may pull itself back together, and this is a fitting closing.Howard Shore did the soundtrack for the movie. It's a good soundtrack, but since I did know this going into the theatre, I found it a little distracting, as sometimes there are (perhaps imagined) echoes of the LOTR soundtrack.This is not a movie for young children. Once again, I was disturbed by how young children were in a movie with brutal violence. When you hear a five-year-old ask "Is that the bad man?" in the theatre, you have to wonder.A definite recommendation here!
summary: A violent past, a peaceful present...what of the future?

reviewText: A History of Violence (David Cronenberg, 2005)The Oscars, this year as most years in the past quarter century, were widely considered a joke. One of the main reasons for this is that A History of Violence was overlooked-- robbed, many thought-- for a Best Picture nomination. I've now seen it, and I'll add my voice to those who believe it should not only have been nominated, but that it should have won.David Cronenberg's films are never less than excellent, and A History of Violence is a watershed for him in many ways-- "his best film since" is a phrase that was made for this film, and while every Cronenberg fan will probably give you a different movie to fill that blank, I'm going all the way back to Scanners-- and I say this as someone who has loved every movie Cronenberg has made between the two. This is not only because Cronenberg has recaptured the raw, ugly essence of his low-budget days, which had slid under the radar a tad, but because the adaptation takes a lot of risks-- and gets away with all of them.The first point is simply Cronenberg being Cronenberg; everything he touches turns to gold. The casting decisions are solid, if nothing surprising (Viggo Mortensen playing a taciturn good guy, Ed Harris playing a taciturn bad guy-- yeah, that's a real stretch), and the actors are top to bottom good performers. Cronenberg's sense of chiaroscuro is second nature by now, as is his ability to judge pace. When you see a movie directed by David Cronenberg, you're going to get your money's worth.This one is different thanks to Josh Olson. Yes, that Josh Olson. Watching this movie, you will find it very hard to believe that the man responsible for Infested came up with this adaptation (going from Infested to a Best Adapted Screenplay Academy Award nomination-- with nothing in between-- is an achievement that, I don't believe, has ever been seen in Hollywood; it would be like Traci Lords having picked up a Best Actress nom for the first role of her post-porn career). Granted, John Wagner's original graphic novel is a minor gem in its own right, but what makes the film so amazing-- to those of us who've read it, anyway-- is that Olson read the novel a few times, picked up his pen, and just went off on his own.Specifically, trying to do this without giving spoilers, there's a point about halfway through the novel/film that marks a turning point for the Stall family. At this point, the novel becomes a superhero comic, really, albeit a hugely satisfying one. Had Olson stayed true to the material, it would still have made a bang-up movie. (Truth be told, I was looking forward to seeing what Cronenberg did with the now-absent basement that forms the climax of the novel.) But at this point, Olson runs off with his own story, and the second half of the movie has not one jot to do with the second half of the novel, and it's still brilliant. Olson's screenplay gives us a darker, grimmer, and far more morally ambiguous storyline (and hero), and there's not a single place where Olson or Cronenberg bent that part of the script to cater to the original novel. This may not sound like much, but believe me, the rarity of such a thing in modern Hollywood cannot be overstated.David Cronenberg has made a truly fantastic movie here. That it got overlooked for a Best Picture nomination is, well, par for the course. **** ?

While I could have done without the closeups of smashed noses and shredded faces, it does bring it home.  But the theme of the film - how the psychology of the entire family is affected when secrets are revealed - makes this unusual and special.  The actors are simply wonderful as well.Recommended.  You either get it and like it, or you don't.

reviewText: ***1/2David Cronenberg's "A History of Violence" works pretty well for the first two-thirds of its running time, then slithers to pieces in a slew of implausibilities and mob-movie clichés.Tom Stall is a genial man living an unobtrusive and generally happy life with his wife and two children in rural Indiana.  All that changes one night, however, when two armed men enter his diner, threatening to kill him, his customers and his employees.  When Tom turns the tables on the perpetrators, killing them instead, he is immediately acclaimed a hero by the townsfolk and the local media, until some mysterious men in suits arrive a few days later, implying that Tom may actually be an ex-mobster named Joey Cusack gone into hiding.  Even his wife and teenaged son begin to suspect that the man they know as husband and father may, in fact, be a complete stranger to them.In terms of its substance and style, this is one of Cronenberg's most straightforward, least esoteric works.  Derived from the graphic novel by John Wagner and Vince Locke, the film asks the fascinating question of whether it is possible for a killer to ever truly find redemption and escape the sins of his past.  The movie is at its most compelling when concentrating on the effect the life-shattering realization has on the people closest to Tom, the almost ambivalent way in which his wife and son are both appalled and strangely titillated by discovering that the man they knew as a decent family man may instead be a cold-blooded killer.  For the most part, the film is thoughtful and well-paced, taking time to establish the details and rhythms of life in a rural setting before slowly laying out the complex melodrama that eventually ends up engulfing the characters.However, in the last half hour, the movie reveals some of the weaknesses inherent in movies derived from graphic novels.  When Tom/Joey heads back to Philadelphia for a confrontation with his mob boss brother (hammily overplayed by a balding William Hurt), the film devolves into a series of highly implausible fight scenes that look as if they have, indeed, been lifted straight off the pages of a comic book.  Thus, all the efforts to make the story ring true pretty much fly out the window at this point.  Moreover, the final scene of family reconciliation resembles one of those bad codas one finds in "meaningful" plays by first-year drama students.  It's too carefully worked out, too deliberately staged, and too cute by half to be truly effective.Viggo Mortensen underplays nicely in his role of a passive man who may be a powder keg of violence and emotion under his placid surface, and Maria Bello registers just the right amount of devotion and befuddlement in the part of his wife.  Ed Harris also scores as the scarred, half-blinded gangster who winds up shattering the family's idyllic life.All in all, "A History of Violence" is a fascinating, albeit deeply flawed, work that never lives up to its full potential.  It's a finely directed and well acted film, but something about it just doesn`t ring entirely true.

reviewText: I don't know why this movie received such critical acclaim. The villains are completely improbable, comic-book characters whom the hero is forced to take on and try to defeat with stunning kung-fu action.The first scene is good. On the surface, everything in it looks casual, normal. But it has a nightmare quality. Every chair, every door seems to possess a strange, silent inner heat and heft, as if it had been forged in the hot coals of Hell and can incinerate anyone who comes too close.But when the film moves from this atmosphere pregnant with malign intent - and shifts to actual villainous confrontation - it completely loses its way and becomes simply ludicrous. There are phalanxes of avenging mobsters from Filly. There is one blood bath after another. The shoot-em-up cliche of old westerns seems to apply - all the hero's bullets hit their mark; all the villains' bullets miss or simply maim.Then the fact that this movie is largely a man's comic book fantasy is also betrayed in the relationship between husband and wife. The audience is presumably meant to be given a stake in the hero's success by virtue of his loving family life. We should root for him because he has something worthwhile to live for - the love of his wife and children. But again as has become cliche in so many movies, this love is demonstrated by the fact that his wife is drop-dead gorgeous and is given to treating her husband by acting out frolicking soft-core porn fantasies.No, the whole thing just doesn't wash. A love worth fighting for and living for to me would look more like an average couple digging up their septic drain and not hating it, because they are doing it together. Not so cinematic perhaps, but more indicative of an abiding love worth fighting for.So all we are left with here is a series of improbable events and improbable characters. There are lots of shotgun blasts and bangs, but the film's message is ultimately a whimper. If you want a movie that does the choreography of gore better - rent Reservoir Dogs or Pulp Fiction. If you want a recent movie that gives a more realistic view of how violence is bred by subtle slights - rent Bubble.

reviewText: David Cronenberg (The Fly (Two-Disc Collector's Edition),Videodrome - Criterion Collection) is an artful and masterful director.  There's no denying it.  The man behind such films asDead Ringers - Criterion Collection,Naked Lunch - Criterion CollectionandShiverscomes with this film, a stark difference from his fist films of the century.A History of Violence is about a man who, after becoming a local hero, is hounded by a couple of mobsters who believe he is someone else.The strength in this movie isn't the script alone, it's the directing of one David Cronenberg.  A movie that you should see, maybe it'll spark your interest in the often overlooked David Cronenberg.The DVD includes a commentary from the director, a few featurettes going over every aspect of the filmmaking, a "Too Commercial for Cannes" feature, a deleted scene, and the behind the scenes of that deleted scenes.Highly recommended.

reviewText: David Cronenberg's "A History of Violence" is a watered-down version of "Mystic River," with Viggo Mortensen pouring both the Tim Robbins and Sean Penn roles of that movie into one man. Mortensen does good work, and Cronenberg presents an interesting character study. But it is not the great film some critics suggest to be; the movie discards its plot to morph intoan explotation flick. Adapted from a comic book, "A History of Violence" does not, as "Road To Perdition" did, rise above the pulp. Its, blood and otherwise, are a turn off.The movie opens in Millbrook, Ind., and Tom Stall's (Mortensen) diner. Tom's a deliberate, shy man, edging toward courtly, with a supportive wife (Maria Bello), a sweet but angry son (Ashton Holmes) and a little daughter who exists mostly to be in danger. One night two mean-spirited crooks come through Tom's diner to rob the place, and probably kill the patrons. Tom rather efficiently kills them instead. He's a local hero and in the news. A few days later a black car comes around. Its occupants are gangsters from Philadelphia. Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris) is the leader of this crew, and he seems to know Tom. As a guy from Philly named Joey. Joey's the strongman who gouged Carl's left eye out, and half his face. Tom doesn't know who Joey is. Says Carl, "I can still see out of this eye, but all I see is Joey."Behind the mystery of Tom, Joey and Carl Fogarty is a mob boss named Richie Cusack, played by William Hurt with bemused menace. Shades of Jimmy Cagney, it's an excellent, over-the-top performance, and once we meet Richie we understand a lot more about Tom, and the final 15 minutes of "A History of Violence" are excellent. Visceral. Mean. Worthy of a good crime picture.The movie's weakness is its buildup, which to work requires Fogarty to hang around, a lot, when any competent gangster would have snatched Tom up in the back alley and went to work on him without announcing his intentions. The gang is a cipher, a possible reminder of Tom's past, but not able to function as mobsters would. We've seen too many "Goodfellas" to expect this elaborate stalking act. Cronenberg needs it to chart its effect on Tom's family, which undergoes quick changes, culminating in a scene between Mortensen and Bello that isn't enjoyable or likely.Cronenberg assembled some of these same ingredients in "Crash," which skewed the world as a means of talking about theories of evil. "A History of Violence" is wrapped up in this argument of nature vs. nurture, of Tom and Joey. Mortensen delivers a strong two-sided performance - Tom is one innocent, convincing liar - and Bello continues solid supporting work - she'll have a shot at an Oscar nomination. But both actors are playing out theory than reality. The message is interesting. The plot is a bit absurd.
summary: More of a theory than a great film
Title: N/A

reviewText: A History of Violence starts out with a violent acts and ends in one of acceptance of the violent nature of human beings.  Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) becomes the town hero after dispatching two would-be burglars with surprising ease.  His face is splashed all over the news, which brings a couple of Philadelphia mobsters into town thinking Tom is an old colleague of theirs.Viggo Mortensen does an excellent job playing the sweet family man, but there is something strange about his aloofness that makes you wonder if he is the Philly mob man Joey Cusack.  I think Viggo and Maria Bello did excellent jobs in this movie.  They played both sides of the coin - anger/love, passivity/violence, rejection/acceptance - extremely well.  It's like someone set the coin on its side and flicked it so it spun around so fast that it all blurs together.  I hadn't really heard of Maria Bello before, but this great performance (and realizing she was the alcohol advocate in Thank You for Smoking) will make me remember her name and seek out any forthcoming movies she is in.  A good role for Ed Harris.  The children was definitely not the best part of the movie and tended to overact.The plot of the movie wasn't that strong.  It was somewhat predictable and a little out there.  But it shows how strong the direction was because, in my opinion, the audience feels a very strong physical and emotional impact from the movie.  The scenes of love anda family life drawn one in because of the intamacy, and the scenes of violence shock because of the ease in which they come and the quickness in which they are carried out.Great movie.

reviewText: I was anxious to watch 'A History Of Violence' because I had heard it was quite, well, violent.  While there are two very exceptionally gross scenes, the violence unfortunately didn't fit it with the rest of the movie.  For the most part, 'A History Of Violence' is a rather boring movie that takes a long time to get going.Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) owns a diner in the quiet, rural town of Millbrook, IN, has a beautiful wife and two well-behaved children.  When two thugs enter his diner with intent to cause violence, Tom takes them out with skill and finesse (along with the first gruesome scene).  Now a local hero splashed across the news, the diner is running full speed when another thug named Fogarty (Ed Harris) shows up, acting strange and calling Tom by the name Joey Cusack.As Fogerty stalks Tom and his family, he reveals more and more about the Joey Cusack he is looking for, and Tom's claims that he is not Joey become weaker.  Also looking for Joey is Philly mob-boss Richie Cusack (John Hurt), Joey's brother, but why does Richie want to find Joey so badly?There are two love scenes in the film between Edie Stall (Mario Bello) and husband Tom that are awful.  The first during the long, boring stretch at the beginning of the film, attempting to indicate what a loving husband and father Tom is, was so silly and contrived that I didn't know whether to laugh or throw up.  The second, rougher scene on the steps only left me yawning and wondering why Edie didn't have more bruises on her back later that night.The overall feeling of the movie was that the entire film went overboard on both the calm and the cruelty in an effort to instill more shock value to Tom's flashes of brutality.  It failed, simply because it tried too hard.  A more balanced flow throughout the film would have made a better movie.  The ending to the film is flat and lifeless, horribly trite, cheesy, and abrupt.Still, 'A History Of Violence' manages to wring three stars from me for the efforts of Ed Harris, Maria Bello, John Hurt, and Viggo Mortensen for performing their roles well in spite of the script, and for the two gruesomely bloody scenes involving a jaw and a nose.  Strawberry jam, anyone?

reviewText: I have to admit that I find David Cronenberg's movies a little too "juicy" (not in the apple juice sense, either) to be truly enjoyable.  I like being unsettled as much as the next moviegoer, but too many of his past movies have left me a mite cold even as I admire his eccentric wit and craft."A History of Violence" changed much of my opinion of Mr. Cronenberg and his art.  This is an intelligent movie (no surprise there for Mr. Cronenberg, admittedly) that uses the director's trademark fixation on gore and the "true grit" of the human body as a stark, effective counterpoint.There are two worlds intertwined in "A History of Violence."  One world could have been lifted from the pages of Garrison Keillor or a family-friendly sitcom.  This the world of Tom Stall (Viggo Mortenson, looking very un-Aragornish), husband, father, and proprietor of the local diner in the middle of Everytown, Indiana.  Tom's corn-fed yet gorgeous wife Edie (Maria Bello) is a talented local lawyer, and her idea of a kinky Saturday night is to send the kids to the sitter and dress up in her old cheerleader outfit for some serious hanky-panky.The other world is the world of Joey Cusack.  Cusack was a brutal enforcer in the Philadelphia criminal underworld, but he hasn't been heard from in twenty years.That is, until two murderous thieves make the mistake of trying to knock over Tom Stall's diner one night.  Faced with murder and mayhem, Tom reacts instinctively, and unleashes murder and mayhem on his own in a way that doesn't seem quite right for the quiet family man who runs the local diner.From here, all bets are off as the link between Joey and Tom gets drawn in greater detail.  This is a first-class idea for a movie executed by first-class talent (Mortensen and Bello give excellent lead performances, and look for great "supporting" work by Ed Harris and William Hurt).  While there are several scenes of graphic sex and violence, this is first and foremost a movie about ideas.  And these ideas can lead you into some uncomfortable rooms.True to form, Cronenberg makes "A History of Violence" an unsettling experience.  Most directors are content to take the story of a child fighting off the local bully to its logical, positive conclusion that justifies your universal right to stand up for yourself.  But Cronenberg twists this slightly -- what if, by standing up for yourself, you take unfair advantage of the bully because, unknown to the bully, you have inherited a gift for causing pain and using your fists?  Is it right to beat up the guy who's bullying you if you can send him to the hospital?This is just one of the questions "A History of Violence" tosses at you -- and all of those questions are equally unanticipated and challenging.Cronenberg is a filmmaker uniquely capable of asking these questions and not giving you a clear answer.  In a maddening development, many loose ends are left unresolved at the end of the movie -- indeed, there are so many that I can't give the movie the five stars I want to bestow upon it.  Call me a simpleton, but I like resolution.  A few loose threads are fine, but give me something more than a family staring down at the dinner table, silently contemplating an ominous, unsettling future.
summary: Excellent, dark, disturbing "little film" raises questions of identity, love and nature

reviewText: Imagine if Fritz Lang or Alfred Hitchcock had a crack at "A History of Violence." The legendary filmmakers certainly would have jettisoned screenwriter Josh Olsen's sloppy adaptation of the popular graphic novel. David Cronenberg, on the other hand, goes full speed ahead - embracing the  needless subplots and gradual implausibilities. There are effective performances by Viggo Mortensen, Ed Harris and William Hurt, but it's all for naught. Wildly overrated upon release, this disappointing crime-thriller was deservedly panned by some of the more-perceptive critics.

reviewText: It's difficult to discuss the themes explored in this movie without giving too much away. Suffice it to say Tom Stall may, or may not, have a violent past that is entirely at odds with the life he's led for the last twenty years. After defending himself and his employees when his small-town diner is randomly targeted by a couple of itinerant psychopaths Tom is catapulted into the media spotlight, which in turn brings him to the attention of a mobster who claims to know him. Has Tom reinvented himself after a gruesome past as a violent gangster or is it a case of mistaken identity? If he was a ruthless and efficient killer can he expect to be able to escape that past?Even if you find the central premise of the film a little hard to swallow A History of Violence is a powerful and at times moving portrayal of a man's fight to keep his life and family intact in the face of increasingly violent intrusions. There's even some very dark humour, especially when William Hurt gives his marvellously cheesy performance.

reviewText: Emily Dickinson once said "Hope is that thing with feathers". Woody Allen called his second book "Without Feathers" in clever disagreement. A History of Violence, I suppose, is a thing with feathers too because Cronenberg is as sharp and original as Allen, but he hasn't lost hope. This fine production is an ambient, thought-provoking, and often a downright chilling meditation on the causes of violence and its unexpected yet inevitable ramifications. At its heart, it's a story of faith and forgiveness, of the enduring ability of man to bury his past and start over.The film is studded with radiant performances. The always underrated Viggo Mortenson (because I have never once been bored by a film that had him in it) is ideally cast as Tom, a man with the gift of killing, trying to recreate his life as a simple pastoral family man. Looking almost like Gary Cooper but with a dark edge, Mortenson powerfully plays the role right on the balance between decency and denial. Even more impressive is Maria Bello, who simply electrifies as his wife Edie, especially as the revelations transform her existence. A certain stairway scene with Mortenson and Bello brings to life a visceral energy that scorches the screen. Ashton Holmes is terrific as their teenage son Jack, who must tap into his own reserves to tackle a high school bully. William Hurt is surprisingly ferocious and barely resembles the man who bumbled about as a philistine professor inOne True Thing. Ed Harris looks more feral than any other persona he has played on screen but is snug in the skin of his character.To tell too much more would be to ruin the plot, but suffice it to say that the movie echoes with flashes of unflinching violence that only Cronenberg can pull off without being gratuitous. Don't read too much into laments that it is all too brutal; it isn't. Whatever action there is, is so perfectly placed and shown with such hot-penny realism that the foreboding title falls short of what it promises. This is a distinctly subdued endeavor from the director behind the head explosions inScannersor the gooey transformations in the 1986 remake ofThe Fly.The screenplay and the pace are a throwback to Client Eastwood's Dirty Harry movies: tranquil, but with sensational interludes flowing naturally when action is necessary. Cronenberg and screenwriter Josh Olson do not slather contrivances to hit home obvious points in their story, and the ending is effectively, hauntingly open-ended. All said and done, it throws down a moral gauntlet about changing one's path in life. The manner in which each character copes with this possibility is richly presented.A word for the "Platinum Series" DVD package. It contains one of the best Making Of documentaries I have seen for a major release, an hour-long feature called "Acts of Violence". It is divided effectively into eight bits with particularly thoughtful comments from Cronenberg, Mortenson and Bello. Cronenberg also provides terrific commentary on an alternate audio track, and there are actually two extras related to a deleted fantasy scene that reflects the more typically gory side of Cronenberg's style. Having seen the end product, I must say the editing was spot-on.This one is a classic, with a message as hard-hitting, as compassionate asAmerican History Xor the Indian filmGardish. Get one for your library if it isn't already in it. Must-watch, must-buy, must recommend on to friends and all those for whom you care.
summary: GRIPPING STORY OF REDEMPTION THAT WILL CHALLENGE YOUR MORAL GAUGE WITH FIENDISH AUDACITY

reviewText: I had heard nothing but kudos about "A History of Violence" and certain critics bemoaning the fact that this film did not make the Oscar cut, so I was ready to pop in the DVD and be amazed.Maybe I had my hopes just too high, but I was disappointed.The story centers on Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen), a small town family man who runs a local diner, his wife Edie (Maria Bello), and their two children, Jack (who is being bullied at school by the local high school sports hero-jackass) and Sarah (who suffers from nightmares). Basically, your average American family, at least on the surface.One day, two thugs from out of town stop in to the diner intending to rob it and kill everyone (Tom, his two employees and two teens on a date) present.  Tom ends up kicking some major butt and killing the two thugs in under thirty seconds.  The news media, in what is obviously a slow news week, descends on Tom's small town and makes him an overnight media hero.  This is where the real problems start for Tom.Before you know it, men from Philly show up (including Ed Harris, spectacular as always and in much too small of a role) claiming that Tom is really Joey Cusack from Philly, a bad guy/hitman type.Is Tom really Joey?  Did he run from the mob?  If he was Joey, is it possible that he left all that behind is now Tom?  How will his family react?The idea is a good one, with many possibilities but this is where the movie fell apart for me.  The film left a huge dramatic possibility in the scene where Jack ends up beating the tar out of the kid bullying him.  This certainly should have opened a well of conflicts in Tom - - did he pass this "trait" along to his son?  How could he tell him not to punch someone, given his violent background?  Did the film show Tom grappling with this conflict, maybe even a worry that Jack might end up just like Tom?  Nope.  Tom tells Jack that their family doesn't hit people, Jack makes a smart-alecked remark, Tom slaps Jack and that's the end of it.  Edie at least throws up upon learning of her husband's sordid background, and gets in a slapping, shoving and punching fight with him - - that ends up with the two of them having sex on the stairs.  Yes, that's right - - having violent sex on the stairs.  I had a hard time believing this - - not just because Edie had just seen her husband kill two men, but she had also found out about his past - - and let's not forget, that they have two children at home who could have walked in any moment.But even forgetting about those problems, the ending was a massive disappointment.  Tom returns from Philly, after having seen Richie Cusack, Joey's brother (a nice little cameo by William Hurt).  Edie, Jack and Sarah are having dinner and Tom walks in.  My first thought was that if I was Edie I would have changed the locks.  But that's just me - - Tom walks in, sits down at the dinner table, everyone looks at each other and the  movie fades out.  What??  What kind of sorry ending is THAT?  It tells us nothing - - had Edie just accepted her husband?  Are they just never going to mention this again?  Disappointing is an understatement, this ending was a complete let down and a complete sell out.Overall, other than Ed Harris, none of the acting performances jumped out at me and I really didn't understand what all the critics were doing putting this film on their Top Ten list for the year.  Definitely some better choices out there.Maybe the film might have done a little more for me had it just focused on Tom's family life and the effect this had on his family - - or maybe had Ed Harris played Tom the movie might have had a different flavor.But I'm giving it 2 stars, for Ed Harris' performance.

reviewText: This is another classy film from director David Cronenberg. Its a compelling story of a normal guy running a Coffee bar who's life changes dramtically when some nasty characters turn up late one evening and try and rob the place.This is cleverly done, excellently acted, especially by Ed Harris and William Hurt in their supporting roles. The film is concise being just over 90 minutes, and certainly I couldn't predict where it was going. Cronenberg as always directs with his unique style. This film is certainly more mainstream than most of his, but it is in a different class from your average Hollywood thriller.Whether the premise of the film is believable or not is irrelevent; this is a great piece of entertainment from the spooky opening right through to the end. The film is probably nearer 5 stars for me, and further viewings will no doubt confirm this.

reviewText: Scanners. The Fly. The Dead Zone. David Cronenberg has done it again. Another fast paced, highly entertaining film. And A History of Violence is definitely Cronenberg's best submission since Dead Ringers back in 1988.Viggo Mortenson (who plays Tom Stall...or is it really Joey Cusack???) is awesome, believable and keeps the audience glued to the screen on which he is in almost every scene. He's cleaned up and hardly even resembles his character from the Lord of the Rings Trilogy (he was the scraggly looking warrior Aragorn in Rings). He portrays his character flawlessly and makes the underlying plot seem very realistic.Basically the movie is about how mild mannered Tom Stall (Mortenson) thwarts a robbery by couple of thugs and disposes of them almost effortlessly, which gains national news headlines. A day later Tom gets a visit from a scary looking Ed Harris who accuses Tom of actually being a different person with A History of Violence that promises to bring Tom big trouble. And the rest of the movie is the suspenseful tale of how Tom deals with this new threat to his life.Overall, it's a good movie to rent. A Golden Globe nomination for Best Picture seems a bit excessive to me for such a simple story. Clearly there would have been no movie if the supposedly "well organized" bad guys just snuck into town and whacked Tom instead of announcing their arrival with pompous fanfare, and that's a pretty large hole that's hard to overlook.Otherwise, A History of Violence is a sure thing for suspense/thriller fans. Definitely worth the rental time from the local video store...perhaps not a collector's item for purchase though.
summary: History of Some Pretty Decent Films

reviewText: With Cronenberg normally you get in your face wierdness, very complex plots exploring the nature of the bizarre and filled with strange devices and themes. This film is almost a reverse of that, there is nobody more boring and down to earth as Viggo Mortenson's character and his familly. A quiet self-effacing man with an aggressively pacifist son and a devoted wife living in Suburbia. But this character is a [...], a re-invention of the old Joey who was a ruthless nihilistic killer. Throughout the movie the new Joey is presented with challenges to his new persona and these come from his past and while he meets each of them fully his new gentle persona slowly starts to erode a bit. Joey himself is like 'The Bride' from Kill Bill, only instead of seeking revenge he is protecting himself from it. When attacked he can certainly handle himself, and the violence is very strong. There is also a subplot involving two wandering killers, in the beginning when one of them shoots a little girl and then the camera changes to show Joey we see a great resemblance between the young killer and Joey - no doubt done deliberately it had me thinking the young killer WAS Joey in his youth, i think Cronenberg cast a young actor with a resemblance to Mortenson for this very purpose, it is perhaps the only really visceral image of Joey in his violent youth we are allowed to have (even if it is illusory). I do think the film was not fleshed out enough, not enough happens to keep the viewers' interest and Joey himself remains something of an enigma right up the end. I kind of like a 'Taxi driver' interpretation for the whole film, perhaps Joey is deluding himself about all these violent encounters with super villains? Perhaps he is an ordinary guy in an ordinary job with an ordinary familly and wishes he were someone else? Evidence for this includes the almost comic book nature of his martial prowess in fighting the villains - his 'history of violence' serving his fantasy as a badge of machismo and his good guy persona acting in self-defence killing bad guys all points to fantasy, the ending were he just walks in and sits down to his familly (who are giving him funny looks) slots in as well. It is possible though i could be over-interpreting it because it is Cronenberg.
